40974110.review:
Celeste is a criminally underrated masterpiece platformer with an emphasis on clearing levels using your moveset in very unique ways.
Levels are beautiful and extremely well designed, with spaces to explore and find secrets. 
Collectibles are woven into the game beautifully, with most of them having no meaning other than just for a sense of achievement.
The difficulty doesnt go full super meat boy on you, with levels having a respectable difficulty curve as you progress the game.

All in all, just an extremely good platformer that you should check out if you like the genre.

40958834.review:
Je fais (très) rarement des évaluations, mais pour le coup je me dois de le faire.

Un jeu de plateforme de type die & retry qui a une progression de la difficulté bien dosée: ça commence vraiment tranquille, et la dificulté ne monte pas d'un coup, et pourtant à la fin du jeu on se retrouve, on se SURPREND à faire des trucs pas évidents.
De plus, en général ce type de jeux vont bien appuyer sur leur difficulté genre "VOUS ALLEZ MOURIR PLEIN DE FOIS AHAHAH, SOUFFREZ !" et là c'est le contraire: on nous encourage à continuer, c'est pas grave si on meurt car on progresse ainsi, on avance. Et c'est rafraichissant d'avoir cette vision de "coopération" dans la progression, et pas de "compétition" contre la difficulté du jeu.

Chaque niveau apporte sa mécanique propre, pour que l'on ne s'ennuie pas à juste sauter et dasher, et ça marche. L'ambiance visuelle et sonore aussi change pour chacun de ces tableaux.
Les collectibles sont pour la plupart totalement optionnels (les fraises), certains autres débloquent des niveaux bonus où là les tryhardeurs vont pouvoir s'abandonner à fond à leur plaisir masochiste.

Plus intéressant encore, c'est que Celeste a un scénario, certes léger dans sa durée et la quantité de dialogues, mais lourd de sens, et porté par le gameplay. Quoi de mieux pour dépasser ses limites que de prendre l'exemple classique de ces alpinistes qui gravissent des montagnes, nous ayant donné l'expression correspondante? Et je vous passe évidemment les détails (certains même cachés de manière inattendue).

Mais revenons un instant à l'ambiance sonore, parce que l'OST (par Lena Raine, ou kuraine) est simplement magnifique! Du piano ou de la chiptune, peu importe, on rentre complètement dans l'ambiance, on est transportés, et encore une fois la musique sert énormément le message porté dans le scénario.

Mon seul regret, mais ce n'est qu'une histoire de goûts: je ne suis pas réellement friand des "boss" dans ce genre de jeux. Mais il faut de tout pour faire un monde, comme dit ce sacré Arnold (non pas le gouverneur).

Vous l'aurez compris, pour moi ce jeu est indispensable pour qui aime la plateforme, la bonne musique, un jeu qui porte un message par plusieurs de ses outils (scénario, musique, mise en scène ET gameplay). Du tout bon.

Bon je vous laisse, maintenant que j'ai fini la partie principale (certes un peu courte), je vais me perdre dans le contenu optionnel (commencé mais, ouch!).

40937545.review:
[h1]Review zu Celeste[/h1]

Celeste selbst mag ja keine Revolution in der Gamingindustrie sein, aber der beigefügte "Assisst-Mode" ist es. Er fördert die Individualität des Spielers. Etwas, das jedes Spiel anstreben sollte. Für alle, die nicht im Bilde sind: Celeste´s Entwickler haben nach der Kontroverse um Cuphead und dessen Schwierigkeitsgrad, entschieden, einen gewissen "Assisst-Mode" ins Spiel zu integrieren. Dieser Assisst-Mode bietet Spielern, die nicht unbedingt jede Herausforderung schaffen möchten, die Möglichkeit sich das Leben leichter zu machen. Man kann damit die Spielgeschwindigkeit einstellen, sodass Projektile und sich bewegende Gegner sich langsamer bewegen, sich selbst unendlich viel Ausdauer verpassen, sodass man unbegrenzt an Klippen hängen kann, sich die Anzahl der Sprints in zwei, oder unendlich an der Zahl einstellen, oder sogar Unverwundbarkeit.
Und ich LIEBE "Matt Makes Games Inc." für diese Entscheidung! Der Assisst-Mode ist das Sprachrohr der etwas schlechteren Spieler. Der Spieler, die keine Lust haben auf frustrierende Tode, die letztendlich auch Zeitverschwendung sind. Denn damit verbringt man einen großen Teil des Spiels: Sterben und seinen ehemaligen Fortschritt in einem Areal zu wiederholen. Ich kann mir nicht vorstellen, dass jemand gerne stirbt. Und seien wir mal ehrlich. Das ist Zeitverschwendung. Ja, ich bin auch einer derjenigen, die sich den Assisst-Mode zunutze gemacht haben. Und ich schäme mich nicht dafür, denn ich WEIß, dass ich gecheatet habe. Allerdings kann ich den Leser beruhigen. Ich habe das Spiel vollkommen normal und ohne Assisst-Mode beendet, doch Dinge, wie die blauen und goldenen Herzen, die goldenen Himbeeren und die erneute Suche nach Erdbeeren habe ich mit Hilfe des Assisst-Modes [i]errungen[/i]. Wer sich das antun möchte, im Falle der goldenen Himbeeren, einen gesamten Kapitel, ohne Tod zu überstehen, bitte sehr. Ich halte dich nicht davon ab. Nur habe [u]ich[/u] keinerlei Lust darauf. Letztendlich, so sagt es das Spiel selbst, beeindruckt man damit nur seine Freunde.
Celeste´s Geschichte beruht auch indirekt auf der Nutzung des Assisst-Mode. Es heißt immer wieder: "Der Berg wird die wahre Natur Madeline´s offenbaren" und somit auch die des Spielers selbst. Nutzt man nun den Assisst-Mode, oder nicht? Ich persönlich habe ihn voller Desinteresse einfach mal angestellt "Könnte ja nützlich sein.", dachte ich mir. Und ich habe mich nicht getäuscht.
Auch wenn Celeste´s Schwierigkeitsgrad hoch angehoben ist, ist es vermutlich sogar möglich das Spiel komplett ohne Assisst-Mode zu schaffen. [u]Ich[/u] persönlich hätte das wohl nicht geschafft und das hat einen ganz simplen Grund: Man kann nicht verschnaufen. Nehmen wir als Beispiel mal den "weißen Palast" aus Hollow Knight. Ein recht schweres Jumpingareal auf einem Niveau, das man vom bisherigen Standpunkt des Spiels nicht gewohnt war. Man hatte im weißen Palast, in Hollow Knight, zwar sehr schwere Jumpingpassagen, aber man konnte sie sich in sicherer Umgebung anschauen und studieren. In Celeste hingegen hat man Areale, die nicht einmal komplett auf dem Bildschirm passen. Heißt: Man spielt sich durch bis dorthin wohin man blicken konnte und muss improvisieren. Oft klappt das nicht. Also muss man die Bewegungen verinnerlichen. Ich persönlich habe dies oft nicht hingekriegt und verlangte sehr viel Schweiß, Tränen und eine gewisse Belastung meiner Stimmbänder, aber irgendwann hab ich es geschafft. Wie gesagt es ist vermutlich möglich das Spiel ohne Assisst-Mode zu beenden, aber dafür braucht man Nerven aus Stahl und viel Geduld, sowie Zeit.
Ich hatte dennoch sehr viel Spaß mit Celeste. Hauptsächlich deshalb, da ich auf Sammlersuche gegangen bin, denn das Spiel weckt wahrlich den Sammlerdrang des Spielers. Und um alle Secrets und Collectibles zu finden muss man viel Neugierde und ein Auge für Details mitbringen! Ich kann es wirklich auch nur jedem ans Herz zu legen: Auch wenn man nicht wirklich eine Herausforderung in Celeste sucht, so sucht man nach Secrets! Vorzugsweise mit dem grandiosen Assisst-Mode!

Kommen wir für die Schnellen unter uns einfach mal zur Pro-Contra-Liste:

[u][b]Pro:[/b][/u]

+ Der Pixelart ist wunderschön und knallbunt! Wirklich eine Augenweide!
+ Auch die gezeichneten comichaften Bilder sind allesamt wirklich niedlich gezeichnet worden!
+ Celeste wird mit einem tollen Soundtrack untermalt! Es gibt sogar noch Remixes der jeweiligen Tracks.
+ Die Soundkulisse von Celeste ist FANTASTISCH!
Hier einfach mal ein kurzes Video dazu:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lMZ_jXrxQoI

+ Es ist tatsächlich möglich nach oben zu gucken! Ein Feature, dass seit Super Mario World ein Muss für jeden Platformer sein sollte! Selbst wenn es keinen Nutzen hat. Es fühlt sich halt einfach falsch an, wenn man nach oben drückt und nichts passiert... Zumindest ergeht es mir so.
+ Sollte man sich in der Kapitelauswahl befinden und sich einen Kapitel und einen Abschnitt des Kapitels aussuchen, so ertönt ein kurzer Ton, welcher zum Soundtrack bei der Kapitelauswahl dazu passt. Ich finde das wirklich faszinierend und man kann so ganz amüsante Eigenkompositionen erschaffen.
+ Ich persönlich bin kein Freund von Abspännen in Videospielen. Anders als in Filmen beendet ein Abspann eine mehrstündige epische Reise und dies ist auch in Celeste der Fall. Allerdings liebe ich es, wenn ein Spiel diese "Wartezeit" mich erstens vorzugsweise überspringen lässt, sofern der Abspann langweilig kreiert worden ist, oder, vorzugsweise, den Abspann kreativ gestaltet. Dies ist wiederrum auch in Celeste der Fall. 

[u][b]Contra:[/b][/u]

- Das Gebrabbel während der Diskussionen nervt stellenweise extrem.
- Es gibt keine Verschnaufspausen, während der Jumppassagen. Etwas, das mich persönlich wirklich extrem stört.
- Grafikeinstellungen sind nur spärlich vorhanden. Sollte jemand FPS-Einbrüche haben. Viel Glück. Am besten vor dem Kauf die Mindestanforderungen checken.
- Steuerung mit dem Stick auf dem Gamepad oft ziemlich unpräzise. Vielleicht sieht das ja mit Maus und Tastatur anders aus, aber das Spiel wirkt einfach so, als wäre es für ein Gamepad geboren worden.
- Hitboxen einiger "Stachelpflanzen" und "stacheliger Hindernisse" ist manchmal nicht nachvollziehbar.

[u][b]Prontra:[/b][/u]

+- Es gibt bedauerlicherweise recht viele Übersetzungsfehler. Auch die fehlende Leerstelle zwischen zwei Wörtern lässt sich öfters beobachten.
+- Sollte man einen Kapitel erneut starten, so wird man wieder mit der Geschichte konfrontiert. Zwar sind alle Filmsequenzen vorspulbar, aber irgendwie nervt selbst das vorspulen.
+- Viele Passagen können nur mit perfektem Timing überwunden werden. Beispielsweise gibt es Wolken, dessen Funktionsweise ich zwar verstehe, aber ich kriege das Timing nie hin und das liegt daran, da man nicht das Momentum ausnutzen soll, sondern am höchsten Punkt der springenden Wolke erst springen soll... (Leute die das Spiel noch nicht gespielt haben, wissen jetzt nicht was ich meine, aber wenn man das Spiel gespielt hat, wird sich der Schleier lüften)
+- Das Spiel hat wirklich STARKE Probleme das Hauptmenü zu öffnen, während man gerade an einer Klippe klettert. Probierts mal aus, das Spiel ist damit wirklich überfordert.

Letztendlich kann ich Celeste vollkommen empfehlen. Es ist zwar kein perfektes Spiel, aber meine Sucht nach Secrets und Herausforderungen wurde durchaus gestillt! Der Normalpreis von 19,99€ ist durchaus empfehlenswert! Ohne den Assisst-Mode kann man allerdings bestimmt 30 bis 35 Stunden mit Respawnen beschäftigt sein!

Ich danke fürs Lesen und wünsche sehr viel Spaß beim Spielen! ;-)

http://store.steampowered.com/app/504230/Celeste/

40886681.review:
While this game has a very good soundtrack, beautiful artwork and a quite fun story, I feel I have to lay some critics here.

If you always play this kind of game on a kwyboard, you're good to go. This game is great to be played on a keyboard.

However, if you're like me and you just can't get enough fun on a platform game without a controller, you'll be in for some trouble. First, you have to know this game is hard. The entire story is based around pushing your limits and discovering how far you can go. So that's cool, I like hard games.

The problem is, if a game wants to push you to your limits, they have to be [i]fair[/i]. My major problem with this game is that, on a controller, the diagonal movement was just too rough. Unless you aim your left stick perfectly at 45 degrees, you just won't get a diagonal dash. You will either get a vertical or a horizontal one, no in-between. While indie games aren't expected to have the most amazing graphics and physics, The roughness of the diagonal dashing makes most of the runs that require it too luck-based. A simple tweak on the directional control during dashes would make this game a lot more fun to be played on the controller. It just feels like they lazily adapted the keyboard buttons to a controller without testing it whatsoever. It is very frustrating to build your skill for 2h on a controller just to find out that it won't do and you have to reset your muscle memory so it works on the keyboard, from scratch.

I desperately want to give this game a positive review. It's beautiful, the music is amazing, the story is pretty damn nice. But please, just please, let me play it in a fair way.

40885642.review: The best platform game experience I have every experienced, with amazing and surprising game mechanics and extremely difficult rooms. After you get everything in the game, you find you can still do more with more challenges, and is simply stunning with its soundtrack and visual graphics. Its story is also very well written, and provides a great reason to be climbing the mountain that you are, with very real world problems that are relatable.

[code]如果想挑战后面的各种高难度，建议一开始就用键盘玩

游戏中还有各种各样的小技巧，我这里就说下几个简单的

爬在墙上边角处可以向上小跳，然后马上反向登墙跳出去，这样可以跳更远，更高

向上冲刺，如果刚好贴着墙，马上按跳跃登墙，可以借助冲刺惯性跳的更远

登墙反向跳是不需要消耗体力的
如果没体力，又需要往上爬，可以不停按跳跃，然后连续按贴着墙的那一面的方向键[/code]

40824097.review:
Celeste is probably one of the best 2D twitch platforming experiences you’ll ever play, and easily sits with other modern classics like Super Meat Boy, Rayman Legends, or Donkey Kong: Tropical Freeze. The controls are dead simple, and easy enough for anyone to pick up. But underneath the basic button scheme is a brilliantly designed, expertly paced, and relentlessly challenging game that never stops introducing clever new mechanics, and fun twists on the traditional run/jump formula. 

The level design constantly encourages you to improve your skills, and the lessons learned from each death will help pull you a little closer to victory on the next run. Even after thousands of deaths, I never stopped having a great time, or felt like the game was unfair – even on challenges that looked impossible at first glance, like some of the diabolically hard post-game “B-sides”.  This feedback loop of incremental improvement gives you a refreshing sense of determination as you play. That feeling  syncs perfectly with the theme of the game’s surprisingly good story, and is hammered home with well written dialog that never lets you forget “you can do this”.

Did I mention that the music is bangin’ too? Because it is. 

If you like platformers, buy this game. If you don’t like platformers, but it anyway, because after a while of playing you probably will.

40811193.review:
I generally had a lot of fun with this game about a girl named Celeste.  She climbs a mountain (omg spoilers oops) and breathes a whole lot.  Just some good solid platforming with enough variation to basic mechanics to keep things interesting while not overstaying its welcome.

But I will admit that sometimes I didn't have fun and it basically came down to whether I was doing a b-side chapter because those things are collectively The Devil and some areas made me want to dropkick children off of houses.  Some places in the game require a certain level of precision and timing that I simply can't perform consistently.  I could know exactly what I needed to do but my stupid fingers wouldn't be able to quite pull it off and that sort of failure leads to a level of frustration comparable to what I will describe as punching my soul in the [Strawberries].

Story-wise, the game has a simple premise with a strong heart.  It leans heavily on the hero's journey template though I think it uses it well.  The characters are good and cool.

The music's really good, though I wouldn't put it in like... Undertale or Nier tier for music.  It does get very close at certain moments (like the prologue).  I like the noises that the game uses in place of voices.   Works out really well.

The UI is simple and does exactly what it needs to.  I do want to give kudos to the developers for implementing some sort of dialogue system in the game.  Unsure if it's gold plating or a feature that was mostly cut out of the game except for the one place that it's used... either way, I appreciate that it's there.

Overall, I enjoyed the game and do recommend it but with the disclaimer that it does require a certain level of manual dexterity and, due to the nature of the game, failure can be very punishing in that it can be very frustrating.

40798971.review:
Under no circumstances do I shed tears over any entertainment media.  Having said that, Celeste currently holds the record for getting me the closest.  The story is awesome, the soundtrack is god-tier, the art is very pretty, and most importantly, the gameplay is solid and satisfying while everything else is going on.  It's an experience.
The platforming gets really hard, but one key thing about Celeste, at least for me, is I can feel myself getting better at it with each attempt at a difficult room.  Going back through some of the earlier levels, rooms that stumped me for legitimately 15 minutes can now be completed in one attempt.  And I'm someone who generally is not very good at difficult games.  Cuphead is too much for me.  And while I've thrown my fair share of curses at Celeste and even ragequit a couple of times, I keep starting it back up and enjoying my time overall.  I've competed the main storyline (took me about 8 hours and 2199 deaths, which the game counts for you) and am currently working on the higher-difficulty B-side levels as well as getting more of the collectible strawberries that the game tucks away in tough-to-reach places.  I'm probably having more fun now than when I started.
And, as I said, the story is amazing.  I'm not going to touch on it here because I don't want to spoil any of it, but you can find information on it pretty easily if you need to know before you buy it.  It's got the thumbs up from me.

40793224.review:
Man, do I want to tell everyone about this game. 
Really, the game is super simple, with three main actions you can do: Jump, Dash, and Grip. You're character's motivation is to climb a mountain because its a hurdle and she needs to prove something to herself that she can do it. The character motivations feel incredibly real to me, that the mountain exists to be conquered, and while it is easier to give up because the task is daunting, accomplishing the feat is a reward on its own. 

Celeste features high quality platforming and very original designs when approaching each segment. The controls are simple but the challenges are numerous and the environment makes the game fun. I cannot sing the game's praise enough. Namely because I haven't found a game that really resonates with myself for a deep need to conquer something if only to say that you did it. 

As a challenge goes, the game offers a core story path, and additional optional challenges and challenge levels that up the difficulty if needed. I wont say that going straight to the goal is particularly tough or easy if you dont collect strawberries, but the strawberry collectibles make some easy segments much harder, and while they don't really do anything they are fun to search for. There are B side levels to each of the main levels you can play. I can only say that I both love and hate the developers for the hell that they created in those levels. Every death is a learning experience and the levels are very completable, but you measure progress in baby steps. Its frustrating, but eventually you overcome the hurdles to achieve your goals. Its hard to explain, but it feels like raw satisfaction to overcome the challenges you face. 


There are times that I feel like giving up when I am doing a challenging segment, but I take a pause, a deep breath, and verbally tell myself "I am capable of doing this" and I resume. The main character is adorable and relatable on so many levels as to why she is conquering the Mountain. I can only sing the developer's praise for creating such a lovely masterpiece with motivations so simple to evoke such a complicated emotional response in me. 

I highly recommend Celeste as a beautiful game, with compelling characters, great level design and mechanics, snappy and responsive controls, great music, and honestly I feel like there is more to love about this game. Its a simple platformer, but you must learn to be tenacious to reach the end. Its a solid 9/10 (personally 10/10).

40747445.review:
Masterpiece.

This game is a spectacle above other games, and it sets an example on how to truly tell a story without sacrificing any aspect of gameplay.

The world is colorful, and inviting. It makes you want to dive in and never come out. I love how the color pallets get darker and darker as the game progresses, finally ending on a bright scheme of bright hues and blinding lights. It is very symbolic.

It will challenge you enough to make you want to quit, but the reward of overcoming such an obstacle is enough to fuel your adrenaline rush. I'm only just now getting involved in the B sides, and while I know that the C sides will make me want to die, I am fully ready and willing to take that risk.

The score is beautiful. It speaks to you as you play through the game, painting a mental picture of what happened to the player character before, what is happening now, and what is to come. It makes you yearn for more. Beautiful.

And the narrative...oh, the narrative. This game is golden. I don't want to spoil anything for anyone, so I wont. Rather, I'll post a video link for those who want to see and hear my complete thoughts on this game. BUt this may be the best story ever told my a developer. Heartwarming, heartfel, painful, yet encouraging...I lost count of the emotions running through me when I was playing this game through for the first time. 

Please, do yourself a favor. Play this game. It helped me contextualize my own emotional issues and really put them in prespective in terms of what is important in my own life, what isn't important, what needs to be cut out, and ultimately, helping me come to terms with my own emotional issues as a whole.

I proudly gave this game a 5 in my review on Youtube. I encourage anyone who hasn't played this to stop what they're doing and to play this game.  

If you're interested in my review, you can check it out here. I don't usually post links in these types of things because I feel like it sort of taboo, but I want to spread the word about this wonderful video game.

You can find my review by heading to my channel. Just type in www.youtube.com/jayboygaming and it will be the first thing you see. This isn't a call for subs, either. This game seriously changed me a lot, and I want to share my thoughts with the world.

Keep playing, people.


-Jayboy

40732724.review:
I finally did it... 6772 deaths later, I have completed [i]Celeste[/i]. I have decided to deviate from my standard template to give a special review on this very special game. At its essence, [i]Celeste[/i] is a [b]story-driven[/b], [b]challenging[/b] [b]puzzle platformer[/b], and I'd like to break down each element of this characterization to give a full picture of what this game is about.

[h1]Story-driven[/h1]
[i]Celeste[/i] is deep. You play as Madeline, a young girl suffering from depression as she struggles to find her life's purpose. Temporarily leaving her fears and worries behind, Madeline sets out to climb Celeste Mountain, as she feels that reaching the summit will provide her a sense of accomplishment and direction. However, unbeknownst to Madeline, Celeste has the power to reveal people's true natures, and Madeline will have to confront and conquer her inner demons to reach the top.

What makes [i]Celeste[/i] so brilliant is the analogy it draws between Madeline and the player, both of which have embarked on a journey in which their spirit and perserverance will be put into question. But more on that in the next section.

[h1]Challenging[/h1]
You should probably know that [i]Celeste[/i] is a difficult game. Fitting well with its story and theme, your skills, patience and determination will be put to the test. You will die a LOT. However, everything in [i]Celeste[/i] is completely achieveable, with quick respawns and forgiving checkpoints that encourage attempt after attempt.

The game is well tailored to fit multiple skill levels. The main game, while tough in its own right, should take the average gamer roughly 5-7 hours to complete. For those willing to challenge themselves, there are optional collectable strawberries throughout the game that require more from you to obtain. For those who want to go further, each stage has a "B-Side" that will kick your ass. And if that still wasn't enough, there's a little something extra for the most determined players. On the flip side, assist options are available to help ease the difficulty if needed, though I highly encourage playing without them.

[h1]Puzzle Platformer[/h1]
So why is this a puzzle game? [i]Celeste[/i] is more than just jumping from platform to platform; each room has been carefully crafted with a definite intended solution that, more often than not, isn't immediately obvious. Beating this game requires complete understanding of its many mechanics and how they interact with each other... and some trial and error. If you're having a hard time completing a stage, you're probably not doing the proper sequence of movements. I feel that this aspect of [i]Celeste[/i] separates it from many other platformers, leading to a wonderfully unique experience.

And for those who are interested, there is plenty of speed-running support built in. The game will keep track of your fastest time and fewest deaths for each individual stage, as well as each complete run of the game. There's also a basic in-game clock so you can keep track of your run while playing.

[h1] My Personal Opinion (Recommendation Reflects This) [/h1]
If it wasn't obvious, I can't recommend this game enough. Intense puzzle action platformer with tight controls, excellent music, and a great theme. What more could you ask for? One of the few games that is definitely worth its pricetag.

40719466.review:
Celeste is one of my favorite games, as well as one of the best games I've ever played. The story was executed well, and includes one of my favorite twists to a formula I've seen, but, despite it being a large part of why I love Celeste, I feel like I should let people experience it for themselves.

Gameplay wise, you're climbing a mountain, armed with a jump, limited wallclimb, walljump, and a dash. Some of the harder levels are comparable to a Super Meat Boy level, but none of them are required. The use of the dash and the exact movement mechanics make the game less about momentum and more about agency, which I feel reflects the story very well. It also means that certain jumps will require more control than setup, and it can require more skill than SMB at times. It plays decently fast, but not too fast for you to require special knowledge at any point, so there is no memorization. Most of the challenge comes from secret B-Side levels, so casual audiences can still play the game. Still, if it is too challenging, there is an assist mode, where you can change how you play the game to help with your problems. You can slow down the speed, give yourself extra dashes, and some other features I don't remember. 

All things considered, there isn't much of a barrier to entry in Celeste, so there is no reason to not play the main story at least once.

40717352.review:
The overwhelmingly positive reviews speak for themself, and I couldn't be happier that this game got the recognition it deserves. Celeste is an insanely fulfilling platformer. Even slight progression in Celeste feels immensely satisfying. Not once does it try to talk up how difficult it is, it instead encourages you to keep going. The entire experience feels very genuine.

It is the real deal. To any fans of Celeste, I highly recommend checking out TowerFall Ascension, another fantastic game by Matt Thorson, and in some ways a necessary predecessor to this masterpiece.

40695375.review:
First of all, a big fat warning: this is _not_ a casual 2D platformer. This is a hard "die and retry" _huge_ 2D platformer. It is tough, can be very frustrating, and you better have a very good controller/keyboard.

Getting to the top of celest mountain accounts for less than 40% of the game. You have many bonus levels to unlock, side goals (making levels way harder), secrets to discover, etc, which will take probably way more time than getting to the top and/or will be above what you are ready to commit for a game in order to reach 100% completion.

That said, this game is amazing. Everything is great and polished (nintendo grade). The pixel GFX are beautiful, I mean _really_ beautifull for pixel GFX. The music conveys the peculiar atmospheres of each level, not to mention the quality of sound effects. The background story unfolding is so good, you will get attached to the characters. The game level design is accurate, sharp, and a few/couple of times reached my personal accute sadism threshold.

Ofc, the linux based OSes port is perfect.

2D platformer of the year?

40694559.review:
Having 100% the game, I can safely say this is one of the most polished plataformers out there right now.

+ The difficulty is unforgiving right since the start, there's no handholding by the game. I died around 9500 times by the end of the game.
+ Level design is just perfect. Each room in each chapter is unique, you'll never see a room that feels similar to another. I also love how most rooms are small -- this is a pro because you'll die a LOT in some rooms, so by making each room small it makes the experience way more worthwhile than in a level like in SMB for example. You can beat a level faster, but the difficulty is scaled up a notch when you go from chapter to chapter.
+ The soundtrack is just beautiful on every level. One of the very few soundtracks I'd actually consider buying.
+ Tight controls & game mechanics. I really loved how the game handled each movement in a perfect way. The controls are just as tight as Hollow Knight's and Ori and the Blind Forest's. 
+ Pretty graphics. Pixelated graphics that just look stunning. 
+ Adding the strawberries as a side challenge was a great idea. Perfect for completionists and players looking for an extra challenge.
+ The story was alright. I grabbed this game thinking it wouldn't even have a story at all. More on this below.
~ Underwhelming ending. I won't spoil it, but it was certainly underwhelming to me. They did a great buildup of each character, but it didn't unveil correctly in the end. 
- Absolute lack of story on the extra levels (b-sides/c-sides). This killed one of my expectations when I finished all the extra levels. Those are the hardest levels in the game, one can easily make an experienced player be stuck during one or two hours throughout it, and for there not to be any story development at the end is a punch to the gut. I only saw two extra levels with some dialogue: [spoiler] b and c-side of chapter 7 [/spoiler]

Overall this is a great game. Don't get it if you get angry easily or can't tolerate dying many times. This game will test your patience and plataforming ability. Other than that I definitely recommend it for plataformer enthusiasts.

J'ai passé deux heures à y jouer. Et je continuerai. J'envisage même de le speedrun.
Ces deux heures ont été une claque vidéoludique, un jeu qui m'a procuré des sensations de gameplay comme j'ai rarement eu dans un jeu de plateforme. La prise en main est simple, intuitive. 40677570.review:
This game, man. Never before has a platformer been so emotional, yet so uplifting and rewarding.
Oh, it's hard. It's very hard. This game will test you, and you will die a lot. 
But the challenge you face mirrors what Madeline faces, as she deals not only with the mountain, but her depression, anxiety and her inner demons.

THIS is what truly makes this game special. It tackles these topics with care and finesse, and you can tell that they knew what they were talking about, probably from personal experience. The characters are flawed, but very relatable and charming, and you want to help them succeed.

Add the tight controls and lots of variety to the platforming gameplay, and you have an excellent game backed up by a great soundtrack. Everyone SHOULD play this game, even if you have to use the Assist Mode (which lets you modify the difficulty through a number of different options) to do so. It's a masterpiece.

40644844.review:
Celeste is one of those games that will keep challenging you all the way through the journey while giving a very satisfying feeling for every success.

The gameplay and controls are simple yet very fluid and it feels good to tackle the levels at every point. The levels themselves are themed around unique mechanics and include optional challenge Strawberries for those who want that tiny bit of extra challenge every here and there. For the fans there are extra stages that are way harder than anything in the main levels.
The story and overall dialogue in the game is very enjoyable and the OST is amazing across the board.

Strongly recommended for anyone who likes more challenging platformers. 
There is ALOT of content in the game if you want to do it all...
...and going through it all, will not be easy.

40641343.review:
Celeste is a beautiful platformer in which your goal is to climb a mountain. While the game itself is not easy for the casual gamer, its painstaking challenge repressents the character's internal struggle to come to peace with their inner demons. Celeste isn't a game that pokes fun at your mistakes as a player (unlike some other mountain climbing games *cough*), but rather tries to have you learn and grow from them. Although it's difficult, you'll see that it is SUPPOSED to be hard. And if the game is really too difficult for you, there is an Assit Mode to help you out.

Besides the difficulty, the game provides an interesting experience. Most of the level mechanics were fun to deal with in their own ways, although a few were annoying (mostly thinking of the wind and clouds because they were finnicky to control imo). I found myself wanting to go back and take on the previous challenges too hard for me to make before, so the replayability is definitely there. Along with the tight gameplay, the small cast of characters in Celeste gives the game more character and life overall. While the story is sort of vague, you slowly but surely can understand the plot of the game. Honestly, I wish the story had a kick of something more, but I can understand why the creators left it as is.

Overall, would I recommend Celeste to someone looking for a challenge? A new experience? A heartwarming plot full of lovable characters? Yes. Would I recommend it to casual players looking to have a stress free time? Probably not. The choice is yours.

40640325.review:
Один из лучших платформеров на моей памяти.

В кои то веки управление на клавиатуре не проебано, хотя к нему все равно придется привыкнуть, но как только вы его прочувствуете, все неудобства исчезнут. Персонаж двигается очень плавно, но не скользит, не падает там, где не надо, одним словом - полный контроль. 

Сюжет не то чтобы особенно крут, но он достаточно лампово рассказывает об упорстве, мотивации и борьбе со своими внутренними демонами. Он служит, скорее, приятным дополнением к прекрасному геймплею.

Геймплей просто шикарен, в каждой новой главе в игру вкидывается что-то новое, что подогревает интерес и не дает устать от платформинга, так же есть боссы, но они не особо впечатляют, честно говоря, это тот же платформинг, но с дополнительными помехами в виде этих самых боссов, хотя тут ничего иного и не надо по сути.

Музыка шикарна, ничего больше не скажу, просто шикарна.

Сложность для моих стандартов была на 1.5~2/10, стороны Б посложнее, примерно на 3/10, я слишком много играл в нидлы, чтобы меня таким забороть, а вот обычному игроку будет местами тяжело, но игра не слишком давит сложностью, ее цель не в этом, так что бояться не стоит.

В целом я прошел ее примерно за 6 часов, я не пытался собрать все ягоды и открыть все секреты, оставил на потом, все остальное время - попытки в спидран. Эта игра идеальна для спидрана, если вы такое любите, в ней есть шикарный таймер, так что тратить лишнее время с лайвсплитами всякими не придется. Ну и не могу не похвастаться, пока что мой ПБ - 59:10, хотя я мог и лучше, но это потом.

Как итог, один из лучших платформеров, что я видел, не знаю к чему прикопаться, так что 10/10

40639359.review: Best platformer i've played in years

40638453.review:
I really wish there was a "mixed" review voting option.

The good : the soundtrack and the graphics are amazing. The controls are smooth, especially considering the machine i'm running on. The story was good for this kind of game.

The eh : it doesn't...bring that much new to the table? It's a nitpick really, because while mechanically all that Celeste does has been done before, Celeste brings together for a really good platforming experience.

The ugly :
- The ledge dropping is wonky. like, really wonky, counterintuitive. This might be a personal nitpick but ledgedropping was always a matter of chance for me, never managed to get it precisely. Maybe i'm not good enough, but such a simple mechanic shouldn't require skill.
- The level design truly fails on one big point : viewing the whole level when it's too big. Now, this isn't often a problem in other platformers, but this one knows it can be one and gives you the option to look ahead with some "fixed binocular" thingies to spot traps or think on complicated areas before attempting them. The problem is that those binoculars are poorly placed, very often there in long but intuitive, trapless levels, and absent in complicated, full of choke point ones. Knowing that the mechanic could be there but isn't is even more infuriating that not having ever had the "look ahead" possibility.
- The overarching, zone design, fails on another big point, and all because of one thing : there are one way ledges that stop you from going backwards in a zone. This is a problem with exploring : you often will explore, take one path that stops you from seeing what is in the other path. The only way to get to explore those paths at that point is to... restart the zone. Missing secrets because you chose the "no going back" path is infuriating.

All in all, i'll still recommend this game, but if the points above sound like they'll infuriate you more than me, i wouldn't recommend it at full price. I still think the overall quality of the game offsets those snags.

40632241.review: Masterpiece. Feels like a brand new Snes game for 2018!

40632016.review:
[h1] Celeste, il gioco che tocca il cuore.	[/h1]

Preso a prezzo pieno pochi giorni dopo il suo day-1, [i] Celeste	[/i] è probabilmente uno degli indie più belli a cui ho giocato negli ultimi anni, nonchè uno dei platform oggettivamente più curati e strutturati di sempre. Il gioco di per se è estremamente semplice nelle meccaniche (ed è chiaramente ispirato al sempreverde Super Meat Boy nel sistema di movimento-controllo), e su questo non ci piove: strutturalmente parlando infatti il gioco è estremamente semplice come controlli e come gameplay, e oltre al classico tasto per saltare e per sprintare, con la pressione del trigger sinistro, potremo anche aggrapparci alle parete e scalarle (ma non potremo scalare le pareti all'infinito, a meno che non rimaniamo fermi immobili). La progressione diverrà, livello dopo livello, sempre più difficile, con schemi sempre più complicati, ma mai troppo frustranti: la difficoltà è sicuramente tarata verso l'alto, ma non è frustrante, e tende ad accompagnare il giocatore così da aiutarlo a prender mano con il mondo di gioco; il trial and error è alla base di [i] Celeste	[/i], quindi aspettatevi di morire tante, tantissime volte (anche più di un migliaio), ma non sarà mai eccessivamente pesante, e vi invoglierà a migliorare le vostra abilità e a correggere, salto dopo salto, ogni minimo errore. 
E fin qui tutto  ok, descritto così questo gioco sembrerebbe un platform di qualità "standard", niente di così eccezionale, direte voi. Ed in parte è vero, ma questo gioco in realtà ha dalla sua una delle art direction migliori che io abbia mai visto in un gioco di questo calibro. 
Madeline, la nostra protagonista, dovrà scalare una vetta per molti insormontabile, il monte Celeste, attraverso un lungo percorso che la porterà a conoscere nuove persone...E sopratutto, se stessa: la montagna infatti ha il "potere" di rivelare il vero te stesso, portando quindi la nostra eroina a compiere un viaggio ancora più difficile per riuscire ad uscire dall'oscurità (oscurità rappresentata da una malattia, ma non andrò oltre..). La narrazione va a pari passo con gli umori di Madeline, con momenti spensierati raccontati con una dolcezza e una famigliarità unici e momenti drammatici e cupi, volti a rappresentare le sofferenze della protagonista. La soundtrack poi è perfetta, ogni traccia è perfettamente adatta ad ogni contesto e livello. Graficamente poi la pixel art è bellissima, mentre le tavole che rappresentano i personaggi sono molto simili ai volti disegnati dal famoso Bryan Lee O'Malley, celebre fumettista americano autore di Scott Pilgrim vs The World. 
Una vera e propria perla che va assolutamente vissuta, che saprà unire chi cerca un gioco dallo storytelling profondo e chi cerca una sfida appagante ed impegnativa (grazie anche ai livelli bonus e ai numerosi collezionabili presenti nel titolo). Imperdibile!

40630019.review:
I never thought I'd play another platformer that was as amazing and charming with a brilliant soundtrack as Super Meat Boy but here we are, with Celeste, a very well made platformer, one of the best actually, that offers incredibly challenging but not impossible platforming with a interesting story of conquering the issues of ones self. 

The gameplay consists of challenging platforming through different levels, each offering unique twists and harder gameplay as you progress through the story and game. Its similar to SMB and other platfomers where you can grab ledges, double and even triple jump, filled with hidden secrets and collectibles for you to find that unlock additional challenges called B-Sides. Also you'll need to find at least 4 hearts to be able to progress to the final chapter which is insane in difficulty though not really necesary since the story ends before it. 

The story is basically conquering your fears and emotions in the face of challenge, which in this case is climbing the mountain and facing different challenges. There is some mystery throught the game though its clear from the start where this was going. Dont expect some amazing detailed written plot, its not about that. 

Atmosphere, though pixelated which I would've preffered a more modern take, is still pretty good to look at. There are some really nice places you'll go through, from a Hotel to a mysterios temple, and some other not so good looking environments but decent overall. 

The soundtrack is one of the best parts of the game and if you loved Super Meat Boy's style of soundtrack, then this is similar to it. You'll need to listen to it to understand/experience how it fits so well with the game. it truly adds to the quality of the game.

Overall its a near perfect platformer, a game I would recommend regardless of price and a contender for 2018's GOTY awards. 9/10.

40623143.review:
This game is nothing short of a masterpiece.

The visual style is beautiful, retro enough to be nostalgic but highly artistic.

The controls are tight and reward precision, without feeling oppressive like many platformers do.  There aren't any cheap tricks or stupid death traps like many retro platformers.  The game gently introduces new mechanics and teaches you how to do things with them you'd never imagine.

The music is my favorite part.  It slowly evolves as you progress from screen to screen, rewarding you for advancement.

As jaded as I am to new games, this one has won a special place in my heart.

As a gamer who has spent too much money on crap I can never refund, please buy this game.  The developers deserve your money.

40619001.review:
It's rare that I am compelled to write a review (it's free labor for Steam, who doesn't need it), but I'm recommending Celeste for a particular reason beyond it being a beautifully envisioned, wildly expansive joy to play:

Despite being incredibly punishing, Celeste respects your time. I find myself contrasting it to the last platformer I really loved, Super Meat Boy. SMB's most vicious levels tended to be on the longer side, with vicious traps and pitfalls building towards the end. The result was spending a great deal of time jumping through the same hoops of the earlier parts of levels again and again just to take a crack at the final obstacles. Celeste, by contrast, has frequent checkpointing between discrete rooms, and these rooms tend to be more front-loaded in terms of difficulty (though make no mistake, they can become very difficult). 

This is an exceptional design decision and one I can't praise enough. I love a good challenge but too many games, despite having mechanics I enjoy, confuse "challenge" with "the threat of sending you all the way back" (I'm looking at you, Souls series). Celeste avoids this trap with tight, thoughtful design. It's extremely refreshing to be able to take on an intentionally difficult game [spoiler](especially on the B-sides)[/spoiler] without feeling like I'm giving away an increasingly busy life to do so.

Celeste est un superbe jeu. 

Graphiquement, c'est un pixel art qui fait très bien le job et crée des atmosphères variées, avec des animations réussies. La musique est superbe et va sûrement rejoindre les OST qui rythment mes heures de bureau, et en terme d'ambiance sonore, les effets qui font office de "voix" pour les dialogues rendent très bien (en particulier l'intonation désabusée). :D

40570559.review:
Everything about this game is fantastic, with the expertly crafted gameplay and level design. The platforming is stellar and simple yet difficult, while there are tons of extra challenges I've yet to do. You really care about the characters and their journey throughout, and the theme (which I wont spoil here) is done perfectly. The beautiful artwork and wonderful soundtrack keep you going despite your failures and as such fits great with the theme. 
Highly Recommend to anyone who likes challenging platformers.

As I play (and now after finishing the story), I must say: The story really struck a chord with me and left me really caring about the characters and Madeline's journey, the dialog is also convincing and inspiring. Even after the story there is so much wonderful content in the form of collectibles and bonus levels.

Anyways, after simmering down from all this enjoyment. A word on the extra content: Its fantastic but not for everyone. The strawberries are wonderful challenges that I highly suggest going after. But the B-Sides, while some of them are good, seem to fall away from the design of the game where problems could be solved more than one way and it was more about your moveset. In Chapters 4 and 6 B-Sides, the challenge is based almost entirely upon your reaction times rather than figuring out the solution, a much different experience than the rest of the game.

40569842.review:
While I do believe this game is a bit overrated, I did enjoy it for the most part and completed it 100%  The A-sides are where the heart of the game is, and where I had the most fun.  Not only because it was less difficult, but it was far more cohesive and didn't feel like a chore to get beyond every section.  Not to mention, I felt that the A-sides built off of each other, whereas the B-sides felt more like trial and error toward the later parts, and the C-sides were just hell on Earth. 

Being the completionist I am, I felt myself getting frustrated at times due to a "what the hell do they want me to do exactly" mechanic, but once I figured it out, it became progressively easier.  Like on Chapter 5, where you are carrying Theo on the B-sides, I didn't know you could wall jump while holding the crystal above your head, so I died countless times in frustration before I finally realized this was possible. (It is very counterintuitive).  Overall, I would recommend the game if you like challenging platformers, but there is some wonky directional controls at times when exiting bubbles and air-jetting, where you swore that you were holding that directional button, just to find that it propelled you in a direction unintended.

Overall, I'll give the game an 8.3/10, not my favorite platformer of all time, but it did have an enchanting story and certainly scratched an itch for a difficult platformer.  Just beware, this game is tough as nails, and sometimes, knowing what to do and actually executing it are two different things, and this is most prevalent in this game.  I purchased at full price, and feel that it was moderately worth it, although I feel that the game is more of a $15 dollar game than a $20.  Good day, and good luck if you decide to play this.

40551301.review:
[h1]O Jogo[/h1]

A palavra que melhor define Celeste como um todo é superação, seja em seus medos, em sua constante evolução de gameplay ou em sua evolução narrativa sútil, porém muito profunda. Tudo é muito bem equilibrado, chegando ao ponto do apego emocional por personagens que acabaram de aparecer ser comum, todos tem uma personalidade muito marcante e distinta uma da outra, causando curiosidade no jogador sobre o que aconteceu com aquele personagem e os motivos dele estar ali.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

Celeste possuí o sistema simples de saltos, wall ride, wall climb, stamina e air dash (o air dash é renovado toda vez que Madeline chega ao chão) [spoiler]no futuro o jogo possui um sistema de air dash duplo que muda a gameplay completamente [/spoiler]. Os cenários complementam a gameplay de forma magestral com elementos que diferenciam cada mundo, usar o empuxo das plataformas pra ser arremessado mais longe, joias que te dão um dash extra no ar, bolhas que te levam pelo cenário ou te arremessam a uma curta distância, todas essas coisas complementam e deixam as fases épicas que funcionais de forma totalmente orgânica e natural.

[b]Enredo:[/b] 9/10
[b]Trilha sonora:[/b] 10/10
[b]Gameplay:[/b] 10/10
[b]Gráficos:[/b] 10/10

obs: não julgo apenas gráficos, julgo a arte como um todo

40548082.review:
I find most of the complaints about this game are from people who probably don't want to be good at most games they play. I'm one of thsoe people that likes to dive into games in depth, and Celeste gives you a lot of depth. The main story line is about 8 hours worth of gameplay, but the extra levels and collectibles will take a lot of your time. Some unlockables give harder levels which in turn give you something to show off to your friends.

The graphics style fits in with the gameplay pretty well. I don't think I ever saw an asset in the game and said to myself "Well, that doesn't fit here." The developers actually make the pixel style look better by adding neat weather effects or coloring. There's also various mechanics that shine on their own and even similar mechanics feel unique in their own right.

If I had to say something negative about this game, it would be that I don't have notches on my controller, so it was annoying when I would dash in a cardinal direction instead of diagonally. That was more my fault than anything, and when I used the d-pad, I would nail it every time. Just need to pay more attention to where my stick is when I'm dashing.

Anyway, great game. Might be the first game I try speed running once I finally finish it. Stil gotta finish the epilogue and the C-sides.

40526315.review:
When it comes to platformers in general. There usually isn't a lot to comment about except for the level design and in some cases its soundtrack. Celeste brings in a new element to the genre by adding a rather emotional and compelling storyline centered of-course around the main character and protaganist Madeline.

The story is not for everyone, as is with all games. But even if you are not the kind of person to play a game for its story, Celeste presents, what is in my opinion, *the* best platformer experience available on the market right now. There are the main storyline levels which also contains a handful of secrets as well as present some level of challenge to the experienced platformed. Then there are the B-Side levels, these levels are unlockable ones that present a very much harder version of the storyline levels and an incredibly fine-tuned level design and a revamped soundtrack fitting for the current progress along the main storyline.

The soundtrack overall is absolutely glorious to say the least, subjectively speaking one of my favorite ones out there. Of-course it's not a full on Dark Souls orchestra, but that would not fine this game regardless.

As for the storyline, I would never have expected this kind of emotional attachment to a character in a pixelated platformer such as Celeste and in my opinion, even disregarding the absolutely amazing level design. The story and character development would be enough for me to recommend this game to anyone.

In conclusion, as we don't disregard that level design; this game is an absolutely well-polished masterpiece. If you're reading reviews right now to decide whether or not you want to purchase the game and you happen to come across my review I have but a simple few words for you: Buy this game, it's worth twice what they're asking for.

10/10

40509874.review:
42시간만에 드디어 끝을 보는구나. 비록 황금딸기 몇개는 내 능력의 한계점을 뛰어넘어야 되는
극악의 수집품이라 얻지 못했지만 거기까지란게 어떤가, 게임을 시작하기 전부터
돌아보며 생각해보면 정말 잘 즐겼다. 짜임새가 있고 아름다운 외형을 했지만 끔찍한
죽음의 고통을 여러번 맛보아야 했던 고난이도 수준의 레벨디자인은 점점 흉포해지고
그 광기를 뽐내왔지만 더더욱 큰 도전을 바라는 나를 자극하기에는 충분했다.
처음에는 쥐새끼정도의 수준이 되는 데에도 불구하고 쩔쩔 맸지만 도전심이라는 욕구
하나때문에 포기하지않고 힘들면 중간에 쉬어서라도 열심히 오르고 달렸다.
여러번 떨어지고 찔리고 낑겨서 죽어 밀려오는 좌절감에 컨트롤러는 땀에 젖고 입술이 말라갔다. 
그러다 등반에 성공했을 때의 그 짜릿함이란, 해냈다는 사실에 기쁨을 감출 수 없었지만 
다음 코스가 남았다. 이 과정을 여러번 반복하며 희노애락을 겪다 드디어 마지막 등반에 성공했다. 
이 이상 갈 곳은 없다. 단지 만족하지 못한 이들을 위한 황금 딸기만 준비되어있을뿐.
정말 더럽고 좆같고 손아팠지만 재미있었다. 그리고 앞으로 이 게임을 할 사람들에게 전할게 있다.
[spoiler]어시스트모드는 젖도 못 뗀 애새끼나 쓰는거다 손대지마라.[/spoiler]

40495555.review:
Celeste is a game about climbing a mountain. However, instead of just being a linear Meat Boy-esque platformer, it becomes a game of commentary, about the mental health issues many people face. The story manages to intertwine itself in the gameplay so that the message it tells and the feats you accomplish (with or without Assist mode) go hand in hand, and that's a good thing. It makes the player feel good; it made [i]me[/i] feel good. And it's definitely difficult for me to feel good, especially after dealing with 5 years of depression. The main character almost perfectly matched the feelings I have, self worth and all, so climbing this mere mountain wasn't just a game to pass the time, it was an experience, and a lesson that I can take home and learn from, even if I am still having trouble taking the first step of making myself better.

Even if you aren't a fan of hard/Super Meat Boy-esque platformers, I still believe you should try the game out for an hour or two.

40483714.review:
I love everything about this game. The mechanics were not only brilliant, but unlike other games I never felt like I was wrestling with  the game's mechanics or UI, it all felt so smooth and polished, and even though rage games aren't anything new, this game was made to perfection. There was rarely anything or any time I felt “oh I can't do such and such because of stupid game”. In a nutshell, you get a jump, a dash, the ability to climb walls and various things like falling blocks and springs, and all of it feels amazing to use.

As well as this, other aspects like art, story and music are good as well. The well-told story, although a sad one, was also a hopefully one, and I loved all the characters to an incredible degree. The music was also really good but also fitting. Things like how the B&C side themes seem to understand that I am failing a lot and don't annoy me almost ever. My favourite tracks were Golden Ridge B Golden Feather Mix and Summit A “Reach for the Summit”. The art is very pretty and although there is a mixture of like three different art styles they never seemed to fight with each other and they flowed very well. Everything just looks so smooth, especially the main character's movements.

The main thing this game did well though was how it made things that should annoy the hell out of me extremely fun. The main culprits for this are level design, art and music. Even though its genre is “rage game” I did anything but rage when playing. (except for one stupid part in Summit B). For almost all of it, no matter how many times I tried a level I would still be enjoying myself, and when I finally beat it I wouldn't think “finally got that shit over with” but more “damn that was fun, let's do it again!”.  On the same note, Some aspects of this game, namely wind levels, I just avoid and hate. When I first did Golden Ridge I thought “gddmt there's a wind level..” but then 10 seconds later I was already enjoying it.

So in a sentence, Celeste is like other games of its genre, but better, and with an incredible amount of polish.

P.S. There are, as we all know, two painfully awful parts of Celeste. The bit in Summit B where you have to use the cloud to jump through the spikes then dash the other way and back again, but mostly the bit where the game ends. Celeste handles this bit very well, considering its high replayability and the fact that it took me 26hrs to complete the main game, but it's still annoying.

So my suggestion is having a level editor like Geometry Dash where people can make their own levels then post them up online for other people to play. Hopefully some people would make some very cool levels for others to have fun with. Celeste is already absolute 10/10, but if you make this a feature I will love you forever, and on the same scale it will be at least  15 (as long as it doesn't just fill with mario maker esque bullshit which hopefully it won't).

40482062.review:
Let me start by saying I think the first part of the game is great and well done. The challenges are fun and mostly fair and there's a good sense of satisfaction when you first get through there.

I think the game has some large problems later in the so called B-sides (the harder versions of the levels) that you can unlock.

The main thing is that skill becomes secondary to actually getting through a level. What I mean with skill is as set of inputs you can learn to do and pull off consistently. Stuff that may be hard at the start, but once you get used to it you get better and you can use that learned behaviour to get through levels more easily and consistently.
Now the problem is that the levels demand such high levels of precision I don't think any human can pull that off consistently based on learning to do the inputs precisely enough. Stuff like 2-5 pixels worth or error margin when jumping/landing. Timings that are within 2-5 frames (assuming 60 fps). This is simply not stuff you can learn to do.

So the only way to get through a levels is by repetition, because at some point you'll have the muscle memory built up and you know ahead what is coming and then sooner or later you get lucky enough that you get through. And while you DO need a certain minimum level of skill, it's mostly just muscle memory and luck at that point. This is also obvious by the fact that once you DO get through a section the next section is not gonna be easier (because you didn't learn anything or got any better in any significant way)

The difference is also one in how you feel when you get through a section. Half the time it's "ugh, thank god I don't have to do THIS again". Whereas if you feel you mastered a new set of movement skills it feels great and like an accomplishment.

Now that's NOT to say the whole B-Sides are like that, it's about half and half when it comes to skill based challenges vs repetition/muscle memory based challenges. So overall you can still enjoy it, jsut expect there to be really annoying frustrating parts regularly as well.

Also the IDEAS of the challenges are often great. Because part of getting through a level is also figuring out what you need to do, which is cool. It's just that the demanded execution is just a bit too tight to be enjoyable (or fair for that matter, unless you aim at making a game for robots who CAN input frame exact button presses).

There's also the occasional "gotcha" parts, where you just run into things you can't foresee or react to, which is also very frustrating, especially after doing an already difficult section, getting through it for the first time only to find yourself dying to something you can't possibly react to.

Now death isn't that harsh here, since your estart at the same screen, but trust me after doing the same 10 second section 30 times it will still get annoying to die to stuff that isn't really your fault.

But anyway, I'd still say the A sides are awesome and well worth playing. B-Sides, might still be fun, if you enjoy that kinda stuff, I just figured I give a fair warning for people who like to complete everything (Oh and there's C-sides too, good luck with that lol)

40472479.review:
-This review is spoiler-free- 

TL;DR --> Buy this game if you like platformers and story. 

Dear potential game-buyer.

On a first note a have to admit that i never write reviews about my bought games since I normally don't bother with the hassle. But this game is special.

As a big fan of pixelesque 2d platformers and rogue-lite dungeonexplorers this game fit my taste pretty well to begin with. that is what piqued my interest to buy it in the first place. 

While playing it though, I was pleasantly surprised about the quality of this story. the game introduces several characters and these characters really start to get to you personally. Some aspects of this game actually hit close to home for me as it actually made me emotional at times. when you feel that a story is important for you to enjoy a  game, then by all means, give this game a shot.

The gameplay is great. When I say that I died 1,700-ish times before completing the story you might not think this game is very inviting. (mind you, i have to rerun several levels being the completionist that I am) But, the continuïty of this game really "eases" the pain and annoyance of dying. You respawn fast, there are a lot of checkpoints, there is no unneccisary gore involved(not that i don't like gore) and the background music keeps playing. All this, makes dying not so much of a hassle. you just try again, and again. until you get it right. And boy, when you do get it right it is so very fulfilling.

The controls can be a little confusing at first, but 10 minutes into the game you should be getting used to it. I read another review recommending a controller. I have to say that this game is perfectly playable with a keyboard, and my recommended settings are:
W-up
A-left
S-down
D-right

J-jump
K-Dash
L-Hold (for climbing)

basicly these are the same controls the game has as standard, but then swapped around so that your left hand controls the directional movement instead of the right hand. 

Special shoutout for the background music and soundeffects. Damn. 
The great soundtracks really help make this game so much more immersive.

40449804.review:
This game. Oh BOY, this game. Maybe the best game I've ever played in my life. See other reviews for why I love it so much, because I share the same reasons they have.

Anyways, I hold this game near and dear to my heart because of the core themes of the story. I can relate pretty heavily to Madeline's struggles, as I suffer the same problems. After completing this game all the way through to the end, the thought struck me: what if I've been doing it wrong my whole life? What if my anxiety wasn't something I had to get rid of, but something I had to harness for myself? And then BOOM, this game turned from a super enjoyable platformer to a god damn therapy session! It blew my mind when I realized that a game could teach me a valuable life lesson through its story.

Please, if you have some kind of mental health problems, get this game RIGHT NOW

...no, I didn't insult you by saying that you need to be stupid to get this game. I'm not THAT mean.

40432175.review: Pro platformers and speed runners only, not for casual gamers. Soundtrack is pretty nice good job there. Mediocre pixel art not good but also not terrible. Controls are very tight like a lot of others have said, this game demands perfection pretty early on. I made the poor decision of choosing this game to get back into platformers, it's not friendly to new platformers. All that being said it will be the hot thing for speed runners for a little bit til something new is out, so if you're a speed runner or enjoy really intense demanding platforming go for it, if you enjoy casual gaming experience I say move along.

40430688.review:
This game is everything I could ever hope for in game of its type.

Level design is perfect. Not only does every level add several new interesting mechanics that keep it fresh, but they dramatically change the pace as you move from one section to another. There's slow puzzle sections, fast action sections, precision jumping sections, timing sections, and combinations thereof.

Your character controls very well and her moves are incorporated well into all levels. Music and visuals are great, longevity is pretty great. There's secrets all over (including harder "B Side" versions of each level, and supposedly C Sides I haven't even gotten to yet) and while many are very hard to find they mostly feel fair. The story is compelling, and is tied in nicely to gameplay mechanics.

Overall I can't recommend this highly enough to platformer lovers.

40425117.review:
Bought for the hard platforming - loved for the story.
The story really resonated with me and is definitely the strongest point of the game for me.

And the platforming and level design is just perfect. I love the snappiness of the core mechanics and the levels are just right in difficulty and choice. With the way the levels are designed around additional challenge through optional collectibles, the game actually adapts to your capabilities and endurance.

I definitely recommend this game even at the full price of 20€ currently. Even after the 5.5h it took me to play through initally, I feel like I got the money's worth already. And I will very likely revisit the levels to collect more stuff and maybe play the unlockable levels soon.

40413339.review:
[i]Если друг оказался вдруг и не друг, и не враг, а – так. Если сразу не разберешь, плох он или хорош. Парня в горы тяни - рискни! Не бросай одного его, пусть он в связке в одной с тобой - там поймешь, кто такой![/i]

Ну, как там дальше поется вы знаете. Но одно дело – судить характер постороннего человека по его скалолазным способностям. Другое – идти вверх по склону в связке с самим собой.   

С точки зрения искусства, гора – это не топографический элемент местности. Это аллегория человеческих подвигов и треволнений. Никто не взбирается на вершину просто так. Это враг, которого надо победить. Преодолимое препятствие. Достижимая мечта. Поиск неуловимого и желанного просветления. Горы показывают, меняют, открывают. Это универсальный инструмент для любой неисправности или засора мозгов.

Вот и Мэделин тоже позарез надо забраться на вершину. Это больно, опасно. Так зачем? Для чего она это делает? Не спрашивайте, черт возьми! Откуда ей знать? Чтобы дойти куда-то. Закончить что-то. Ощутить себя важной, достойной, целой. Чтобы сузить мучительно беспредметное существование до одной конкретной, осязаемой цели. И выжечь из сознания всё остальное. 

Наконец, просто потому что она может. Ведь если ты можешь забраться так высоко и увидеть красоту, которую мало кто видел, то почему этого не сделать? Точно так же, если ты можешь пройти игру до конца, истирая в кровь пальцы, и собрать все её награды, почему в самом деле не пройти? 

“Селеста” – это так называемый хардкорный платформер. Из тех, когда ты переходишь на следующий экран, медленно понимаешь, чего игра от тебя хочет, секунду сидишь в гробовой тишине, а потом начинаешь бессильно плакать. А минут через 10 ты этот экран проходишь.

Выверенный садистский дизайн уровней – это поэзия, говорящая на языке блоков, шипов и бездонных пропастей. Жестокий, но честный игровой процесс – это музыка прыжков, рывков и кульбитов. Ритм щелкающих стиков и вдавливаемых кнопок. Благозвучный треск истязаемого геймпада. 

Красота удачного циркового номера так сладка благодаря позору загубленных попыток. Парить от экрана к экрану, как перо на ветру, так же здорово, как камнем падать в яму при очередной неудаче. 

Но на краю сознания всегда остается этот назойливый вопрос. Зачем? 
И тут у "Селесты" появляется шанс блеснуть своим сюжетом. Историей о лукавой, норовистой горе, обожащей играть колдовские шутки со своими незваными гостями. Такую гору с нахрапа не укротишь, не объездишь. И чем выше ты поднимаешься, тем глубже она зарывается тебе в голову.
 
Даже самому интенсивному и отточенному платформеру идет на благо сильный, смелый, уверенный сюжет. С персонажами, хватающими душу за грудки. С мощным конфликтом, внешним и внутренним. Сюжет, способный провести жирную красную линию через всю игру и сказать: “Вот где ты сейчас. А вон где ты должен быть!” Сюжет, который объяснит, оправдает и придаст благородный смысл твоему нечеловеческому упрямству. Башковитое сценарное “зачем” для инстинктивного игрового “как”. 

Интересный момент: наша Мэделин выглядит и ведет себя, как маленькая девочка. Обычная канадская школьница, самое большее лет пятнадцати. Однако, на деле она гораздо старше. Хоть игра данный факт не выпячивает, она его и не скрывает. По словам разработчиков ей вообще хорошо за 20, а то и за 25. Почему же так? Чтобы благодарные игроки рисовали умильный фан-арт в анимэ-стиле? Или потому что реальный возраст и психологический – это две большие разницы. И проблемы могут превратить любого из нас в свирепого, брыкающегося, обиженного на весь мир карапуза. 

С игровой точки зрения Мэделин – богиня альпинизма, совершающая один акробатический подвиг за другим. По контрасту, Мэделин сюжетная – не спортсменка ни в каком смысле слова. Тем не менее, она тащит на спине огромный рюкзак, который в пиксельной перспективе становится чуть ли не с неё размером. Это нехитрое, но эффективное воплощение страхов, проблем, ошибок - того багажа, который она несет с собой к вершине. И который отчаянно тянет её вниз, истощая силы, которых и так-то было немного.

Еще один поэт написал: “Черный человек! Ты прескверный гость. Эта слава давно про тебя разносится. Я взбешен, разъярен, и летит моя трость прямо к морде его, в переносицу... Месяц умер, синеет в окошко рассвет. Ах ты, ночь! Что ты, ночь, наковеркала? Я в цилиндре стою. Никого со мной нет. Я один... И разбитое зеркало...”

Люди не знают теневой стороны вещей, а именно там, в глубине таится то, что придает остроту нашим чувствам. Чтобы забраться на гору перед собой, нужно преодолеть такую же у себя внутри. А чтобы победить себя, не надо спасаться, прятаться или драться. Надо бежать не прочь и не вверх. А навстречу, в самое сердце тьмы. 

В этом сражении Мэделин не может проиграть или выиграть. Она должна лишь пойти против всего, что двигает её вперед и дает силы. Соединить две половинки своей души. Познать собственное “я”. И стать человеком, над которым не властны внешние силы. Который распоряжается своей душой, а потому тратит жизнь только ради жизни и никогда — ради разрушения, боли и ненависти.

С игроков спрос, конечно же, не так строг. Мэделин отвечает за смыслы. Мы должны только пройти игру. И игра признает, что каждый из нас борется по мере своих способностей. Она предлагает широчайшие возможности по упрощению и облегчению прохождения. Чтобы даже четырех- и девяносточетырехлетние геймеры смогли приобщиться к её рассказу. Заслуживают ли игроки, пользующиеся допингом, пусть и санкционированным, своих звездочек, сердечек, клубничек и достижений – это тема для отдельной диссертации. Сейчас важно знать, что на вершину Селесты может забраться каждый, выбрав для себя маршрут соответствующей сложности. 

Селеста – это место удивительной красоты. А её пиксель-арт – полноценная форма художественного авангарда. Использованный с умом и по назначению, он всегда изображает и отмечает то, что по-настоящему важно. Создает атмосферу несколькими мазками. Выделяет героиню ярким пятном, как красный буек посреди синего моря. Ничего лишнего! Как и положено для суровой игры, не прощающей ошибок и заминок. Тем не менее, ни о каком аскетизме речи не идет. Горный рассвет ошарашивает своими красками. Магические факелы в древнем храме создают атмосферу замогильной чертовщины. А ночной пейзаж пробирает холодом до костей.
Дополняют картину рисованные от руки вставки и полные жизни анимированные портреты. Они добавляют персонажам выразительности и передают нюансы сложных эмоций. 

Честное слово, в этой игре меня умиляет даже меню. Не помню, когда я последний раз обращал отдельное внимание на меню. Тем более, столь простое и ненавязчивое. Может, дело в симпатичных иконках, отмечающих успехи каждого уровня. Или в потрясающей электронной музыке. Или в том, как мой прогресс аккуратно прослеживается на трехмерной модели горы, по которой медленно, но верно поднимается к вершине героиня.

“Селеста” - это красивая, сложная, отлаженная игра. С замечательно мудрым сюжетом о том, что горящая свеча порождает тени. Что крылатая клубника стоит того, чтобы за нею гнаться. Что понять вещь или человека гораздо важнее, чем узнать, какая от них может быть польза. 
Есть ли польза от бестолковой Мэделин? Есть ли толк от наших игровых потуг? Или от этой самой горы с её семью сотнями испытаний? Заберитесь на вершину и сами узнаете.

40399747.review:
Una mezcla de Super Meat Boy (timing, precisión y dificultad) junto con I wanna be the Guy (doble salto, muertes erróneas y dificultad).

Celeste, un juego con una dificultad retadora, con ganas de saber más a fondo de la historia, coloridos escenarios, un soundtrack púlido, pixel art muy trabajado y personajes memorables, hace de este título una compra asegurada, tomando en cuenta como lo mencioné arriba, un juego con mucho desafío al morir, pero que irás aprendiendo poco a poco de los obstáculos.

*Pros*
- Dificultad alta (tipo SMB o IWBTG)
- Soundtrack variado
- Personajes memorables
- Secretos y rejugabilidad
- Niveles extras (aún más complicado que la historia)
- Pixel art y efectos muy buenos
- Escenarios y mecánismos variados

*Cons*
- Si eres una persona poco paciente no es para ti

40394728.review:
[b]PLEASE NOTE I'M ONLY AROUND 3 HOURS IN AS OF WRITING THIS REVIEW AND HAVE JUST FINISHED THE HOTEL LEVEL[/b]

If you like challenging platformers at all, you are doing yourself a disservice by not getting this. This is a game where an 8-bit minigame of the main game is just as difficult and absorbing as the main game and can easily sidetrack you - not to do the main game a disservice at all. The gameplay is designed around one core concept - the dash that can be used once before having to touch the ground before using it again. This concept is built around as the game progresses, and more objects in the levels are introduced, but the movement roster always stays the same (as far as I've played).

I haven't got far enough in for the story to really throw me loads of curveballs (just finished the hotel) but the hotel level and the guy who runs it actually made me feel an emotion, which is very rare for a platformer. The themes in this game are pretty obvious from the get go, and if you didn't figure out the symbolism of the 'dark' version of the main character being her inner doubts and negative temptations early on, I don't know what to tell you, but the story is still well told - especially for a platformer, let me re-emphasise.

Highly recommended and a fairly obvious candidate for GOTY early on.

40383677.review:
This is the 2d platforming equivalent of Concjump/Rocketjump maps. Which is to say, it's a game about controlling the momentum and angle of your jumps, dashes, midair flight, and so forth--with a lovely bit of climbing and pretty-consistently tight physics puzzles for good measure. The best part is that it manages difficulty by allowing you to perform optional side courses, reminiscent some of the puzzles in Super Metroid or Metroid Fusion.

Basically, if you're the type who liked collecting every last missile tank, doing all the weird dash stunts and sequence-breaking tricks and stuff, you're going to like this game a lot more.

Each stage sort of has its own unique mechanics to teach, as well as an optional, hidden unlockable 'B-side', which revisits the story stages with a much harder set of courses. Did I mention there's a story? Including classic Prince of Persia-esque bits with your reflection coming out of a mirror and trying to fuck around with your life and shit?

One brief quibble I do have, is that, for the challenge of the content, it's not very good at pacing itself, and the levels are all quite drawn out. It can also be easy to miss all of the optional challenges in any given map, as there are multiple hidden rooms in each level. Make sure you have more than a little time on your hands for all the precision platforming, as some of the later stages get... rather merciless.

In retrospect, the Mountain Climbing theme was aptly chosen, as Celeste can be quite tiring, at times. I do wish there was a little more story and exploration, to soften up some of Celeste's puzzling sequences. There's a reason, in retrospect, that games like Super Metroid were one part exploration, one part side-scrolling shooter, one part extreme wall-jumping platform puzzler, and it's that the puzzle segments on their own can get quite fatiguing stringed back to back to back, like Celeste's are. Moreover, unlike titles like Super Metroid, Celeste's Strawberry optional rewards don't really contribute to the gameplay experience in any way, so even succeeding at puzzles, at times, can feel like getting busy work out of the way, and the temptation to opt out of them grows greater as the puzzles' difficulty increase without any clear reward aside from collecting what are the fruit equivalent of Mario 64 stars.

Basically, it's Super Metroid's dash boot segments meets Prince of Persia's navigating with switches and spikes, and running from evil things trying to catch up with you, and the air-control of a TFC or TF2 jumpmap, except in 2d. Hectic with moments of story progression, and lots of crashing into spikes and retrying. Yeah. That about sums things up.

[The infuriating and unfun 3-B is the only exception so far.] Great soundtrack. I found the story surprisingly moving and thought the hi-res faces during conversations were particularly effective at conveying emotion. Such a simple, cohesive and beautiful game.
