39982961.review:
Platformers are rarely this pure. Celeste doesn't indulge in an abundance of mechanics, instead opting to perfect something much more simplistic. You jump, you dash, you climb. Later levels do introduce environmental mechanics, but they're mostly versions of those three. You jump, you dash, you climb. It lulls you into a rhythm, making you persist even through death after death. You jump, you dash, you climb. For a while I thought that was all it was going to be.

See, I started Celeste expecting nothing more than a neat little platformer and I impatiently button-mashed through the dialogue trying to get back to the gameplay. Around the 4th level I realised I'd been skipping some of the strongest indie game writing in recent memory. The story is surprisingly simple and heartfelt, melancholy and triumphant, crushing and soaring. There are themes in the main character's arc that I don't want to spoil by mentioning but that are searingly relatable. Celeste made me tear up twice, once because I could feel Madeline's pain and struggle, and once again because I was so proud of her progress. By this point, the platforming I've previously lauded praise on had become a backdrop, a perfect interstitial between the cutscenes that managed to elegantly mechanically reflect the themes of the current story.

Celeste is nothing short of brilliant.

39982717.review: This is what a masterpiece feels like.

39982197.review:
Quite frankly, Celeste is near perfection. Before I start, just buy it, it really is something special.

This game is one of the best, most complete 2d platformers of all time. I went into it with a hint of skepticism. Lately there's been an absolute deluge of 2d indie titles, with some sort of renaissance happening with the medium right now, so for a game like this to hit me this hard, it really means something.

At first glance it's a simple masocore platformer in the vain of games like super meat boy: that rough 2d look and insanely tricky platform puzzles, requiring twitch reflexes and astute timing. But once I booted the game I immediately realised that a super meat boy clone this was not. Right from the get go this game has context, a proper story about a young woman coming to a mountain to do something, to either prove something to herself or escape from something. And the game reflects this throughout, both with the setting of the mountain and of the difficulty curve itself. As you ascend close to the top, more and more revelations happen in the story and the challenge gets harder, but so too does your determination (Undertale reference not intended). As Madeline struggles yet perseveres, so too do you, overcoming the rising challenges and ascending the mountain. 

The story hits on some deeply relatable themes. Both Madeline and Theo have a reason to climb the mountain, and both are believable and understandable. You can skip some of the dialogue throughout the game, but I feel you would miss out on a lot of the context and the message it's trying to tell. Some of the problems facing Theo I myself have had to tackle, and likely a lot of you will too. I really wasn't expecting that from a game of this ilk. 

In all, the ascent itself isn't astonishingly difficult, with the climb being more about the representation of Madeline's realisations as much as it is about pushing the player to their limit. However the additional content and optional areas are what really dial the game up a few notches. You can find bonus strawberries throughout the game which reside within some fairly difficult platforming challenges and hidden areas. These are strewn all throughout the different levels of the game and tempt you to test yourself every time you find one. Though non essential, you constantly find yourself yearning for one when you see it, unable to leave it behind for fear of "failure". The theme of the game really drives you on here. But these are only minor obstacles once you unlock the alternate sides of levels. For every level there are B sides, amped up versions of the level where your skill will be tested on another tier from the main game. These alone can be totally daunting, with some of these taking me around 40 minutes to complete, even as a fan of tricky platformers. And lets not even start with the later sides you can unlock, where being merely human is not enough.

In all, Celeste is an experience aswell as a game. It's the perfect ratio of story and gameplay combined to form a genuinely fulfilling experience that i'm glad I had the chance the complete. To some degree, I hope the developers will release some form of additional content to expand further on Theo's character. The game quite rightfully focuses on Madeline from start to finish, but I would like to follow some of his own challenges throughout the game. Honestly that's my only request, the game does everything else right. The difficulty curve is perfect, the optional content is as as hard as you want it and the game strings it all together with a story and theme that really makes you want to see Madeline succeed.

For the sake of good games everywhere, buy this. It deserves a purchase.

39981654.review: Celeste is a platformer that is filled to the brim with death traps which make the game hard, similar to the very first Mega Man. The main character, Madeline, keeps hallucinating and gaining abilities the farther you go into the game. One that you get relatively quickly is the ability to dash. The dash ability is extremely similar to Specter Knight's dash from Shovel Knight. It's the main mechanic other than Madeline's ability to climb basically anything. She can of course jump as well, and she can look up and crouch too, but she can't move when she is crouching or looking above herself. All around, this game is a hella good time. Pick it up on here or even get the Switch version, I don't care which. This game is amazing!

39981277.review:
Celeste est un jeu créé et développé par Matt Makes Games Inc.

C'est un plateformer 2D où vous devrez escalader un mont en parcourant des niveaux avec des univers tous différents !

Et ce jeu est excellent ! On a là le meilleur gameplay de l'année 2018, tout simplement ! 

Vous pouvez vous accrocher aux murs pour les escalader, et dasher dans les airs. Le gameplay est aussi simple que ça. Mais dans chaque "monde", vous découvrirez de nouveaux pouvoirs comme sauter une fois de plus, foncer tout droit dans les airs ou bien même voler !

Pour ce qui est du style graphique, c'est tout aussi bien maîtrisé ! C'est du pixel art très (voire un peu trop) simpliste avec des mélanges d'HD avec l'interface et les dialogues.

L'OST est juste superbe ! Certaines musiques (surtout celle du dernier "boss") m'ont transcendé !

Pour ce qui est du scénario, vous êtes Madeline, et vous voulez grimper le mont Celeste. Et ce serait le point négatif du titre, le scénario est trop ordinaire. Mais le gameplay prend énormément le dessus !

39978558.review:
I'm one of the people that's experienced Celeste from it's origin; and thought I had an idea of what to expect. I was WRONG.

For starters, this is a game that does NOT confuse depth with complexity. It is not complex; but it does present you with an array of abilities in it's levels; and fully explores the possibility space within those abilities, without any of them overstaying their welcome or feeling underappreciated. The levels are big and mostly nonlinear; but always having a feeling of natural progression to them; and some routes are FAR more challenging than others.

Madeline's emotionally wrenching journey to the top (of the grocery store shelves) is perfectly complimented with this very immersive environment and soundtrack - and even everything in the game seems to dance with the rhythm of it; yet in a way that doesn't exactly make this flow like a rhythm game.

I'm at stage 7 now; and there's one thing I'll admit, but I wont spoil too much about. For all it's simplicity, this game has one of the most intense and thrilling boss chapters I've ever experienced; and I play stuff like MegaMan X6 and Dark Souls for lunch.

GET. THIS GAME. IT IS MAGNIFICENT.

39951925.review:
If you're reading reviews, you're probably trying to answer the question: Does Celeste live up to the hype? What's so great about it?

In a word: polish, in every way.

Yes, it's at heart a pretty simple 2d platformer, but the difference between a great game and an average game is rarely in the big picture stuff; it's in the details, in how well it's all put together and how refined the result is. And Celeste scores absolutely top marks on that front. It's not groundbreaking, or genre-bending; there's not a massive living world for you to get lost in; it's just simple, 2d platforming that's been polished until every surface is smooth and clean. 

The controls, as everyone has no doubt heard a thousand times, are tight and responsive, and just feel good. The music is outstanding. The story is entertaining - though if you're the sort who just doesn't care about the story, the cutscenes are skippable. The level design is consistently solid and varied, with unique elements introduced in each level so it never feels repetitive. 

It's very rare for me to get 20 hours into a game and not be able to think of anything it did wrong, and that's where I'm at with Celeste right now.

Now, all that said, if you hate 2d platformers in general, I don't see any reason Celeste will be the exception. If you're just burnt out and gun-shy after years of the glut of rough indie platformers on the market, though, Celeste is probably going to make you happy.

39946366.review:
[h1] Absolutely Phenomenal [/h1]

   Celeste is a game that proves to you that you can die 2000+ times and still have a lot of fun playing it (or at least, it was my case). Some people may find this overwhelming, or have low stress tolerance, so the game offers a option that allows you to go easier, and enjoy the journey to the top of the mountain, without the stress. But in overall, I just loved how the levels were fresh and the challenges, exciting. The mechanics are simple, yet, they are sharp in response like a well-tempered blade. This is a watershed for me that defines if I'm gonna love or hate a platformer, and the game exceeded my expectations. The soundtrack was another thing that stood out. It's been a long time since I noticed myself completely stopped in the middle of a map because I was too distracted contemplating such beautiful BGMs.

   Regards story, the game also tackles and brings attention to an important topic, yet often ignored by a lot of games: mental illness. It shows the viewers what feels like to have depression, or panic attack, in a lot of different languages (visuals, texts, etc). Since I've been on a fight for years agains't these mental illness and worse ones, some dialogues definitelly made me shed some tears, and I'll take the things I've learned from Celeste for the rest of my life. I can say for sure that this game is more important to me now than any triple A has been so far because of this.

   If you're not sure if you should play this game, you already should bought this game weeks ago. If you already played, you should be playing it again.

[Edit]: Found out about the B-Side tapes (Secret harder levels you can unlock to challenge yourself) and the death count is now five thousand.

39935223.review:
Don't be decieved by what one might consider simplistic mechanics and artstyle, this gem of a game has something to offer platformer novices as well as veterans. On the surface it lends you few mobility options, however, when combined in certain ways you'll quickly realise that you have advanced mobility almost akin to Super Smash Bros Melee making it very speedrunner friendly and lets you tackle the countless obstacles thrown at you YOUR way.
The main game is moderately challenging and has more than enough spots to take a breather if need be, you have infinite lives and the checkpoints are at every room entrance and exit so you won't have to worry about getting sent back to the start of a level if you were to take a tumble. Now, the content aside from the main game is generous to say the least, there are strawberries that test your platforming skills before you get to collect them, B-side tapes that offer you remixed and more challenging variants of the regular levels and then there are other secrets that I'd much rather have people find on their own.

All in all? Best platformer I've played in years, the levels are beatiful and introduce new mechanics before the old ones even feel old, the characters are cute and endearing, the story is engaging without hour-long cutscenes and the soundtrack by Lena Raine is to die for, which I expect you will do plenty of, die, countless times and love every second of it.

39932329.review:
Celeste

Its one of those games you just can't rate just by numbers at least not with standardized ways.

Lets start with the story.
You are Madeleine a girl which goes through some difficult times right now. To get her head free you sets out for a journey. As experienced hiker Madelaine wants to climb the legendary mystical Mount Celeste, this is the story of her finding herself.

The Game Introduces itself with a a short prologue and the basic controls (which i highly recommend you rebind via the settings or use a controler to play) and setting up the mood that this journey is bound to become a very special one. 

After that you'll dive right in. There are Strawberries you can collect and there are a ton of hidden secrets (and achievements)! Its also very nice that the game tells you that you wont get anything from collecting strawberries and you should collect them only if you find fun in collecting stuff :D

Throughout the levels you will find diverse NPCs you can interact with, further getting information about Madeleine and Mount Celeste. You will find that you are indeed not alone on this trip! After every Level and during some conversations you also get beautifully handdrawn cutscenes which help conveying the plot very much!

Each level will also introduce a new movement  technique for you to learn, which it then utilises in the separate rooms and builds the difficulty on it. (for example to do a dash in midair) So this means, while some rooms are definitely very difficult, you'll always know what to do you just have to find your way around them! Some rooms are only there for you to get through, some are little puzzles who are fun to solve!

As stated above Madeleine goes thorugh a difficult time right now, and so this game is also about fighting/surviving your inner demons; topics like dealing with depression and self counciousness play a heavy role in the story of Celeste.

Similar to Dark Souls you cant lose while playing Celeste. The only way to loose is to give up.

Conclusion:
-----------------

[list]

[*]+ Wonderful Pixely Graphics, which wont get boring and greatly contribute to the beauty of this game
[*]+ Absolute Stunning Soundtrack! Music will determine the tone and mood of each level heavily and ranges in variety from adrenaline inducing fast paced songs, over calm moody ones, to creepy/sad ones and then there is that one song in rooms with switching platforms that      apparently is just there to mock you xD
[*]+ A very well written Story for the Protagonist that is also very relatable! (YOU WILL learn something, that you can apply to your own life here!)
[*]+ Very fluid and forgiving controls
[*]+ A variety of levels all with different themes (city, medieval, forestry)
[*]+ Rewarding secrets!

[*] B-Side Cassettes: practically Bonus/Alternative version of the level you are in 
     SUBSTANTIALLY HARDER THAN THE LEVEL ITSELF! 
[/list]

Celeste is a great platformer with a very well written Protagonist and a stunning soundtrack that truly will make everyone happy. Newcomers to platforming and Pros as well.

Its Price may seem a bit high at first, because you can Speedrun this game in 4 hours. but if you are into collecting stuff and not just into speedrunning the game and like to take in the scenery and explore (which i strongly recommend) you will have substantially more fun during your time playing it.

This game is very well made and another example for why small indie studios often make better games than AAA-Studios.
It is worth every penny and I gladly supported its developers.

If you are short on money, you can wait until its in a Humble Bundle or in a Sale on Steam, but YOU HAVE TO GET IT! ASAP!

Thanks for Reading.

Вроде на серьезные темы с тобой разговаривают - про то, как сложно бывает жить в мире с самим собой, про депрессию, но делают это без занудства.

Еще музыка замечательная - саундтрек периодически слушаю просто так.

This game is definitely worth its high price tag. Not only does it build on the characters beautifully, it also succeeds in bringing unique and thoughtful gameplay to the platformer genre. Instead of just hard mechanical challenges (there are still plenty of those), Celeste tries to challenge you with puzzles and offers new ways to use your abilities almost every chapter. 

You'll surely die a lot your first time playing through Celeste, but the satisfaction of figuring out and getting through each room will definitely make up for the frustration. If anyone here has the money to spare I highly recommend purchasing Celeste. :)

39924127.review:
Amazing game.  I'm generally a fan of this kind of precision platformer, and this is a stunning example of it.  It's replaced my previous favorite, Dustforce.  While Dustforce I'd say has harder high end levels, this game's overall package is just incredible.  The music, narrative, shifting mechanics on each level, and the way the story and gameplay intertwine seriously impressed me.

It also features a very handy assist mode for people who choose to use it.  If you desire, you can turn on assist mode for your save file, which gives you an options menu that you can toggle at will for things like extra dashes, infinite grip, or even invincibility or level skipping.

39924126.review:
This game is flawless. That is scientific fact, I have research to prove it, and has absolutely nothing to do with the emotional bias introduced by this game's wonderful story. Which it did introduce. In great quantities. Seriously, this game has a genuinely meaningful and interesting story.

Concerning gameplay, these kinds of games tend to be frustratingly challenging, and this one can be too, but I feel this game does absolutely everything in its power to ever let that hinder your enjoyment of it. Oh hey a list:

-1) The game never ever ever demands ninja-level finger dexterity & timing from the player. In fact, it's wary about even approaching it. When I ever thought the game was asking me to make a crazy jump, I was mistaken - I eventually found a much better way to go. Because of this, there's no part of this game I would dread replaying; a genuine feat with this kind of platformer.
-2) The controls are so unbelievably well polished. Not just to be responsive, but more importantly, all actions are easily repeatable & thus consistent. This applies to even the most complex techniques in the game. Again, this goes back to finger dexterity - anyone can play this.
-3) When concerning fast-paced games, if you would describe yourself as an intoxicated sloth with severe bladder issues, fear not! You can still play this. There's an "assist mode" which lets you tweak some core rules to make everything easier. You can turn it on at any time - please don't be too stubborn to use this. Consider it a 'safety net' if this game does turn out too hard, and you want to actually keep enjoying yourself.

The game is simultaneously tuned to please the high-effort players too - the amount of optional challenges in this game is unreal. And every last bit of it brings something brand new.

Nine-billion out of ten, buy it

39923367.review:
By and far one of the most purely enjoyable platforming experiences I've had to date, with some solid music, a plethora of challenges to overcome and secrets to find, with a very comfortable and well-tuned difficulty curve. The story, characters, and themes resonated very strongly with me as well, as somebody who has struggled severely with depression in the past. I couldn't regret a single penny spent on this if I tried, and I haven't even completed it in full yet. I absolutely [i]cannot[/i] recommend this enough to anyone who likes platformers.

Keep on climbing, you can do it!

UPDATE: Closing in on the last few levels in the game and my opinion has changed very little. This game is still incredible at every turn (with exception of the occasionally frustrating bumper segments). I dearly hope to see a level editor in the future, it would suit the game beautifully.

39908549.review:
Games should not be allowed to be this good.

I bought Celeste at full price at the insistance of the N++ discord folks, my small protest about waiting for sales thoroughly shot through. It couldn't have been five minutes into the game before the fun just started wafting, like delicious steam off of a freshly baked pie, into my face. It controls so well, the sounds as Madeline runs and boosts feel so nice on my ears, and even when I died for the hundredth time I continued to smile, because I was having fun.

I knew at fifteen minutes in that it would be a one sitting completion, because I would [i]not[/i] allow myself to leave this gem unfinished and go to bed. And so I pushed. I ignored my inner completionist for the sake of my potential future sleep, instead focusing on the main path towards the summit. And I was rewarded with mechanic after mechanic that continued to stack and make me giggle as I took them apart and learned to use them, and a story about a woman who is doing something she is entirely unprepared to do, but must do regardless, and stage after stage of platforming goodness.

It was a wonderful journey, and it was worth more than the price I paid for it. Thank you for convincing me, C.C.S.

Now, twenty-odd hours in, I'm scraping the entirety of the game for all its secrets, all the brutal bonus levels, all its hyper hush-hush extra bits. No idea when I'll be done, but I feel like it's gonna be a while. And that's just fine by me.

Buy it, it's wonderful.

This is a masterpiece. I loved every second of it. It is extremely challenging though. Sometimes more challenging that Super Meat Boy. But that's a good thing.
It is easy to admire the passion that went into creating this game. Every pixel was placed perfectly and the game looks beautiful. The particle effects, the weather, Madeline's hair, everything. The soundtrack is also really great. I had not heard a soundtrack that good since Hotline Miami 2.
The story is also really good. It seemed forced at the end, and it ended up being a little awkward, but the dialog is top-notch and the story is touching anyway. But the thing that really kept me coming hard was the difficulty. I just finished the main levels, and I will try to get every strawberry before attempting the B-Side.

Another awesome thing about Celeste is that even though it's challenging, you can choose how hard you want it to be. You could decide not to get any strawberries (the most challenging jumps are for collecting the straberries) or turn the assist mode on. The assist mode can make the game up to 50% slower, give you infinite dashes and other things. It is not the way it's meant to be played, but it's nice to have the option to make things less frustrating.

In the end, Celeste is an awesome game. The end is a little disappointing, but it's still touching. The game looks amazing and the soundtrack is great. I would give it a 9.5/10. A must buy.

Also, for the price, you get up to 25 hours of gameplay. I already finished the main game, but there's still much more to collect. It is worth your money.

39896480.review:
Overall Celeste is a fantastic game that I would recommend to anyone remotely interested in platformers. There's a fair amount to cover here, so I will arrange my review into "bullet points" for ease of separating things into pros and cons.

+++ TIGHT CONTROLS: This is extremely important in a precision platformer like Celeste, and the game nails it. Never once when I played did I really feel like I had died to the game misinterpretting a control or not doing what I wanted it to. This made it a lot less demoralizing to die, since I knew that it was my own fault and if I did better next time I could succeed. The only controls I have a tiny bit of trouble with are the golden feather controls being a little difficult to get used to (but I feel like that might have been the point).

+Good Story: The story isn't exactly subtle or incredibly unique, but it does offer an interesting and metaphorical look at the nature of anxiety and belief in oneself. The story is also unobtrusive to gameplay, and all cutscenes are skippable if you don't want to watch them again when replaying a level.

+Collectibles: There's a vast swathe of collectibles in the game and enough content to facilitate at least 20 hours of gameplay (assuming you try to find things on your own without looking them up). With the exception of a few to enter the final level (4 out of the 16 total of a certain type), all collectibles are also strictly optional.

+Difficulty Settings: Not true difficulty settings, but there are quite a few ways that Celeste offers different difficulty levels for different players. Baseline, the game offers an "assist mode" for players who feel the game is a bit too challenging, which can enable things such as infinite air dashes or even incincibility if you just want to see the story. As for the default settings, the game can still be fairly easily breezed through by a competent player in a few hours without going for any collectibles. Players interested in a greater challenge can go for collectibles (which are often challenging to find and even more challenging to acquire once located), or the brutally punishing B-side levels (harder variations of already-completed levels).

+Graphics: While graphics don't matter so much, Celeste is legitimately one of the most beautiful 2d games I have ever played. Seriously, just look at the screenshots. Gorgeous.

+Soundtrack: This game sports an amazing soundtrack, rivalling other games with famously great soundtracks such as Undertale and Hollow Knight. Lena Raine is a phenomenal composer and artist, and it shows through in this game.

-Unfair Collectibles: This is a very minor complaint, but some of the collectibles in the game are rather bothersome to find. They will sometimes be hidden in a fake wall, and while many of these have a crack or somesuch to indicate that they are something else, a few don't. It left me frustratedly jumping at any open wall I could hoping to locate that last strawberry when I had exhausted other options.

-Arbitrary gating: Another small complaint that only really applies when going for collectibles. Sometimes the game will lock you out from going backwards without any real warning when you go from one screen to the next. This makes it rather annoying when collectible-hunting, checking an area for a strawberry only to have it prevent you from going backwards again without any warning.

Overall this game is absolutely amazing, and one of the best games I have ever played. It should serve as an example to future platformers of how to make a game that truly shines without having overly complicated controls or arbitrarily punishing levels. If I had to assign a numerical score, it would be at least a 9/10, maybe even a 10/10, and I would highly recommend it.

39886249.review:
Overall a great game with a respectable learning curve. Artwork is beautiful and the music for the most part is great, there are some lower quality tracks but these are made up for by the really good ones, like "Resurrections". 

I love how the game rewards the player for exploration. I miss the old days when game developers could hide secret areas in a fun way, rather than behind DLC. As the game says in the description, this is a game "The way mom used to make it". You can tell that this game was made to be enjoyable and with love and dedication, rather than made in as little time as possible for as much profit as possible. 

My only major complaint about the game is that they actually included a feature where you can look through binoculars to see further into the level so you can plan ahead, but these are missing in some of the areas where they are needed the most. It was infuriating trying to complete the B-sides and getting hundreds of deaths just because I was having to try and figure out where to go in the middle of the action. I feel like if you are going to include a feature like that, it should be used more often in those kinds of places.

Other than that, I really liked it and will probably keep playing for 100% completion

39883929.review:
This is the kind of game you get once in a generation. This damn game. In an area of the genre that's historically dried itself out with some real samey stuff riding off the coattails of a game like Super Meat Boy, Celeste breathes some incredible air into how you can make that game all at once accessible, challenging, and relaxing. Because on top of Celeste's ridiculous, inspired level design are some seriously gorgeous and charming environments and character illustrations, varied and soothing soundtrack, and a fucking admirably clever sense for theming and writing. Because not only does the dialog in Celeste communicate its characters well, but the levels themselves tell the story in a way that is, honest to god, kind of breathtaking to experience.

Celeste is a game anyone can play, it's a game that doesn't taunt you or mock your failures, it doesn't even contextualize death as "failure"; it just sees it as learning, a way to keep track of how far you've come. You're never pressured to finish a level, because the game's always willing to save your spot for you if you want to just take a break and try again later, which saves even the challenge levels from being frustrating and instead just makes them feel long and a bit exhausting, but always gratifying and never a pain. I haven't liked a 2D platformer this much since Rayman Origins, and I might even consider Celeste to be a step above that! This game rocks.

39881495.review:
If there's a game that perfectly embodies what makes platformers great, this is the one.

One of the most solid 2-D platformers in years, finely tuned around it's simple central mechanic of dashing that offers an incredible amount of depth and tech skill. The game ingeniously continues to expand and expand on this one mechanic, offering a vast variety of possiblities, from momentum-based jumping puzzles to fast-paced, adrenaline filled platforming challenges.

The story is servicable, and works perfectly for the type of game. The characters are what makes it truly shine - the general plot of climbing a mountain is extremely simple, but allows these fantastic characters to grow around and with each other and have genuniely fantastic and heart-warming interactions between each other. This especially becomes apparently later into the game, and without spoiling anything, this game tackles several aspects of human personality that you wouldn't expect to see from a game like this.

The spritework is absolutely incredible. Top notch animation, absolutely breathtaking visuals, and all of the colors imaginiable mesh together to create a truly incredible world for you to explore. This is compounded by the game's absolutely stunning soundtrack, featuring very soothing piano pieces with traditional videogame synth, as well as a host of remixes for the hard-mode versions of the levels.

The game finally has a great sense of accomplishment in finding secret areas and goodies. From collecting strawberries to the elusive Crystal Hearts hidden in every level, you will always feel satisfied either in your technical ability or brain power when finally collecting them.

In summary, this game is absolutely fantastic, and as a lover of 2-D platformers for my entire life, this is not only one of the best in years, but has an absolutely stunning amount of replay value and potential for speedrunning. All in all, a beautiful adventure from start to finish, and one I cannot recommend enough.

9/10

39880638.review:
Man, where do I start? Alright, I know!


Celeste is a beautiful retro-style Platformer with similar difficulties that of Super Meat Boy, with the fun bonus of collectiable Strawberries and really hidden Crystal Hearts if you're up for the extra challenge, Celeste has a very nice story that you usually don't see coming, but somehow it fits perfectly in a game like this.

Celeste's chapters each have their own special little mechanic that makes them  unique, like changing amounts of wind that makes it harder to move in a direction, and even bubbles that move in the direction you point at!

There aren't just challenging jumps and timings, there are also a few bosses aswell, Celeste sports a respectable 3 full on bosses, but every chapter has a fun end part to top them off, next thing on my list are the lovable characters, Celeste has managed to blow me away not only with the beautiful soundtrack and great platforming, but it's also managed to create great and lovable characters too, like my favorite one, Theo; Not only is he a down-to-earth nice guy, but he always helps you out alot in his own quirky funny way, especially in Chapter 5. 


and with all of this said, I have reached the end of this review, overall Celeste is a nice, beautiful, retro-style, challenging, hilarious, lovable Platformer with a great story to it, but I must say; If you don't have much money to frequently buy games like me, just wait for a sale. 


And now, my review on Celeste is actually over, I hope this was atleast semi-helpful to any of you out there, goodbye and have a good day!

39870553.review:
Não é trabalho de um crítico de videogames dizer se um jogo é bom ou ruim, simplesmente. O objetivo da crítica é compreender as mecânicas básicas de jogo, relacionar todos seus elementos e então descobrir em que pontos o jogo se destaca, de maneira positiva ou negativa. Jogos que falham em determinados aspectos, como narrativa, podem ser indicados para públicos determinados por suas características de gameplay; o contrário também é frequente. Celeste é um caso raro de jogo recomendado para toda e qualquer pessoa. Os gráficos pixelados foram criados com a atenção aos mínimos detalhes, e com uma paleta limitada de cores os desenvolvedores foram capazes de construir personagens carismáticas e um mundo que está vivo e em movimento. A trilha sonora inclui mais de duas horas de algumas das músicas mais marcantes feitas para videogames nos últimos anos. E com uma jogabilidade simples e fluida, Celeste constrói uma dificuldade consoante com uma narrativa dedicada à doença mental e ao esforço de superar a depressão e ansiedade. Ao mesmo tempo, o sistema único de ajuda torna Celeste acessível mesmo para quem não possui os reflexos e a coordenação necessários para chegar ao topo da montanha por conta própria, um recurso que mais uma vez ressoa a mensagem de compreensão com a doença mental que o jogo quer passar.

Perfeito não é uma palavra que a Mãe utilize com frequência. Mas talvez o termo caiba em uma análise do jogo. Perfeito para experimentar uma forma inovadora de lidar com a dificuldade e perfeito para corridas contra o tempo que testam ao máximo as habilidades do jogador. Perfeito para aumentar a visibilidade de uma questão social importante e para absorver e apreciar boa arte, visual e sonora. Perfeito para aprender a lidar com desafios e para aproveitar uma boa estória. Celeste é perfeito porque alcança a excelência em todos seus aspectos e ao mesmo traz inovação para a indústria.

------------------------------------------------------------------

39869982.review:
Celeste is a game about self-discovery and anxiety under the guise of a great, hard-as-nails platformer.  Built for speedrunning and with lots of heart – help Madeline find herself (and strawberries) as she summits Celeste Mountain.

Madeline is on a journey of self-discovery. In hopes of shedding her routine existence, she’s decided to challenge herself to a climb of Celeste Mountain, completely unaware that Celeste Mountain tends to bring out the best (and worst) in people – literally. Madeline suffers from anxiety and depression  - something that is not often depicted in video games, especially platformers. Celeste does a good job of representing what that’s like, rare for a video game – even rarer for a platformer.

There are 8 worlds full of challenges, secrets and strawberries to collect. Run, jump, climb, and dash over obstacles with each world full of unique environmental hazards and assists all rendered in a gorgeous pixel art style.  B-side challenge levels increase the content AND the difficulty, presenting some truly nefarious challenges.

I really enjoyed my time with Celeste and I definitely recommend it.

Check out more of my Celeste coverage on 3CR:
https://thirdcoastreview.com/2018/02/05/game-review-celeste/

39868008.review:
Celeste is one of those indie gems that pops up from time to time. 

What I love most about the game it has fairly simple mechanics, but mixes them up in a way that doesn't cause the game to go stale. Each level brings a new theme to the table, but keeps to itself, allowing the level design to be about the level and not about loading the player with more and more things to have to interact with as the game progresses. 

The base game on its own is not a cake walk, but it's not crushing either, the rate in which you respawn after a death will barely give you time to consider giving up. The game tracks how many times you die on each level, but actively reminds you that your death counter is an ode to your persistence and not something to be ashamed about. 

For the masochists, each level has a "B-side" which can be unlocked via secrets in the main level. The B-side remixes the level to bring out the potential difficulty in the mechanics of that environment and then further adds to that by pushing the player to make precise, fast movements. 

The game also has a story that more or less just follows the main character pushing herself to climb the mountain, and along the way she discovers that not only is the mountain unique, but that it forces her to also challenge the worst of herself. 

Sadly there are a few negative points with this game:
Firstly joystick controls on the controller can be tempermental and having the stick pushed a few degrees to the left or right of a cardinal direction can cause you to instead air dash diagonally, which will usually always kill you. 

The Camera shake function is triggered by dashing, camera shake is fine on some environmental objects but when tied to dash it gets spammed constantly and can be a headache.. I recommend turning it off for challenge levels because the shaking will throw off precision jumps. 

In a few levels the secret hearts are located by finding extremely obscure hidden paths that would require you to blindly dash at walls which can be very boring since you are basically replaying old levels with no hints as to the general area you are looking. You need to find the secret hearts to be able to do the final challenge. The puzzle based secret hearts are very well designed and a challenge to figure out. 


Overall this game has been given a lot of love, and it has been pushed to give those wanting a story driven experience something to sit down to, and to give difficulty junkies like myself something to feel accomplished about.

39862214.review:
几乎是一口气，花费9h18min，死掉2745次之后，我打通了Celeste的主线。
在这之前我根本想不到这个平台跳跃游戏会如此吸引我——毕竟是烂尾过Super Meat Boy、The End is Nigh乃至Super Mario Brothers的夕阳红手残玩家。

仔细回味起来，Celeste的每个元素单独看虽均为同类及格线以上，却也不是多么的完美：
像素画质尽管对我胃口但表现力也有上限；
配乐音效十分贴切但也仅只是贴切；
游戏机制精巧而富于充满挑战，但这好像是同类的标配；
附带不少表演性关卡/场景的游戏剧情倒是意外地用心，但归根到底只是老生常谈的“悦纳自我”四字。

然而当Matt Makes Games Inc.把上述所有组合在一起，却产生一种“浑然天成”之感
游戏故事明面说的是登山，暗面说的是从某种心理病态挣脱出来，都是外人一眼看不出个中惊心动魄的事情——正好对应了乍看上去人畜无害低幼低清的像素平台跳跃外衣下，百死千亡的硬核游戏体验。
由此，在Celeste上反反复复的“失败—挑战”，被明确赋予了除“获取胜利感”之外更丰富的情感内核，给玩家提供了十足别致而强烈的通关动机。

值得一提的是，Celeste提供了功能如同外挂的“辅助模式”，想必是为了降低门槛保证销量。
作为小体量游戏，不能像黑魂仁王等大制作设计丰富机制来调整难度，采用这般简单粗暴的方法。。。
个人觉得还不错！！

39859202.review:
One word for this game. Stunning.

I'm not one for hardcore platformers. I played through the first couple chapters of Super Meat Boy and called it a day. The idea of dying over and over and over doesn't appeal and strikes me as frustrating.

But Celeste is different. Celeste WANTS you to win. As Madeline climbs the mountain in search of herself, and to settle the score with her inner demons, you're right there with her and NEED her to reach the summit.

And then when you do, you feel the urge to go back, to find more hidden tidbits, to tackle the harder levels... and I'm no completionist either! So while the story may take the average gamer like me 8-10 hours to complete, there's still more. And you'll return to the mountain.

Beautifully crafted. The visuals, the soundtrack, the audio (shout out to Power Up Audio!)
A definitive example of where art and video games meet.

39858345.review:
Let me preface this by saying that I have refunded this game on Steam. The keyboard controls are absolutely atrocious, and I do not recommend playing this without a controller, save if you're a masochist and/or enjoy hating yourself and everything else. I now only own this game on the Switch, but it's exactly the same, so I'll review it on Steam based on my experience on the Switch.

I absolutely adore Celeste, despite never having played a Dark Souls game, a Metroid game, or a Castlevania game. Quite frankly, I'm not sure how I came to the decision to purchase it in the first place.

The soundtrack is phenomenal. After nearly an hour in a single level (I'm bad at the game, fight me), it still hasn't gotten annoying or repetitive. It's really one of the most uplifting and magical collections of music I've heard in a video game.

Celeste features some of the best level design I've seen in a video game, ever. The game features two primary mechanics, jumping and dashing. That may seem a bit underwhelming, but the developers more than make up for it with levels that are super satisfying to complete and complement the art style perfectly.

Seriously, even when Celeste is kicking your ass, you'll still enjoy everything about it.

Just don't play on Keyboard and Mouse.

39843102.review:
被朋友推荐的一款平台跳跃游戏，想着上一个同类型游戏还是《超级食肉男孩（SuperMeatBoy）》，稍微有些激动地下载了

现在刚玩到第三章，短短1个小时，就迫不及待的来写评测，这个作品的惊艳程度可见一斑
这可能是我玩过的最帅、最干脆、最具速度感的像素游戏了。

所有动作都那么干脆利落，画面表现和音效很引人入胜，BGM也会随着进度和玩家的位置、操作不断变化，玩法非常新奇，剧情简练却又带有幽默
脑子一闪而过，我几乎考虑不到它的缺点
真正的神作。

另外它的难度并不高，不要被吓到。
不知为何，很多朋友喜欢把它和《I wanna be the guy》相提并论，我觉得没什么好比的，死100次和死10000次有本质的不同。它的难度非常平易近人，操作频率很低，甚至比《Super Meat Boy》还容易。
你只需要好好计划你的通关策略，而不像其他平台跳跃游戏那样，花太多的时间在游戏技巧上。

给制作人点赞，十分不错的游戏，让我很感动。我会推荐给其他朋友游玩。
请继续努力！

39837387.review:
Wow. Just wow. I never expected to love a 2d platformer as much as I love Celeste. Celeste easily falls into one of my top ten games of all time. So, if you are looking to buy this, I give it a definite yes! Here are the reasons why:

1. The levels are masterfully designed. Not one level have I looked at and thought to myself how bad of an idea it was to set up that way.

2. The controls are crisp and fluid. Going from a dash to grabbing onto a wall and performing any action feels satisfying in every way.

3. It is challenging in just the right way. The base levels are very fun and pretty hard, but if that doesn't scratch your itch, then there are plenty of b-side levels to try your hand at (these levels are BRUTAL).

4. I actually enjoy the story that follows the game, it isn't huge or complicated, but simple and heartwarming. The characters are cute and loveable.

MUST BUY

39837385.review:
BUY THIS GAME.

While the movement options in Celeste are minimal - you only have a jump and a dash - the extent to which the developers push these mechanics is mind blowing. There were multiple times where I thought a secret was impossible to obtain, but a slight variation in movement revealed a nuance behind the movement that had existed since the beginning of the game, but only became necessary now. Celeste's ability to repeatedly teach these nuances through level design rather than explicit instruction is thoroughly impressive. It's these a-ha moments that keep the game consistently fresh. 

All other aspects of Celeste are equally enjoyable. The soundtrack is dreamy. The story is surprisingly poignant, and doesn't feel overly forced. The graphics are beautiful. The challenge feels just right. One of the tightest and most satisfying platformers I've ever played.

39837285.review: The second Meat Boy with somewhat existing story. It's worth a shot!

39836400.review:
Occasionally, while playing Celeste, I’d get light-headed because I’d focus so hard on a sequence of jumps that demanded precise timing and perfect button presses that I’d forget oxygen was a thing my body needed. Trying and failing and trying again, getting a little closer each time, I let the beautiful art and adaptive music of the titular Celeste Mountain - alongside the passionate, relatable story told there - completely whisk me away.

Despite appearing at first to be yet another retro pixel-art 2D platformer, Celeste is surprising in so many different ways. From the moment I took my first jump, I fell in love with the satisfying way its protagonist, Madeline, feels to control; soon after I fell just as hard for the charming world she inhabits. But Celeste also caught me off guard with a relevant and emotional story about the pressures of modern life. What’s remarkable is that the story isn’t told in the background or overlaid on top of the action with constant interruption, but seamlessly and thoughtfully blended into the level design using both subtle themes and overt conversations. That’s especially astonishing in a genre not known as a vehicle for such delicate messages.

39835610.review:
A combination of grueling difficulty and having to overcome it so the main character can overcome her own obstacles and learn how to love and accept herself is just the most beautiful thing in the entire world.

This game is so simple, yet every single thing is executed flawlessly.

The main story and levels are hard enough that your average player will struggle a bit, but feel a great sense of achievement and progression both in themself and for Madeline once they complete it.

The post-game content is so ridiculously hard, and is there for the more hardcore players that want it. There's even challenges that aren't a part of the achievements, some of which are next to impossible.

"Funny how we get attached to the struggle.
Promise me that you'll take care of yourself, okay?"
Describes this game perfectly.

Hands down my favorite game of all time. If you're on the fence about this one, do yourself a favor and get it.

Thankyou developers, for making such an amazing experience.

39835369.review:
I basically only heard of this game the day it came out but boy am I glad I did because this is genuinely one of the best precision platformers I've ever played.

Let's start with the story and atmosphere? The story is really good? Not going to spoil it but yeah I enjoyed it a lot. Great characters and pretty relateable, and pretty surprising for this kind of game as well. The atmosphere is pretty dang fantastic? Like especially in level 5, geez, but just in general the levels each have a lot of personality to them. And the music's great too, personal favorite is the B-side track for level 5 but there's so much good music here.

Okay anyways onto the gameplay. The core movement mechanics alone support a lot of interesting level design and then each level has several extra mechanics on top of that, almost all of which work great with the basic movement mechanics themselves. The game plays smooth as butter and the level design is smart, rarely having instances where you'd have to wait or stop moving at all. No bosses, no autoscrollers, just constant enjoyable platforming challenges. There's maybe a small handful of rooms I wasn't a fan of (level 3 b-side and a few rooms in level 7 b-side come to mind) but so much of the game is good and has a great difficulty curve throughout that the small nitpicks hardly matter.

And on top of that it's got a great exploration aspect to it, the levels are not necessarily linear to begin with all the time but have a lot of secret rooms hidden away with various collectibles, including some really devilishly hidden ones that make interesting use of the game's mechanics or have some unique puzzle surrounding them. And this is kept strictly to the a-side of the level where exploration is most encouraged, leaving the more demanding levels as straightforward tests of skill.

It's just... a really great game all around, reminds me a lot of Dustforce even though they don't play particularly similarly, but it's definitely as smart as that game and maybe even better on the whole, who knows. It definitely sits comfortably among my favorite games of all time though, absolutely a must-play in my book.

39820226.review:
People say this game has tight controls, and I agree. They're so tight you can't even use them. At least not with a keyboard and mouse.

Keybinds are seemingly possible to change, so I changed the movement keys to WASD instead of the arrow keys. Gripe #1: I had to change every key individually because the devs didn't think about usability. 

I didn't get to play more than 2 minutes (including gripe #2:  2-3 annoying and infantile cutscenes that you have to press escape AND another key to skip) before an in-game tutorial told me to click "sideways arrowkey + X to dash". I don't know about everyone else, maybe they have some alien keyboards but I have never seen a sidesways arrow on a keyboard in my life. Nevertheless I tried every combination imaginable, both intuitive ones and the most retarded ones I could think of, but nothing happened. Gripe #3, as I couldn't dash, I couldn't get past the level and continue the game.

This is where the real shitshow started. So I went to the in-game keyboard settings yet again to change back to the arrowkeys for movement. I figured they couldn't program properly and maybe changing back to default movement keys would make it work. 

Somehow, changing to default movement messed everything up and I couldn't use the 'down' function anymore. Which means I couldn't navigate the menu or do anything. Which means gripe #4. It seems like the 'x' key is now bound to the down function as well as the back function, and the back function is the only one that works. I have no idea how this is possible, the only thing I know is that the devs didn't add failsafes.

So I uninstalled the game, and reinstalled. I did this 4 times until I realized that the Steam Cloud would not let me completely uninstall all game files, and the game would continue to load the messed up keyboard settings everytime i reinstalled the game. 

So I tried disabling the Steam cloud. And tried playing offline. That seemed to work (just tried navigating the menu again and it worked), until I went online again and Steam forced me to sync to the old cloud files even though I disabled this function.


Also, gripe #5, everytime you start the game, the credits are rolling. That's pretty arrogant, but makes sense seeing  as everything else about the games is dev-centered rather than user-centered.  Speaking of usability, you have to click a key to get to the main menu after starting the game. I guess the devs wanted to be different just for the sake of being different, or never played a game in their lives. Maybe the didn't know how to make the game menu appear as soon as you started the game.

TLDR: Controls don't work and there's no way to fix it because the developers didn't add failsafes, and Steam Cloud sucks ass. Devs obviously don't understand the importance of usability and didn't think of the end user when creating this game. So I assume it's a case of: No great loss.

39819728.review:
If you enjoy 2D platformers or speed games, you shouldn't pass this one up. Hell, you should consider it even if you're only looking for a good story, because this game has it all. It's difficult, but almost never feels unfair, and you learn the mechanics of the game by playing, rather than by tutorial screen. Although Madeline's moveset may feel small at first, there is a lot of depth to your movement options, and each level has a unique mechanic to it that expands on your moveset in interesting ways.

There are lots of collectibles to find in the form of strawberries, and while they are technically optional, this where a large amount of the gameplay comes from. In this game, when you find a secret area, you are rewarded with a challenge for a strawberry, rather than just a strawberry. It feels rewarding to prove your skill at the game, rather than your skill at finding secrets. Deaths don't feel too punishing, either, quickly putting you back into the action at the start of the room your were in.

The pixel art is wonderfully done, and the music is incredible. I don't really know how to describe it well, so just go watch the trailer if you don't believe me. And there's also a good story in this game, which is uncommon in 2D platformers in my experience. It's deeper than a "save the princess" story; there are real and relateable themes in Celeste.

TL;DR: Amazing gameplay, great story, wonderful presentation, and rewarding collectibles. 10/10.

Oh, and I should mention that the devs have been awesome about interacting with the community. Speedrunners have been finding small issues all over the place, but the developers are quick to fix them and have been listening to our suggestions.

遊戲的故事環繞在主角Madeline登山的過程中和自己邪惡那一面的交戰過程

但這款celeste，不管他以後是否會大降價，花468$購買，我認為是非常值得的
我覺得最可惜的是這遊戲在2018年1月25號上架
要是他可以早半年上架
或許Game Awards 2017又會多出一個可敬的Indie game黑馬了
10/10 
(2018年一月就有如此優秀的遊戲，想必今年會很精采)

39811769.review:
Celeste is genuinely a masterpiece. It is very obvious that the creators of this game put their heart and soul to create something that could only be described an experience that is well needed. The mechanics are incredibly tight, everything feels fluid, and throughout the course of the game there is constant stream of new mechanics that are being effortlessly sewn into the game. 

Story- This genuinely came a surprise to me, the story revolves around madeline, who is determined to reach the top mount celeste. She initially comes off as a character who has likely climbed a mountain or two in her day, and this is just mountain that she wants to tackle. But as you progress through the game you see Madeline's character develop into something that is heart wrenchingly relatable, and this mountain is more to her than saying that she climbed that mountain itself. The game also features a lovable cast of supporting characters that are very well written, everyone is lovable from the start

Music- The OST for this game is absolutely outstanding, every part of the soundtrack sets the perfect scene for whats going in the game and amplifies it ten fold. I was finding myself wanting to progress through the game not just because it was fun, but because i wanted to hear the next part of the soundtrack. It was obvious from the get go that Lena Raine poured her heart and soul into this OST, and even if you were to decide to not pick up the game, at least listen to the soundtrack.

39807929.review:
素质非常高的平台跳跃游戏。

移动、跳跃、冲刺、攀爬，以及各具特色的机关，Celeste用这些元素玩出了相当多的花样。

游戏机制上，最令我印象深的一点是它的引导机制：无UI，仅提示基础按键，游戏机制的深度要靠玩家自己去去发掘。比如一个机关，一开始你会想：哦，这个机关是这么用的；然而到下几个场景你感觉你的现有理解行不通，于是你就想：难道这机关还能这样？于是你动手试了试，一边发出“我靠 真的可以”的惊叹一边过了关。游戏隔几个场景就会丢给你新的东西，新的惊喜，不带停的，你要不断的学习这些新东西，发掘其中的可能性，最后才能通关。这种成就感太爽了。同时也侧面说明了游戏做到了平台跳跃的广度与深度。

一个平台跳跃游戏做到这点已经很不容易了，更难能可贵的是，它用极具风格的叙事手段，讲了个好故事，将几个角色塑造得有声有色。游戏的音乐配合场景有相当多的变奏，结合剧情，达到了强烈的演出效果，营造出游戏多变的节奏：听着柔和的钢琴度过前几个关卡，正当你感到稍腻的时候，音乐渐渐变奏，场景变得诡奇，伴随紧张的弦乐与撕裂的电子音，果不其然，你马上开始了boss战或追逐战。

游戏通关用了10小时，还有一堆特殊关卡没碰，意犹未尽。

39807275.review:
Celeste is the perfect entry level platformer, even without using the assist mode. Each chapter is broken down into a bunch of mini sections that all have a checkpoint at the very beginning, meaning that no matter how challenging each section is, you can keep trying over and over again until you beat it. The game is very forgiving in that regard.

This game is like someone teaching you how to write sentences, but before writing sentences, you first need to learn the alphabet. In the first third of the game, each section is teaching you a different letter of the alphabet. 

"Oh, what is that 'E'? That doesn't look like 'E' at all. You better keep practicing writing that 'E' until you write it [i]perfectly[/i]." 
"Finished perfecting that 'E'? Good! Let's move on to 'F' next!"

Sometimes, if you were an excellent letter writer, the game trusts you enough to begin forming words before you finish mastering the alphabet to give you a harder challenge. Sometimes you'll fail to make words, and that's okay. You're still learning, after all.

Once you master writing the alphabet, you've beaten the main game. The second third of the game has you putting together letters of the alphabet to form words, but you better make sure you wrote all those letters [i]perfectly[/i], or else you gotta to rewrite the whole word. 

At this point, Celeste doesn't trust you to write sentences by yourself. This time, you need to master writing ALL the words in the dictionary before you can begin making sentences.

For beginners, this game is a masterful teaching tool. [b]Celeste makes sure that you're good enough at its mechanics before letting you try a level that uses said mechanics. It makes sure you know how to write the necessary letters before writing the words that uses those letters[/b] This is the heart of its design. However, this design didn't work for me.

I already know how to write letters. Maybe Celeste has some new words for me to write, that's fine. But when can I start writing sentences? What was that? I can't yet? What do you mean I need to write all these words [i]perfectly[/i] first? I don't care if I'm not ready to write sentences. Sometimes I just want to try something difficult every once in a while.

Writing words all the time is boring. Some words are challenging, sure, but I don't feel rewarded for writing it correctly. They're just words. 

Sentences is where the fun is at, and that's exactly what the last third of the game is. After FINALLY mastering how to write every word in the dictionary, Celeste lets you write all the sentences you want, and it's a blast. I've never had more fun writing sentences in my life. 

TL;DR Needs more sentences mixed in with the words. Words are boring.



Celeste fails to properly reward you for completing its challenges in the first 2 thirds of the game. The majority of the challenges are too short to feel like an accomplishment, and the infinite and VERY frequent checkpoints makes most of them trivial. This is what makes this game perfect for beginners to the platformer genre. It properly tests you to make sure you've learned the necessary mechanics before letting you attempt a more diffcult challenge that uses those mechanics.

The last third of the game has brutally difficult challenges with practically no checkpoints, and that's what makes it so great.

Overall, I'd recommend this game to everyone. Experienced players of the platforming genre may find the tutorial to be too long, but there is a great game hiding at the end.

39800748.review:
I bought this expecting just some average 2D platformer but Celeste manages to create a satisfying experience throughout with it's awesome story and characters.  My other favorite parts is how the game motivates you throughout the experience to cheer you on as you get through it knowing well that it's hard and the advanced moves that the game teaches you throughout the experience.

The game is getting a lot of praise from reviewers recently with a 90 on metacritic and Overwhelmingly positive on steam, is it really worth the hype?  In my opinion I feel so but as is for most games don't set your expectations to the moon and expect it to deliver.  What you see is what you get but what you're getting is a competently made platformer.

While the game is hard the majority of it is solving simple puzzles to discover how you're supposed to tackle a platforming challenge instead of pixel-perfect-precision which is reserved for some of the unlockable challenge levels (there's an assist mode in which you can bypass any insurmountable challenge if need be).   I also love how the game handles strawberries in which an average player can find all of them without having to look them up.  However, some of the crystal hearts tend to suffer from being very cryptic to unlock but if you're a great problem-solver (aka not me) you should be fine.

It took me 6 hours to beat the game and 22 hours to 100% the achievements but considering how fun the advanced moves are and how you progressively get to be very good at the game I can see myself returning to this in the future.  There's even a late-game incentive towards doing the levels deathless for a true challenge, I wonder if it changes the game's ending?

Since I scored 30 hrs. into this game, I can finally make a review for this amazing game knowing full-well what I have been through. Okay, where to start. Well, first I want to say spoilers ahead for anyone who hasn't played it and/or hasn't beat it.

So, what I have been hearing are about the controls, they are actually quite fluent for me, since I am using a controller and not the keyboard. The game is better if you have a controller, it's much easier. This is basically the only gameplay problem I've seen.

First off, the character design is great, funny and lovable the same, [spoiler]especially the supposed, villian of the game, she actually turns good and helps throughout the near end of the game[/spoiler]. I know people really don't care about the story or the characters when they are just speeding through the game just to get it done, but I just wanted to take a sec to just want to applaud for what this game offers.

The level design is wonderful, even if you are or you aren't going for the strawberries, cassette tapes, and/or crystal hearts in each level, they use each thing you have learned from each level throughout it, even the teaching new things along the way. Like in the first level, it teaches you easily that springs restore a dash when bounced on, dashes can be only used once, and for the second half (or the third level) about the momentum of the platforms launches you farther than a normal jump. But most people already know that.

Knowing this is all I can spout out, you'll have a fun time with this game, it's just when it comes to getting to the final level of the game, it's kind of need to collect a few more things. When it comes to beating the game fully, [spoiler]you need to collect about 4 crystal hearts, which are found in the cassette tapes in each level (Normally called B-side), but in this place, it is extremely hard, take it from me.[spoiler]

This game is 8/10 for me. Hope to seeing more wonderful things from Matt Makes Games.

39785289.review:
A very well crafted, highly precise platformer. Your only moves are to jump, to dash and to climb, and with it you will conquer a multitude of dangerous levels and pitfalls. The game also features optional B- and C-Side levels and strawberries to collect. The graphics are charming, and the soundtrack is a masterpiece.

I completed the entire game (collecting all collectible strawberries except the golden ones which you can only get by completing a level without dying, as well as completing all B-Sides), but the C-Sides are what broke me in the end, particularly the Level 7 one - an ungodly amount of hard, for sure, but only if you seek the challenge. The actual story areas are in the range of easy to slightly difficult most of the time, which is perfect.

My only gripe with the game is that some rooms require almost "too" much precision. That can make the difficulty of those rooms feel almost cheap, though this is a rare occurence. The controls are very precise and spot on, but aligning your character with the smallest of holes can often feel like luck, as your hitbox is kind of hard to make out sometimes when you dash across the room. Additionally, swerving your character left and right can sometimes feel very imprecise. That is especially an issue in some of the C-Side areas, the hardest areas in the game.

Get this game if you enjoy a lovingly crafted platformer with a large host of optional, difficult challenges.

[b]Personal Rating: 8.5/10[/b]

39782638.review:
Celeste es un juego de plataformas en 2D, el juego mecánicamente recuerda mucho a otros juegos como Super Meat Boy o The End is Nigh, pero no me malinterpreten, el juego tiene una personalidad muy propia, presentando unas mecánicas muy novedosas y originales. En todo momento el personaje reacciona a nuestros movimientos, dando una sensación de absoluto control sobre el mismo.
Las mecánicas están bien pensadas y elaboradas, cada capítulo presenta nuevas mecánicas, una ambientación excelente.
El apartado gráfico es precioso, el mismo presenta una estética pixelada, las animaciones son muy fluidas y agradables a la vista, la paleta de colores es muy agradable y se hace muy buen uso de esta.
La banda sonora del juego es maravillosa, y encaja a la perfección con cada lugar y situación que se nos presenta.
Sinceramente la historia del juego no es su fuerte, pero cumple su función como motivación para sumergirnos en esta aventura.
El juego puede resultar difícil para una gran parte del público, pero en ningún momento el juego se siente injusto.
El juego no es muy largo, pero vale totalmente la pena por su precio, además tiene una gran rejugabilidad, y si te planteas completar el juego en su totalidad vas a pasar muchas horas intentandolo.

Celeste me ha parecido una muy grata sorpresa para empezar el año, y sin duda alguna va a ser uno de los mejores indies (y juegos en general) de este año 2018.

Y aquí termina mi humilde y breve analisis a este juego.
Mi calificación: 9/10

39781775.review:
Played using DDR Dance Pads - https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLRA5Y8XNiJ6goMFzn0zlzzCJvRP86dDPE

Celeste is a fantastic platformer that nails the perfect balance of tough-but-fair gameplay with a steady difficulty curve. Controls are tight and snappy, visuals are soft and pleasing and the soundtrack + SFX are phenomenal.

A lot of other platformers have the tendency to reward the player with more challenges, whether by unlocking bonus stages or reaching a new area but with Celeste you get so much more than that. You get introduced to a small but memorable cast of characters that progressively develop and push a narrative that gives the stages and challenges you face a lot more meaning.

Without going into specifics for the sake of keeping the game as spoiler-free as possible, Celeste reflects upon hurdles we all face in day-to-day life, how we cope with them and how we overcome mental barriers. It's a game of patience and persistence that encourages you to observe and explore your surroundings.

With an inbuilt assist mode, options to remove screen shaking and even a speedrun mode to better streamline the play experience, Celeste has taken great steps toward making itself as accessible as possible to a wide audience. If platforming and/or storytelling is your thing I wouldn't even question this purchase, it's well worth the money.

39775993.review:
Would I recommend this game? To most people - No.

Celeste does a lot of things right. The art style is beautiful, the story is cute, and the levels are just fantastic. However, it surprises me that Celeste has received such universal acclaim. I think it is a niche game - best suited for those who love quick reactions, tight controls and snap decisions. Me? I'm probably pretty average at platform games and Celeste completely destroyed me.

The frustrating part is that 9 out of 10 deaths are because I dash in the wrong direction. I first figured it must be because I used the stick and not the dpad. So I switched to the dpad, but it was only marginally better. Some of the later stages require such quick direction changes that for me it came down to luck rather than skill.

But if you are looking for a challenge and don't mind dying a few hundred (or thousand) times, then go for it.

I would indefinitely recommend this as a buy to anyone that were curious.

Amazing game! 9/10

This game has great controls, giving you all the power and making you feel like you could go anywhere. Its not really about pixel-perfect platforming, but rather about figuring out what your supposed to do to beat the level and then continuously trying until you get it. I have died over 2200 times in this game in one playthrough!

It feels great to play, making it fun to do the side challenges to get these Strawberry collectibles. Even though strawberries didn't do anything, it felt great to get them because they were always a challenge to get. This is another game thats hard to put down once you start playing. 

For a 2D sidescroller, this game actually has a good story. Its very simple, but the characters you encounter all have unique personalities (similar to undertale) and the progression of the story is one of my favorite elements of the game. 

The only thing that wasn't amazing was the music. The music was okay, some songs were good but they just weren't catchy like in VVVVVV, LISA or Undertale. Don't get me wrong, the music still did a great job of setting the atmospere, it just didn't stand out as being particularly great. Just good. 

Honestly, if the music was better, this game would deserve a 9.5/10. It still is an amazing game!

39769033.review:
I'd say that this is the most satisfying and one of the hardest games i've played thus far regarding platformers. 100% pure skill is needed.

If you're aware of the game Towerfall Ascension and liked it, then this game is a must automatically. However, if you've never heard of this game but love tough platformers, GET TO KNOW IT! It's an absolute masterpiece in multiple ways. 

[b]Story[/b]
The story itself isn't insanely big but the story that's there is pretty much perfect for the setting. You're thrown into climbing a mountain without knowing truly why. A mountain..? Seems normal right? NOPE nothing about this story is normal and that's exactly why it's so good. It picks up nicely and every stage makes you more curious about the next. 

[b]Graphics[/b]
I mean, I am a huge lover of pixel art in general... but the atmosphere set in this game with the graphics alone is a tremendous feat alone. It's absolutely adorable, pretty and very clear. I'd give this a 10/10. Just wait till you get to the third stage before you set your opinion. (:

[b]Characters[/b] 
Not much to say, the main character is super adorable and possibly for some relatable as well. The other characters are equally adorable and interesting. Amazing character progression for how small the ''actual'' game is. More about the ''actual'' part later.  

[b]Music[/b] 
Best music i've heard in a long time for games. First time I am tempted to actually buy the soundtrack. 10/10.

[b]Controls[/b]
Insanely tight. Can't be better, feels fluent and fun. 

[b]Gameplay[/b]
Oh boy, where do I even begin? The gameplay is if I had to describe it in one word '"Satisfying'' every single move you do is deliberate snappy and good. There's a good sense of progression and the game ramps up in difficulty quite nicely. I HIGHLY recommend to avoid the extra stages if you're more of a casual player because they can be extremely difficult. 

There is a TON of collectibles to find in neat little puzzles/secret stages and other crazy stuff. They are not required for finishing the story, but add a lot of gameplay and replay value to the game. There are STILL secrets out there nobody has found out about yet and it's crazy fun. Everytime you think it's over or something can't surprise you any more.. it does. HARD. 

New elements/mechanics introduced in every new stage you play. None of them feel gimmicky or forced, they're all incredibly fun to try out and play with.

[b]Overall score for me[/b]
A definite 10/10 but certainly NOT for very casual players. Be aware that this game is quite a challenge. 

One last note, there's an assist mode in the game which you can't turn off... but if you're unable to beat the game you can enable it and basically give yourself ''cheats'' to experience the rest of the game that way. So in the end, it's still approachable by all if needed.  

BUY IT!

39768060.review:
[h1]雪山之行远亦险，草莓好吃果难摘——浅谈IGN开年满分神作Celeste[/h1]

从物理系统鬼畜的super meat boy，到翻转腾挪的VVVVVV，再到一直以高难度著称的I wanna系列，这些平台跳跃类的游戏的操作只有跑、跳、多段跳，借助这些简单操作的繁杂组合通过一个个看似不可能的关卡。因此容易被打上的标签往往是“超难”、“抖M向”甚至还有“怀旧”。。。这些游戏全篇都是跳跳跳，山的外面还是山，等着玩家的只有难度递增的关卡，因此相比其它注重画面剧情不俗的作品类型，吸引力上就落了绝对下风。而在8012年，Celeste告诉了我们，平台跳跃不仅可以讲画面，拼音乐，甚至还有一个真挚动人的故事等待着大家发掘。
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1286114633  

[h1]故事梗概：[/h1]
[b]许多人的心中都有另一个自己，并且终其一生两人也无法达成和解。
我们的小主人公来到了塞莱斯特山试图登上峰顶，然而在山峰的神秘力量推动下，心里那个消极阴暗的自我受到了召唤并且具象化，对其登山计划进行了百般阻挠。她在攀登途中遇到了同为登山者的男孩Theo、在山上开旅馆的老奶奶、还有无法承受山庄关闭打击幻化为幽灵的Oshiro先生。或是鼓励或是嘲讽，小女孩在这些人的影响下逐渐坚定了自己登顶的决心。然而就在山顶触手可及的时候，却突然。。
[u]欲知后事如何，请自行剁手通关。[/u][/b]

[h1]操作方面：[/h1]
Celeste没有采用一般平台游戏十分不牛顿的二段跳，而是选择了更为不牛顿的一种方式：向任选方向冲刺。因此与其它跳跳跳游戏相比，本作在关卡设计上也就有了更自由巧妙的发挥空间。而且女主臂力惊人，不仅可以蹬墙跳，还能徒手爬墙（但有体力限制）。因此操作流程有别于传统跳跃游戏，上手时间可能会略长。值得一提的是游戏选择用女主的发色改变来表示剩余的冲刺次数，操作起来非常灵动可爱。要求大量连续操作的地段极少，地图中的看得见或看不见的待收集奖励很多，但存在的意义纯粹是给高玩提供炫技的机会，普通玩家不必强求自己全收集（愣头青选手除外）。

[b]最后我想说的是，Celeste有官方作弊器，有官方作弊器，有官方作弊器。虽然开无敌玩跳跳跳显得很滑稽，但这一举动也体现了官方的人文关怀：[u]想要体验平台跳跃却一直无从下手的玩家，或是被剧情吸引却对平台跳跃不感冒的同学，你们可以开始了。[/u][/b]
[h1]再见了，我继续去摘草莓了。[/h1]
[spoiler]悄悄地装上一逼，我已经集齐草莓了——Feb.2  23:53[/spoiler]
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1286154110

39766619.review:
This game is absolutely amazing.
I'm biased because I'm a platforming fan, but still.

There's no combat, no upgrade system, no huge save-the-world plot. It's just you, the mountain, and whatever obstacles you may face while attempting to climb it, including yourself.

First of all, the art. It's mostly pixel art. Yeah it's 2018 and everyone knows indie devs here and there use pixel art as a cheap and effective way to represent their game. C'mon, everybody knows it's not to "evoke feelings of nostalgia from the gud ol' days". This game though, despite using pixel art as well, does it right. Everything is beautifully drawn and animated. Maps feel alive and hazards stand out fairly well while still not looking out of place in the world itself. When I said it's mostly pixel art I meant the creators actually used different artstyles in a few places: The world map in completely 3D, and menus and speech bubbles are a more modern, smooth-edged 2D artstyle. It all matches up pretty well and looks very good. 

The story is nothing huge, nothing innovative, but I feel it is worth mentioning. While not being the main focus of the game, it still manages to deliver a very good cast of characters, each with a different and interesting personality(ies hehe). Some minor characters are simply mentioned, but you still feel that the fact they're even there is what builds this world as just a place that exists and your character happened to be at, which I feel is also kind of the point of the story. Not much to say about it, to be honest, but like everything else about this work of art, it's well thought out and had some, if not a lot of work put into it.

The SOUND is fantastic. Celeste has a lot of music in it, and it always matches the mood of the situation it's played in very well, enhancing it. The sound effects don't fall short either, with footsteps and "climbing sounds" that differ based on what kind of surface your character is on, down to places where you'll probably walk on just once for a second or two in the whole game. All other sounds are fantastically in place as well, not feeling unpleasant to hear or repetitive, especially considering you'll hear some of them A LOT (the dash and the death SFX come to mind).

The looks may catch your eye, the story might make you want to keep going, and the sounds and music may want you to just keep listening to them, but you'll stay for the gameplay. Featuring a very simple system of 8-way dashes, wall jumping and stamina-based wall-climbing, that's all you have in the beginning of the game and is all you'll have all the way until the end. Don't underestimate this, though, as the map itself provides you with creative ways to use those abilities, with everchanging mechanics that are introduced on every new level. The map design is impeccable. I was sure no one could come up with interesting level design for platformers anymore, as they have been around for so long and so many platformers have already come out, but they did it. The feeling of having gotten a little bit better at the game after every screen you manage to platform through is something that games that are also this challenging and fast-paced rarely manage to deliver nowadays. It's also worth mentioning that Celeste has plenty of accessibility options. If the controls feel too limiting or a section is too hard, there are optional toggles that make life easier for those who are having trouble, being introduced without feeling condescending or blocking you from getting achievements which, in my opinion, is great. You can go through the main game and have a lot of fun, but also search in every nook and cranny for secrets that give you more challenging platforming sections, not to mention the "B-Sides", which are much, MUCH harder versions of the levels they mirror. You have to feel it for yourself though, you'll see what I mean when you play it, because you definitely should play it. Just buy the damn game, tell your friends, family, loved ones and everyone else about it. These devs are the real thing, and so is this masterpiece.

39763465.review:
I was a singleplayer gamer all my life, and in the last few years I moved to online multiplayer adventures.

There are many singleplayer titles out there with undeniable quality that I just try to play and can't because they are lacking that online multiplayer component, it's a feeling I can't quite describe, but I become uninterested either halfway or at worst cases, right after a few hours.

This, leaves me kind of sad, as there are many I wish I had time to complete or wanted to complete, but I can't quite do so.

However, I know that when I can climb that mountain and become attached to a singleplayer, to the point I want to do more than finish it, that I want to love it and know all about it, it's because it's really darn good.
Celeste is one of those few games in the recent years for me. 

The story, the visuals, the soundtrack, every little corner and the thought behind it is just tremendous.
Love it or hate it, just go out there and experience it.
