Once again i've been tricked by critics. Just like the game Owlboy it gets universally praised, awards everywhere. Tons of people are talking about how amazing this game is. So I fall for the hype, I buy it. What a mistake that was. Same exact problems once again, bland gameplay. I'd go in to detail but there's no reason to, I could easily describe it with other games, since that's all this game does. Copies other games. So, you ever played games like Super Meat Boy or Slime-San? Ok, so what if there was no changes to that gameplay formula, actually made it worse in the visual and control department and slapped an unnecessary 20 dollar price tag on it? That's Celeste.

EDIT: I have now beaten the game, I still don't get it. There's not a single original thing about this game even right down to the music. The music is honestly the worst offender here. I can deal with bland uninspired gameplay sure, but this music is flat out plagiarism. Many tracks from this game sound like they were heavily inspired by artists like Doseone, Jake Kaufman or Disasterpeace. So much, that i've actually heard journalist websites like Giantbomb for example confuse the music for them. That's gross, just flat out gross. That not a single thing is original about this game in every aspect.

This goes to show how badly people will cling on and hivemind to journalists or youtubers for opinions instead of making their own. Because I can't fathom this many people actually finding an aspect of this game that could be better than the games, art or music that it borrows heavily from. It's as I said at the start of this review, the same experience I saw with Owlboy which I why I compare it.

39761076.review:
I am conflicted about this game, everything about it is beautiful, but my god is it hard.
It could be just me suck at time-strressed-pixel-perfect platformers, but a lot of hard things that makes me want to kill myself is how they started coupling time stress and tight platforming calculations together in the 3rd and 4th chapter onward. 
You have to keep an eye out for everything, in the later stages of each chapter there will always be 3 to 4 obstacle mechanic coming at you at once, and if you fail to handle one of them, start over.

39760310.review:
This game is phenominal. I've played A LOT of 2-D platformer-style games, including popular titles like Hollow Knight, Ori and the Blind Forrest, Super Meat Boy, and nearly every Super Mario game, as well as some smaller, less known indie titles and Celeste is my favorite by a long shot. It's not even close. I know it's not really fair to compare these games because they all do very different things and will appeal to different people individually but for me, Celeaste blows every 2-D platformer out of the water. Hollow knight will appeal to people who prefer combat and boss fights, while Ori will appeal to more people who prefer puzzle solving. The gameplay in Celeste is most similar to Super Meat Boy because it only has very few movement abilities but the game just continues to build on them in brilliant ways which will continue to suprise you in every level.

This game also has a pretty good story, which is something that I didn't expect at all. I don't think the game really needed a story and the devs could have easily made the whole game with no dialougue and no characters but I'm glad they chose to add it because it's really is a nice touch. The characters are likable and the dialogue is well-written.

TL;DR: Mastapeice- 10/10

P.S-  I highly recomend playing this game with a controller over keyboard if you have the option. Keyboard still works fine but has a steeper learning curve in my opinion

Una obra maestra. 

Tanto si eres bueno con los platformers o no, el juego tiene una curva de dificultad extremadamente refinada que asegura que tengas los pelos de punta en cada nivel; y si aún te parece muy difícil, puedes activar el modo de asistencia  permitiéndote usar variedad de "trucos" como dash/stamina ilimitados o saltear secciones del juego.
Si te parecíó muy fácil, cada nivel tiene una "Cara B" que básicamente es una versión hardcore del mismo, usualmente requiriendo mecánicas avanzadas.

Gráficamente los personajes están exquisitamente animados, el estilo visual es atrapante y los niveles están muy bien diseñados.

La música es fenomenal, tiene un toque de melancolía dada la trama, y los instrumentos/tono van cambiando según las secciones de los niveles. Cumple muy bien su rol de mantenerte en el juego después de fallar incontables veces en un nivel complicado.

La historia toca temas como la depresión, ansiedad, y el auto-descubrimiento. Decir más sería spoiler.


En fin, si les ha gustado Super Meat Boy o TowerFall Ascension, o quieres experimentar una joya de los juegos modernos, compra este juego. (o piratéalo, como quieras, sólo deja de perder el tiempo y JUÉGALO)

39755109.review:
TL;DR: This game isn't just about difficult platforming, although it is marketed and popularized as such.

Long version: This is one of the few games I paid full price for soon after release, and I don't regret it. It's a game about overcoming personal challenges, both in gameplay and in story. The difficulty of the game lies not in imprecise controls, like with Human Fall Flat, but with varied and interesting level design. In most games, deaths feel like failure and are portrayed as negative, with Game Over screens and perhaps some blood and gore, or maybe a bit of waiting around for things in the level to move into place. This game treats death differently. The animation for dying is quick, and you respawn quickly. Moving elements in the level are reset so you can immediately start moving again, without having to wait for things to line up. The music in the background doesn't reset, which is important for feeling a sense of continuity. Frequent checkpoints make death less painful, and death becomes an opportunity to practice platforming skills rather than a punishment for sub-par gameplay.

Story-wise, the player character deals with depression, anxiety, panic attacks, and low self-esteem. A character she meets on her way up the mountain copes with the passing on of a loved one and the search for a meaning in existence. Yet another character faces... faces a sort of kodokushi, and the bittersweet feeling of seeing a treasured thing fade from its former glory. He's hard for me to describe, but he is no less realistic than any other character. They all have unique situations that they need to personally handle, and the writing recognizes that. I like this game because it does that, and does it well. Entire chapters or sequences of them are themed around these characters, with their own color palettes, sound design, music, level design, and game mechanics.

If the platforming itself is too difficult, as it likely is for many potential buyers, you can go into Assist Mode and change the game speed, number of air dashes, or invincibility. This changes the game from a difficult platformer to an exploration game, but doesn't trivialize gameplay or level design. Despite the fact that death can be rendered impotent, there are still puzzles that need to be solved in order to progress through a level, switches that must be pressed and collectibles to be found. That is my favorite part of this game; even when one of the central mechanics is removed, this game is still enjoyable. This game can fit into two genres, that of difficult platforming and of leisurely exploration. This duality mirrors the physical and mental representations of the mountain that the characters face in the story, and makes the game accessible for more casual or less able players. This game isn't just about difficult platforming, and I commend it for that.

Thank you for reading my review, and I welcome any criticisms or comments you may have.

39741754.review:
Madeline is climbing a mountain. Why is she climbing the mountain?
To hug the mountain. To envelop that mountain. Why is she climbing the mountain? Because she's in love.

I think this game is my new obsession. We'll have to see, it's only been two days and I've ended up putting things I thought were pretty neat before back on the shelf well before finishing them. But something about Celeste feels really special. Usually games at this difficulty level have me wanting to throw things before too long, grimly bearing my way through challenge after torturous challenge. But somehow, here, I find myself really getting into the "challenge accepted" mindset. Failure doesn't feel like failure, it really feels like learning. Every death leads naturally to introspection on what went wrong, corrective plans to to make it better, and a slightly refined execution. Until eventually, success, exhilarating success! Every time, I really feel like I've overcome something, not just survived it. But the real magic starts happening when you try the level again.

I remember approaching my first B-side with a little bit of dread, I heard they were going to be really hard. They ARE really hard. But at the end of an hour and several hundred deaths, my feeling wasn't "ugh I'm so glad THAT's over" but "holy crap I can't believe I just did that, some of those platforming sections were INSANE!" And then later today I realized I wanted to play it again. It was much easier the second time, still incredibly difficult but now difficulty with familiarity. I could see just how much better I'd gotten at the game for having played through it (and B-side 2 in between, which was thrilling), and all this just in the course of an afternoon and evening! As difficult as Celeste is, it also really wants you to become good at it, because it is so enjoyable to be good at.

Part of this is down to really tight controls. With a limited amount of verbs and a high degree of responsiveness, every death feels like a place where YOU made a mistake and can do better next time. But this really comes through in the Assist Mode, which is basically a built in trainer. The game doesn't want you to feel ashamed of not being good enough, whether just for now or ever, so it doesn't lock any content behind skill, and you can fine tune the assistance to whatever level you need. My wife, who died several times in the prologue section, can and possibly will play through this stupidly difficult game all the way to the end. And even for me, wanting to prove to myself I can surmount any challenge, sometimes it's fun to relax and just explore a level without worrying about dying. In short, this really is the grueling Nintendo-hard platformer that everyone can enjoy.

39740632.review:
A well made, tight platformer with a fantastic story. 

Features 7 stages, each of which will run you maybe one hour each if you're playing normally, though with practice you can easily blow through them in half the time. Each stage has a unique gimmick that keeps gameplay fresh but familiar, and I found the narrative plot to be very compelling.

There's a few collectibles scattered throughout each stage. There's Strawberries, Hearts, and B-Side tapes. The Strawberries are just personal difficulty markers and have no added benefit for the game besides satisfying your pride. There's one Heart in each stage and each one is very hard to obtain. Getting them will unlock a post-game bonus, but it's not required so don't worry too much on your first playthrough. There is also one B-Side tape per stage, and they unlock a harder version of the stage you're on. You can play these from the menu after beating the stage, and each B-Side Stage has a remixed version of the stage theme.

All in all I think the game is well worth the price. Even if I never play it again, I thoroughly enjoyed my time with it and don't feel at all as if I wasn't getting my money's worth. All in all a solid game, and if you enjoyed Super Meat Boy, you might enjoy this game as well.

39739843.review:
Celeste is a 2D retro platformer with great level design, an amazing soundtrack, and beautiful sprite work. It's a challenging game but not to the point of frustration (except the B-side levels but those are optional). 

If you find the game too hard you can enable an assist mode which makes the game easier by slowing everything down, if you on the contrary, find the game too easy there are the absolutely sadistic   B-Side bonus stages that act as alternate versions of the standard levels. You can collect them in-game by beating a challenge room hidden somewhere in the multiple chapters the game offers.  An average play through will last about 8 hours while a completionist run will last somewhere near 20.

If you enjoyed games like Shovel Knight this will be right up your alley.

9/10

Would recommend for the platforming alone, haven't had this much fun with a platformer since Dustforce. The controls feel absolutely wonderful and responsive, and the later levels take full advantage of that. Absolutely wonderful challenge levels in this one.

The visuals and music in this game also left quite an impression on me, and there's quite a variety of both. Some areas are beautiful and serene, others mysterious and imposing. Each area had its own unique feel to it because of this, and the bonus levels feature remixed themes of each level by various artists. 

Story was okay, a lot of people seem to be taken away with it, but it didn't really leave much of an impression on me. Kinda wish I had a little goth version of me floating around, though

I completed all of the achievements at 25 hours, with one last additional challenge I could partake in should I feel the need to torture myself.

39726581.review:
这是一款强到难以形容的平台跳跃游戏，很难想象平台跳跃这一早已在玩家心目中固化为死板印象的类型，也能缔造出如此丰富多彩的体验。

老实说，平台跳跃并非我喜欢的游戏类型，其中很大原因就是，这类游戏里的大多数作品，所赋予的游戏体验都大同小异。像我这样不是那么喜欢挑战的玩家，自然很难对它们产生兴趣。然而《Celeste》却与众不同，在保留了这个游戏类型一贯高难度的同时，还积极加入了很难在同类游戏中看到的新元素，不仅满足了老玩家的喜好，同时对没有或很少玩过这一类型的新玩家来说，也显得颇具新引力。

游戏一共七大关，虽然估计大多数人都能在十小时内通关，但是通关之后可体验的内容，至少也能玩上数十个小时。就算舍弃掉通关后那些难度极高的关卡，游戏的主线流程虽然看似时间不长，但要知道这十个小时可不是像一般的平台跳跃那样，靠大量地复用场景把时间硬生生堆砌上去，关卡与关卡之间仅有场景元素分布位置的不同；而是每一关都会加入几个全新的设计，而这些设计里有很多不仅需要玩家主动与之互动，其互动的方式与触发效果也不尽相同，甚至几个不同的设计组合起来，又能产生全新的解法，极大地增加了场景的丰富程度和玩家的新鲜感。

除却巧妙的游戏设计之外，该游戏还有着精美的像素画面（每一个关卡的画面风都截然不同）、动人的音乐和丰富的故事情节，甚至每一关的末尾还加入了BOSS战斗，这些从其他游戏类中借鉴过来、看似毫不相关的东西，在作者高超严谨的设计之下，被完美地融合到了一起。要将诸多元素打磨到如此融洽的程度，想必作者一定也在背后下了不少苦功。

游戏整体的难度不低，这自然是平台跳跃这一游戏类型的一贯传统。不过，如果仅仅是通关，而不去追求隐藏内容的话，整个游戏体验是非常友好的。游戏死亡复活很快，几秒就能让玩家重新投入战斗；游戏中的自动存档点也非常多，很少有特别长的关卡，玩家的努力不会因为一次死亡轻易白费。在大量繁忙紧张的操作之后，还有暖心的剧情舒缓节奏，所以尽管我通关死了2000次，但神奇地是中途并没有感受到丝毫焦躁的情绪，始终沉浸在一种愉快的氛围中。

我知道，尽管平台跳跃，并不算是很受欢迎的游戏类型，但鉴于以上原因，我衷心地将《Celeste》推荐给所有玩家。

Not much to say aside from what everyone else is already saying in the reviews, so I'll just post a quick summary and thoughts:

- Great smooth gameplay and controls.
- Great level design with new mechanics popping up often. Many rooms almost feel like puzzles, sort of like a more fast paced 2D-portal.
- Soundtrack is an excellent blend of mellow piano tunes and fast paced synthwave-ish bit tunes depending on the mood the game tries to set.
- One of the best "boss fights" in a long time.
- Srorywise it blew me away. It was the first time a pixel art platformer has actually made me care about its characters and actually managed to tell a deep story about emotions and depression.
- Lots of content/extras/collectibles to enyoj after completing the main story.

All in all, if you like video games in general, you should have no problem settling in with this one.

39720273.review:
What an absolutely beautiful game, both in gameplay and scenery.

There's been a terrifying indie trend lately of hardcore 2D platformers that nobody except for grisled platformer veterans can get into. Celeste is the first difficult 2D platformer with great accessibility options that honestly should be an indistry standard from this point on.

Aside from that, the game excels in almost every category. The chiptune/piano music can be beautiful and a banger at the same time. The gameplay is simple, but continues to teach you new techniques up until the final stage. Every chapter is varied in both gameplay and scenery, with several gimmicks to keep you on your toes as you traverse the stage.

I can recommend this game to you even if you're not the best platformer player, as the story itself is very positive and uplifting, and is worth the challenge to experience.

39716844.review:
I don't play hard games.  I tried Dark Souls a few times, but kept getting dead by the big dude in the first room, or whatever.  I love games, have been playing them all my life - but I'm complete rubbish at them.

At first I dismissed Celeste along the lines of other super-hard pixelart platformers, but the reviews convinced me it was something worth experiencing.

So now I'm four worlds in, and loving it.  I'm even loving the challenge, and haven't bothered to use the assist mode once.  I'm happy to persist (and die hundreds of times each chapter) until I get it right.  The assist mode is a generous inclusion that I fully support, and I may yet use it.  The generous checkpointing also indicates, to me at least, that this is not a game that's hard for the sake of being hard - it's hard with the intent of building up your skills and rewarding your progress, not punishing your mistakes.

Worth the moneys.

Ok llevo 2 horas de este juegos, 3 capitulos, un lado b, y puedo decir que estamos ante uno de los mejores plataformeros en 2d del año.
Graficamente es un pixel art no hay mucho que decir, solo que los personajes son buenisimos y muy entrañables.
En cuanto a la banda sonora es un autentico deleite, las compocisiones son adecuadas en cada escenario, no cansan y son preciosas, dejo lo mejor para el final.
Mecanicamente hablando es perfecto, tienes 2 mecanicas simples un dash a cualquier dirección y un agarre a superficies con una mecanica de cansacio tipo shadow of the colossus, y no necesitas nada mas, cada escenario tiene algo diferente plataformas que afectan tu momentum, paredes de las que no te puedes volver a agarrar, dashes extra, etc. El juego es desafiante sin necesidad de ser ricidulo o injusto, cuando mueres no sientes que sea por un mal diseño de niveles simplemente erraste algo, y para agregar estan los lados B de cada escenario los cuales son un reto difisilisimo solo recomendados para cuando dominaste la mecanica basica, no puedo esperar como los speedrunners haran magia con este juego.
Buen diseño, hermosa musica, gameplay perfecto, y es una absoluta ganga, recomiendo ampliamente este juego, si estas leyendo esto no se porque lo haces solo compralo y disfruta del viaje que esta joya ofrece.

39711724.review:
Hello Everyone, My Name is Ange and this is my first ever review. Today I will be reviewing Celeste, let’s get to it.

This game kept its promise. By providing the upmost of challenges after playing games like Super Meat Boy, Celeste felt more like it and I was able to get to the controls with ease. Plus, they are rather simplistic, which makes it easier to play, but for some people, hard to master.

The game is for mixed players in my opinion , which means it has some beginner elements, but as the game progresses, it deffinetly gives you a punch in the chest if you fell or you perished like the million of users playing this addicting game. It is however the magic of learning after each and every death you have, that gives he most satisfaction after completing a section or an entire level, The game doesn’t seek to punish you, at least in its base storyline level. But it does a great job teaching and refining things like strafe jumping and precise timing, reflexes and to analyze. 

Not to mention, I can’t begin how to describe the soundtrack. It is honestly the best thing I’ve heard since ages. from calm classic piano, romantic guitar and chill-thrilling intense retro music that makes your heart bump the second you hear them. Of course depending on the dialogue, the game pushes it soundtrack to the dark side or with the piano, giving it a creepy aspect with feels that of a visual novel. Truly the best thing about Celeste, without a doubt.

The game, it is definitely fun for everyone, especially those who love platformers, here’s why. The game provides a balanced amount of challenges, starting from the main story path, to optionally set yourself on a detour apart from the main story levels with the purpose of collecting Strawberries and unlocking secrets.

The game really surprised me in its mechanics and the storyline, it was written so well, I got deep feelings when I reached certain parts because of how beautiful and how it’s hidden meaning lies within the purpose of the climb. It is quite the pack over the hundreds and hundreds of levels this game has and its great level designs. It was consistent, and it pushed me to not only do better in the game, but to find out about the ending, not giving up in each Chapter. I enjoy every second playing this game. You can also replay chapters in the many different scenes to easily advance through your favorite levels.

When I first saw the game trailer back in December, I knew this game was going to be hard, but I did not know how great the story, characters and more like the ambiance and level designs was going to be like. it was not hard, it was Satisfyingly difficult. I love how the game developer in one of the postcards about the Death Counter, he tells you to be proud of it. but I realized that I had underestimated him and that I was wrong. Since you respawn quickly, you wont have a hard time trying to apply what you learned from your previous mistake, whether it is at midway, at end, or merely at the beginning of a Chapter, you don’t lose progress either thanks to the handy Auto-Save Feature within the game. I was also surprised me with the boss fights. I thought these were going to be simple, but they were challenging, and I like that. if you know your peripherals and know your reflexes, you’ll be okay. However, sometimes it takes A single frame to mess up if not timed correctly.

I love the moral of this story and it’s lesson. This game.. funnily enough.. this game taught me how to breathe. To not let my anxiety or my desperation by all means not get to my head, and to think straight, to keep my cool. And to think that I can make it, to set a determined goal.

I love the personality of the characters, even one of them had a Pop Culture personality and I’d say Madeline is pretty much relatable with most teenagers. Another character had me searching up the definitions of words because I wouldn’t understand their philosophy, but once I did search up the words, I understood clearly what they meant and followed up with the story. 

I invested around 10 hours to beat the game, and despite my timespan, It is honestly quite impressive of me making through. I had also finished it with a total of 63 Strawberries and more than 1465 deaths using a DualShock 4 Controller. Honestly, for being my first run, I was really proud of that, however, my journey doesn’t end there, I still have yet to make it through the B-Sides. And the Infamous C-Sides which are much harder than the original versions of the levels.

So, as for Ratings, this game by far.. the best indie game I’ve played, it is a masterpiece for its story, soundtrack and overwhelming level designs. So what do you think? Go Reach the Peak of the Mountain! 

10/10.

39708519.review:
[h1]Graphics[/h1]
The game mixes pixel art gameplay with a 3D map menu and comic-style UI elements. That may sound weird but it works very well in practice. All of it looks nice and manages to fit together.

[h1]Music and sound design[/h1]
The music is simply amazing and I would really suggest buying the soundtrack on bandcamp. The sounds are satisfying and never get annoying. I also love the voices of the characters.

[h1]Story[/h1]
It's interesting, emotional and integrated perfectly into the gameplay. The characters are likeable and they all feel natural.

[h1]Controls[/h1]
Tight and responsive. Very simple yet effective. Haven't had any problems with them myself, no death felt like the controls were at fault. I've been playing with keyboard. I did rebind almost all the buttons immediately because the default layout seemed weird to me.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
The levels are very fun and well-designed. They can get pretty challenging later on but they are always fair. The different gimmicks of every area are creative and interesting.
The difficulty of the late-game content is very high but there is an assist mode for players who want to have it easier.
About the length of the game: There are 8 chapters and it should take the average player about 8 hours to complete these (the main storyline). However, every chapter also has about 20-40 collectible strawberries and each one offers a small extra challenge or puzzle to complete. There is also something called a "B-Side" for every chapter. An unlockable set of more difficult levels that usually takes quite a bit longer to complete than the A-Side. There are some other extra challenges and collectibles as well (I won't spoil them) which probably brings the overall time you can get out of this game to 18+ hours (not including the ridiculously hard to get golden strawberries). I myself acquired all the achievements within 22 hours.

[h1]Minor complaints[/h1]
One aspect I don't like is that using assist mode doesn't disable achievements, though that is just my personal opinion.
Some may not enjoy having to redo chapters or parts of them to collect everything they missed the first time through. I don't mind this that much personally because that's just how it is if you wanna collect everything in a game.
The boosted wall jump is not explained very well but the devs also acknowledged this and apparently plan on improving it.
Other than that, there are a few bugs and crashes here and there as with every game but they are minor and uncommon.

[h1]Overall[/h1]
Definitely an amazing game and I can only recommend it, especially if you're a fan of these kinds of games. Celeste has quickly become one of my all-time favorites.

39708269.review: This game is beautiful and addicting. I might suck, but I can't get enough.

39708217.review:
Celeste is amazing! If you're a fan of difficult platformers then I cannot recommend it enough. It features:
1) Awesome level design (very pretty, but also fun and challenging)
2) Really tight controls 
3) A high skill-cap (there's a LOT of movement tech that you learn as you play)
4) A nice soundtrack 
5) A TON of extra challenges available for those who want them. The main storyline took about 6 hours for me to get through, and at the time I thought I had collected most of the extra stuff (about 140/175 strawberries). Turns out I wasn't even close to clearing all the content. There's a bunch of extra levels with harder and harder challenges.

A couple downsides:
1) To unlock the coolest stuff you have to do a bunch of exploring and solve some riddles. I was pretty uninterested in this, so I just looked it all up online. It took maybe 30 mins or an hour to go through it, which was kind of annoying.
2) There's some pretty bad screen shake. It makes sense to have the screen shake a little to emphasize big moments, but this game goes overboard. Especially for the green crystals that recharge your jump. It can get really disorienting and cause some frustrating deaths.

Overall: This is my favorite game in years. Easy 10/10.

39706967.review:
Really fun platformer that doesn't focus so much on precision timing as it does momentum, and figuring out how to use your abilities and the mechanics of the stage to your advantage. It might be my favorite platformer ever, and it is incredibly fun once you get the hang of the controls. The main game actually isn't very long, but if you're trying to get all the collectibles, find secrets, and do all of the optional extra-difficult stages, it becomes much longer, and then how long it will take you is pretty dependent on your skill level as well. Besides just how much fun it is, the environments looks beautiful, the soundtrack is great, and surprisingly there is some amount of story to it, although that's not the main drive for playing the game.
If you like platforming at all, I highly recommend this

39700183.review:
Great game.

Music's really nice, the momentum of the character is excellent, it's very finely tuned for the type of platforming they're attempting to cultivate here. I'm especially pleased with how many little tweaks to the way you're supposed to platform there are throughout the game, forcing you to consider and think and learn as you go.

The story itself is a little less good than the platforming, but is still great. It actually has a bit of a parallel with Silent Hill 2, minus the evil cult energies and whatnot. The hero is called to a mystical place where they are tormented by a manifestation of their inner demons and must look inward to ultimately confront and defeat them. Of course, Celeste is much more light-hearted than Silent Hill. [spoiler] Without wishing to spoil, it's a tale about depression and the main character's decision to defeat it. As someone who suffers from depression, I don't agree with this interpretation, but I'm sure someone else who suffers from depression might. Not everyone experiences it the same.[/spoiler]

Having the wall-grab mechanic tied to the right trigger was a little annoying to me, kinda hurt my hand, although not sure how else I would have done it. I didn't collect all of the strawberries, myself, those started getting very overwhelmingly difficult to figure out so I ended up just abandoning that side-quest entirely at some point. I'll probably go back and do it at some point.

I beat the game in one sitting and my hands are really aching now, so I'm just gonna say this was a 9/10 and be done with it.

39699420.review:
Celeste is an incredibly good platformer, and if you are even remotely considering buying it: Just do. If you are anything like myself you spend the time going through reviews and whatnot and trying to determine if it it's worth it. I did the exact same with this game and let me tell you, the $20 was VERY well spent. I'm 23 hours in as of writing this review, and have completed the main game and 170/175 strawberries (little mini-challenges within the levels, I'm sure you know how that works.) and am currently going through the b-sides (challenges unlocked by finding cassette tapes within each level, which grants a second level, called a b-side, that's almost 5 times as difficult as the original level. These levels are based purely on getting through, and there are no strawberries, but they are still incredibly difficult) For a platformer, this game has a surprising amount of content in it, and it controls so smoothly that I can't logically not recommend it to anyone who likes platformers. And even if you DON'T typically like platformers, I still recommend this game. I'm in the same boat of usually not liking platformers, but after seeing dunkey's review I decided to pick it up. This is one of the first platformers I've ever played (Super mario games in my childhood make up all the rest) and I still fell in love with it, although I've been unable to appreciate any platformer before it. Definitely going down as one of my favorite games. The only downsides to it I've found were mechanics within chapters 4, 5, and 6 (out of 7 total, with 1 bonus, and b-sides for all of them) which were wind, annoying chase enemies, and an annoying block mechanic, respectively. But even with these mechanics which I didn't enjoy all that much, I still enjoyed the chapters, and will still remember the whole game fondly.

TL;DR
-"It's good" - person who doesn't usually like platformers
-"It's good" - Dunkey
-"It's good" - Pretty much everyone with a brain except that one dude in the reviews who was hella salty that it was some feminist sjw bullshit, and spent $20 just to say that. (spoiler alert: It's not)
Update: as of posting this review there are 285 reviews, of which only one is negative, and it's the dude I just mentioned

39698004.review:
[b]How the hell are games getting so good these days[/b]
Seriously, this platformer is not what it seems at first glance 

----

Amidst the incredible level design and tight controls there exists an unbelievably profound commentary on self discovery and depression, which is honestly unheard of within a 2d platformer. I hesitate to say whether the gameplay or the story is the highlight here, because the two are so inseperable that it's hard to tell which compels me to keep climbing the most.

To clarify, that's a good thing, because on their own both elements have struck an amazing balance. This game is all about dying until you get it right, which might be offputting for some but rest assured there is a distinct lack of frustration attached to this game. Each level has this difficulty ramp-up within the individual chapters, culminating in a very steady difficulty curve leading up to the final level's big finale. It feels very natural, but you're still going to die a lot.

And if the base game wasn't enough for you, there are also hard mode versions of every major chapter which seriously put your skills to the test in a completely remixed version of the vanilla map - without all of the collectibles (thank god).

Music is a 10/10 - it does exactly what it needs to do and then some

Sound design is a 10/10 - Nothing sounds out of place and all of it is unique from level to level

Gameplay is a 9/10 - Lowest score here - only because of a couple non-intuitive aspects of character movement which don't become apparent until very late game. Extremely solid other than a few minor gripes of mine

Artstyle is wonderful. You'll be drawn in by the uniqueness of every level.

Story is, surprisingly, wonderful. No number value because it's hard for me to rate in that way. You'll either adore the characters and relate heavily to the main character's struggles, or not.

Conclusion?
[b]Buy this sh*t[/b]

39697831.review:
Comprei esse jogo esperando um clone ou um sucessor espiritual de Ice Climbers (mesma temática de escalar montanhas etc), mas eu estava felizmente enganado.
[list]
[*][b]Jogabilidade:[/b] Os controles são simples, fáceis de aprender e bem precisos. Seus movimentos mais complexos e que você usará ao longo do jogo inteiro são dois: um dash que pode ser usado na terra ou no ar, e uma escalada similar àquela presente em The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild, onde voce pode escalar quase qualquer superfície com seu único limite sendo sua "stamina" que você recupera sempre que encosta no chão. Esses comandos simples e práticos serão os mesmos ao longo do jogo inteiro, onde em vez de você desbloquear movimentos novos ao longo da jornada, cada capítulo tem objetos ou mecânicas novos e únicos, fazendo que o jogo nunca fique repetitivo ou entediante.

[*][b]Visuais:[/b] Visualmente falando, o jogo faz um ótimo trabalho, mantendo um belo estilo pixelizado, onde a informação é representada de forma clara e limpa. Para saber se você pode usar seu dash, por exemplo, basta você dar uma rápida olhada no cabelo da sua personagem, que alterna de cor entre vermelho e azul dependendo se ele está carregado ou não; partículas de vento representam em que direção ou qual é a força dele, entre outras coisas. Todos esses pequenos detalhes tornam sua experiência de jogo muito mais gratificante.

[*][b]História:[/b] Celeste me surpreendeu com sua história simples mas que te prende, fazendo com que você torça pelo sucesso de seus personagens principais. Ela é bem distribuída ao longo do jogo, onde, além de você se focar para passar pelos desafios de plataforma, você também fica ansioso para a próxima vez que vai encontrar aquele personagem importante ou um diálogo interessante. Observando a jornada de Madeline para tentar se entender, eu acabei descobrindo coisas sobre mim mesmo, que eu nunca teria imaginado antes.

[*][b]Trilha Sonora:[/b] As músicas de Celeste são sutis e cheias de charme, e completam a atmosfera montanhosa e calma que os visuais do jogo proporcionam. Cada capítulo tem duas músicas: uma para o modo normal, e a outra (uma versão remixada da original) para os chamados B-Sides (o modo difícil da fase), e ambas são muito bem feitas e encaixam perfeitamente no jogo.
[/list]

[b]Resumo:[/b] Celeste é um jogo que realmente superou minhas expectativas, e que parece ser mais simples e bobo do que ele realmente é. O charme de sua história, os visuais e as músicas gratificantes, e uma jogabilidade precisa e flúida, fazem com que Celeste seja um jogo quase obrigatório nas bibliotecas dos fãs do gênero de plataforma.

39697512.review: I don't usually like difficult games, but this one was so fun that I couldn't stop playing until I beat it. 39697475.review:
Celeste is a wonderful platformer with a suprisingly relevent and powerful story. The levels are designed with the mario philosophy of introducing mechanics in each chapter, slowley building off of it with more creative and unique twists, then discarding it to be replaced with the next chapters gimmick, keeping the whole game fun and interesting. not once was I bored when playing the main story of celeste, and also when doing the post game content. The main stages have brilliantly designed challenges, focusing on creativly using your moveset, instead of cheap pixel perfect jumps. The stages are a lot of really tiny rooms that are connected to form the chapter. you will never loose a large amount of progress when dying, so it encurages risky play, and experimentation. the game even reminds you in one of the loading screens to be proud of your death count, because everytime you die, you learn somethign new. The game is also very long, with 7 chapters, a bonus chapter, bonus "B sides" of every chapter, including the bonus chapter (kinda like dark levels), as well as over 100 strawberries to collect by doing bonus challenges in hidden rooms, as well as crystal hearts in every chapter that were a joy finding. not only that, there are also the super secret "C side" chapters that I have heard are incredibly challenging. 

Celeste is one of the best games in the genre, with very few flaws (I wouldn't be able to name any). anyone who likes platformers should get this game, and will be more than satisfied with the amount of content you will recieve for only 20 dollars. If you plan on 100% the game, expect about 20 hours of content if you are good at platformers, and an extra 10 hours if you arn't good at platformers.

39694791.review:
I've always loved the idea of the platformer genre, but it's rare when a game comes along that's streamlined enough to prevent frustration and full of interesting, fresh ideas. Celeste is one of those games.

This game is absolutely fantastic.

+Art, music/sfx, and even the writing are all spectacular, and set a new bar for modern platformers imo.
+The physics and mechanics always feel tight and within your control. Dying is always your fault, not the games. Feels even better to me than Meat Boy.
+Feels like a "Best Of" of what a platformer can do with air dashes, wall jumps, and climbing as traversal.
+Assist Mode's accessibility tweaks let you customize the difficulty and opens up the game to players of all sorts of experience. 

-Have a few moments where, for a bit, I don't know where to go to proceed story
-If you like more chill platformers and are nervous/skittish about mid-air decision-making and mid-air changes in direction, the Assist Mode options might not be enough to make this your kind of thing.

If you love platformers, play it. If you love platformers but have been intimidated by games like Super Meat Boy and The End is Nigh, put on the Assist Mode and play it. I think you'll love the experience.

Sure, it can be pretty grueling at times, but most of the crazy hard stuff is a little taunting optional collectible. Not only that, but even with levels that make you rack up hundreds of deaths in half-hours, there is no frustration. Every little step isn't only a step towards the muscle memory to clear it, but also to figure out how to route through the level. The stage design was truly phenomenal.

A must-play for fans of indie platformers, I'd place it with the giants like SMB and Cave Story anyday.

I pirated the game with 2 friends to give it a try, since it was really eye-catching, I heard it had great music and it was an indie (I'm a huge indie lover). 
The first two chapters were really cool, with awesome mechanics and fair but challenging puzzles. When I got to the third chapter, my friends were struggling really bad with the second chapter; one of them finished it in 45 minutes, mostly because of the unforgiving boss. We got a 90-95 death count for each chapter, though.
When I got to the third chapter, my death count skyrocketed to 687, and I completed it in almost 2 hours; all thanks to a single strawberry.
Just as I finished the chapter, alongside one of my friends, we automatically closed the game to rest our poor brains. I had to buy the game just because of pure anger, write a tweet to the game dev telling him how much I love his game and I hope it gets the GOTY Award, with a nice "F*ck you" at the end. I felt so exhausted after that nightmare, that I had to have a sad fap and go to sleep. All three of us loved the game and my friends are going to buy the game as soon as they can.

Final thoughts: I love the mechanics (specially the one in the second chapter), I love the music, I love the tight controls, I love the pixel art, I LOVE this game. If you want to have PTSD towards strawberries, buy this game. (A controller is MANDATORY)

10/10 Would chop my d*ck off and gouge my eyeballs with a fork again.

39688429.review:
An excellent masocore platformer with a fantastic soundtrack. The balance of difficulty here is world class. The game maintains a steady climb of challenge without ever being so difficult as to lead to frustration. Strawberries serve as a tasty carrot on the stick to take on the game's more devious challenges, while the hidden B-Side worlds offer a true test of skill; and even beefier soundtracks. 

If this weren't all enough, Level 6: Reflection is a masterpiece. I've never had story infuse itself so deeply into the platforming in a game of this genre before, culminated by the best boss battle I've ever played in a platformer, backed by the best chiptune I've ever heard, finally topped by the most meaningful XP Level up I've ever experienced in a game. 39687619.review:
Not even exagerrating here. This is the best $21.99 CAD I have ever spent! What a fantastic game!

The story is surprisingly good for what is present. The dialogue is well written and clever. But we all know, story isn't why you'd buy a game like this.

The platforming is very polished and smooth. The movement and reactions are instantaneous. The level design is perfect out of 10. There are enough levels to compliment every skill level from the most casual player to the most hardcore masochist.

Having just finished clearing 100% of the game, every achievement, every collectible, every secret, and clearing every stage, I am genuinely impressed! My thumbs are a little tender from 2 or 3 of those levels, but it was definitely time well spent.

I am so impressed with this game! If the developers make any more like it, I'll be keeping a close eye from now on.

Music: 9.5 / 10 (only topped by Undertale and some classic RPGs)
-The music is original and nostalgic, superb composition skills and theme matching for making it blend in with the game in every area.

Sound Effects: 9 / 10 Crisp and high quality, some are even very nostalgically recognizable. You better get accustomed to that death sound though, because it's loud and it will be happening a lot!

Art: 9.5 / 10 Almost as good as it gets for 2D spriting and animations. The stages, backgrounds, UI and dialogues/portraits are all perfectly suitable for this game, the only thing I would nitpick on is the people sprites, including your character (not the portrait, the sprite you control). I'd like to see a little more detail in the character I'm controlling, while playing. The special effects are very modern and expertly executed.

Difficulty: 9.8 / 10 Keeping in mind it doesn't have to get this difficult, in fact I'd say just beating the main story levels casually would rank around a 4.5 / 10 difficulty, but should you want to complete every stage and collect every item / achievement, this is what the difficulty would be rated.

Gameplay: 10 / 10 Polished, clean, responsive, nothing short of perfect. Every death is your own fault and a learning experience to improve your inputs the next time around. Constantly trains you.

Replayability: 6 / 10 Once you beat it, there aren't very many reasons in-game competitively to keep you playing, since it is single player and the only global scores kept are deaths and strawberries collected, but these are measured as "Steam Global" and not best records or anything. It has some replayability as this game is a perfect candidate for speed running. Provides speedrun clock timers in-game and everything! Also a good game to race your friends in, as deaths are pretty much guaranteed unless you're some inhuman TAS bot or need to get a life!

[b]Overall Rating: 8.96 / 10[/b]

Haha, well thanks for reading. Trust me if you are into fun platformers with tight controls, this game is worth every single penny! Had I known what was in store when I was going to buy it, I would pay up to $34.99 CAD for it, easily. I very rarely buy games when they're not on sale but this one called out to me. I couldn't resist!

Would recommend buying! 8.96 out of 10! Will play again!

39678079.review:
Calling Celeste a good game wouldn't do it justice. It's a beautiful game, a masterpiece, true work of passion. 

It's a great achievement to get so much out of such minimalistic design. Celeste is full of surprises, it has pretty low entry point and it builds up new ways to use it's dashing mechanic till the very end. Levels are wonderfuly paced and they ramp up the challenge but I never felt like it got suddenly "too hard". Even the hard sequences were fun to play and repeat  since I felt like a ninja master when I finally finished them. 

Level design is outstanding - there are always few ways to traverse the screen , even if new mechanics can feel awkward at first (looking at you - feather) but after few screens you're natural at using them. If you want more challenge you can search for hidden or hard to reach strawberries. I didn't get most of them in my first run, so now after finishing the game I'm doing a second one to collect all of them. There are tons of secrets and collectibles - my first run took me about 9 hours to complete, I bet you can squeeze additional 20 or more if you want to collect all strawberries, B-side tapes (unlocking harder versions of levels in chapters) and finishing those, which unlock extra epilogue chapter. 

The art is vibrant and full of character. Chapters varry visually in interesting ways. Everything is readible and works well in this fast paced game. All acompanied with beautiful music - with unusual composition of chiptune and life piano, and outstanding sound design. 

Story was the biggest surprise to me. I didn't expect such engaging and heartfelt story in a simple platformer about climbing a mountain. I cared about the characters and the mountain is an intriguing place to visit. It's by far not a regular  mountain. Story is very nicely fit together with gameplay, there were few "WOW" moments when I played created with very clever and out of the box thinking. 

I've waited a long time for this one (ever since playing the original PICO-8 version) and I had high expectations, and yet Celeste was able to blow me away. I can't recommend it high enough! It's by far the best game I've played in years.

39677523.review:
先给意见；质量很高的硬核平台类游戏，如果你喜欢这个类别的游戏，这个游戏绝对值得一玩。

一开始只看了宣传片是不信的，后来看过前十分钟游戏体验的视频，就冲着 OST 决定玩一玩，最终也没有让我失望。IGN 上来给了个 10 分，尽管 IGN 的分数现在怎么看都跟随便给的似的，但对于独立游戏中，该作品的确颇有质量，无论是关卡设计，游戏配乐和剧情上都有可圈可点的地方，评分本来就是很主观的东西，IGN 给个 10 分，我觉得这游戏的素质还是配得上的。

接下来说一说游戏的各个方面。首先是关卡设计和难度方面，偏硬核的游戏也会在设计上尽可能的避免玩家的挫败感，以提升玩家的游戏体验，而实际做法就是存档机制。类似 The End is Nigh ，该游戏也是以玩家完成某一段小关卡（或者叫房间）后存档，故玩家不必要担心关卡整体难度影响游戏体验。另外，作为整个游戏中较为困难的部分，收集草莓和 B 面以及隐藏要素均是可选的，若是玩家只想要体验正常关卡，游戏的整体难度大概仅仅比 Ori and the Blind Forest 高一点点。不过不必担心，[i]你能做到[/i]。

关卡设计则是很巧妙的，除了序章的教学外，新元素的引入都由玩家自行熟悉，且玩家也可以很快的掌握新的“玩法”。操作方式，由于玩家在不断的尝试中愈加的熟悉，主角行进过程也行云流水般越来越流畅，带来了很“爽”的体验。另外，对于可以连续操作的（甚至玩家脚都不需要落地的）关卡部分，也设计了容错，不至于失手之后导致整个体验被打断。

剧情方面，[spoiler]讲述了主角为了帮助自己度过抑郁，调整心情而选择爬山，并于意识中代表着自己负面情绪的“另一个自己”斗争，最终克服困难走向山顶的故事[/spoiler]。剧情交代了关卡中的阻碍的成因，主角登山的目的等，对不同角色的刻画也很鲜明。对于一贯喜欢省略剧情的硬核平台游戏而言，剧情可以说是不错的加分项。[strike]难得一个剧情不需要寄刀片的游戏。[/strike]

关卡配乐也是该作品很值得称道的地方（毕竟本来没打算玩，后来冲着OST买了），对于关卡和剧情进行，配乐的配合也恰到好处。例如旅店整理房间处三次整理的三段配乐的变化，又如终章从山底到山顶的多段配乐，都经过了精心的设计。

画面就不再评价了，像素风一向是有人爱有人恨的，若从场景方面来讲，该作的画面也绝对可以说是精美了。另外提一下操作，很主观的讲，我觉得键盘操作实在别扭，总是搞混x和c的功能，手柄则好很多，尽管一开始也不习惯。另外，如果你要使用手柄，确保你的左摇杆的侧向（↖↗↙↘）灵敏，不然有部分关卡会相当难受。

所以结论是：我推荐这个游戏。

-----------

 - OST 在 Bandcamp ，B 面也有。
 - 隐藏还是很多的，全收集大概会很有挑战性而且很有趣。
 - 参考游戏时长：7 h （不刻意收集隐藏，仅常规关卡从序章到尾声）
 - [url=https://steamcommunity.com/app/504230/discussions/0/1692659769950747099/?ctp=2#c1692659769952352182]帮助模式是可以解锁成就的[/url]。
 - [strike]人生短暂，别碰 B 面。[/strike]
 - [spoiler][strike]人生短暂，别碰 C 面。[/strike][/spoiler]

39675196.review:
I was skeptical at first, but fell in love.

The game had literally just released, but I saw a promising youtube video (and we have all been burned by pre-order / early purchse deals before) and made the purchase.

tl;dr: This game has a feel-good & touching story that was excellently executed. The characters are loveable and very life-like. Platforming is super fluid, each chapter introduces a unique mechanic, and there are optional hardcore challenges for people who like to be tortured. 10/10.

Review made with avoiding spoilers in mind! If anything, i may have left vague hints here and there (to maybe peak your interest i hope)

---Game duration breakdown---
Main story: ~4hours for me (I spent a great deal of time hunting 140/175 strawberries while doing the main story)
Collecting Crystal Hearts/175 Strawberries/Red Hearts: 10 hours
Finishing the rest of the game that unlocked after collecting all Red Hearts (Yes, there is more than just B-side as you'll soon discover): 12 hours 51minutes
----------------------------------

:::::::::: Game mechanics
As many will note, this game is akin to other hardcore platformers like Wings of Vi and Momodora.

Let me first break the connection by stating: Celeste has no attacking/fighting (Unless you count running into/occasional goomba stomping).

This leads to a much less complex game as you don't have to constantly worry about optimal damage output while dodging & platforming. They make up for this lack of complexity by adding in a unqiue mechanic for each chapter (ex: A feather to allow you to fly). In the main story, I found myself not really being challenged all too often. It wasn't until I attempted B-side version of each chapter that things became challegning and fun. After you complete all B-side versions, you see another side (see what i did there?) of the chapter that is even harder! This final version of the chapters was beyond my expectations, it was challenging and "fresh". By that I mean, the developers were teaching you new mechanics for the game up until the very end ... Imagine playing Super Mario and beating it, but then discovering Kaizo levels and learning how to shell jump --- not a new mechanic, just something difficult you've never needed to do before, but now you're doing it over and over again to beat the challenge stages!

Because B-side and the final version are all optional to the game's story. A novice player can enjoy the main story without being pressured to play the challenging levels, while those seeking torment (like me) can pursue the challenge stages. This opens Celeste up to players of all skill levels.

:::::::::: Story + Characters
The characters and the main story development kept me going even though the main story wasn't difficult because they were so well executed. The characters felt alive, they had feelings, they had dreams, they were relatable and someone you could connect to/understand. Not to mention, the way the characters talked (squeaking/squeals) was a very cute touch. Character development was well executed; as you climbed up the mountain you learn more about your character and their ambitions. You learn about a dark past (which btw, would have loved to learn more about the person on the other end of the phone call in chapter 2), about this mysterious mountain's powers, and your traveling buddy Theo.

:::::::::: Soundtrack
I love music. This game has realllly great tunes. If I had only 3 words to describe the BGM in this game it'd be: REPEAT PLEASE, THANKS.

:::::::::: Overall
I would have loved for this game to include some more complexity like how Wings of Vi had Flutter or Dash... not to mention you have to attack while platforming. Or Momodora which involved taking advantages of your two different forms to best manuver around the platforms... and attack as well! But Celeste made up for the lack of combat with an amazing story and implementation of unique mechanics within each chapter. 

Definitely would recommend this game to novice, expert, and daring platform gamers --- 10/10

39674448.review:
This game is everything I want in a platformer. It's hard as balls, has a beautiful retro style, incredible music, a cute and fairly meaningful story, and more secrets than you can shake a stick at. While your character is basically only equipped with the ability to hold onto and climb walls - though not forever; you've got a hidden stamina bar - and an airdash that recharges when you touch the ground, the various mechanics with which you'll interact throughout the game will keep your jaw on the floor the whole way through.

I can't stress enough how good this game is. If you're a fan of difficult platformers in which you'll die hundreds (and thousands) of times before finishing them, this game is for you. That said, the game does an amazing job of introducing mechanics and teaching you the ropes, and there is an assist mode which allows you to modify the game parameters and explore the mountain at your own pace.

I'd gush more, but that takes away from time I could be playing the game. See you at the summit.

39674382.review:
This game is absolutely stunning. I saw a clip of it on YouTube, and immediately bought this game.

[b]Graphics[/b]

The graphics for this game are delightful. They're simple, yet have so much hidden detail in them. Nothing seems forced, and anything that has an icon is a clear, directional hint to something important you need to know. Even the hidden areas aren't THAT hidden once you look closely. The overall atmosphere is unique with each level, and is such an incredible thing to experience.

[b]Soundtrack[/b]

The music for this game is impeccable. It boosts your drive to continue exploring, and even changes subtly when entering hidden areas. It doesn't overpower what you're doing or serve as a distraction, but rather helps you get into the rhythm of the level you're facing. Having B-Side levels include remixes of songs was an incredible decision as well, and just adds to the incredible soundtrack.

[b]Gameplay[/b]

The controls for this game are very tight and responsive. The momentum is just right, and it truly feels like your character is doing what you ask it to. The tutorial is simple and interactive, and makes you feel like you already knew what to do before even entering it. Each level has its own unique mechanics, and does an excellent job of introducing each one.
Everything feels very refined and intuitive.

[b]Difficulty[/b]

You are going to die. A LOT. Be well prepared for this. The difficulty factor is a gradual climb, but boy does it climb. By the end of the game, you are doing some very complex and precise maneuvers, and they can be very tough. The B-Side levels are extremely punishing. If you've played any other platformers that are "iconic" for being extremely hard or punishing, then B-Sides will make you feel right at home. That being said, at no point did I ever blame the game for what happened. There weren't any issues with hitboxes or non-responsive controls, it was always 100% me that was messing up. This game gets hard, but the reward is so worth it.

[b]Final Opinion[/b]

This game is absolutely incredible. The story finishes quicker than I had expected, but still allows an immense world to explore. Can you blow through this game in a few hours? Absolutely. Can you 100% it? Eventually, but it's going to take a lot of time. Put away the guides for this one, because the rush of discovering things on your own is going to be your biggest motivating factor in this game. Love what it has to offer, and embrace the natural challenge that comes with it.

It's also pretty damn challenging, but the difficulty curve goes up smoothly, and the more challening content is optional, so it's not too punishing for less experienced players. Beware, though, the optional levels are REALLY challenging, and will test even the most experienced players. And yet, even though you'll probably die hundreds of times on them, they never feel unfair.

Did I also mention that the soundtrack is amazing, and the story is also pretty cool?

It has something for everyone, and you should definitely play it.

Is it well made? - No doubt
Is it worth the money? - I would say yes
Strong points about the game? - Controls and difficulty
Do you need patience? - Definetly
Feeling after finishing this?  - Indescribable 

But honestly, when I finished it it was like a mix of "my fingers hurt", "oh my god I made it" and "this was so cool" sort of feeling.

The story is enjoyable even though it doesn't go anywhere far, because it doesn't even have to, this game is about gameplay.
There is this sweet pixelated charm to graphics for how it looks and fitting sounds/music going along with it.
Mechanics of the game are phenomenal. They are there simple to put you under a test on how you use them or how crafty can you get with them. It's shame that there is only certain set of mechanics which are usable, but that's kind of given by the current chapter.
Completionists will have something to chew through here since there is quite a lot of optional objects to pick up.

It would be really awesome to have some kind of a chapter where there are most of the mechanics for you to use and get to fully try them all at one place. (I still haven't fully finished the cave yet, so idk about all the stuff there for now - I will edit this once I finish it)

Now cons
I only have 2 where both can be described as problematic under certain cirmustances and both of them aren't really big deal, but I need to address them since one frustrated me and I couldn't make heads and tails out of the other one.

The first one is screen shake.
Screen shake occures when you dash, pick up an object or interact with some mechanic, which later on in the game happens quite a lot. It's not really intrusive once you get used it, but I found one place where I REALLY needed this to be turned off, but couldn't find any settings for this.

Loss of momentum upon releasing movement keys.
I don't have anything against this mechanic being in the game as it is, but there is one (or maybe more) moment(s) where it hit me in the face. When you are traveling on a fast moving object and you want to jump and land on the object again. Laws of this game are strongly against it by the way. If you hold a movement key and jump, it launches you ahead of the object and you better be careful how you get back on it or if you just jump, you slow down incredibly fast so you better be standing at the front of the object so you manage to land at the rear of it.

39671021.review:
I was a fan of TowerFall Ascension (having it be my favorite indie game), so I was excited for this game to come out. After playing through it, I can say this is one of the best platformers of the past few years and I recommend it above almost everything else.

Pros:
- The level design is top notch. Each screen feels like something new, yet also builds on past ideas.
- Even though the game is fairly difficult, it is liberal with checkpoints, follows a proper difficulty curve, and doesn't feel artificial.
- The game is full of collectible strawberries. Usually, I would ignore them but they make up much of the meat of the game. The platforming challenges to get them are tough, but they feel rewarding to achieve. There were a few times where they were so difficult they stood out, but the game design was strong enough that it made me want to collect them.
- There are a few new platforming ideas with each new area that are properly reinforced and used to their full potential while also not totally outstaying their welcome.
- The soundtrack is pretty (almost as good as TowerFall's).
- Each of the levels is aesthetically varied.
- With the strawberries and more difficult versions of each level as well as an "arcade version" of the game and a secret eighth level, there is a substantial amount of content. Edit: This game actually as so much content that you'd still be at the surface of it if you just beat the game once.
- For what it is, the story is surprisingly good and doesn't intrude on the gameplay.

Cons:
- The controls take a while to get used to at first, so there can be frustrating deaths resulting from it.
- It's probably more of my fault for being stupid, but there was one time I got stuck for unnecessary reasons. This happened I didn't realize how a game mechanic worked. This is probably more of a personal experience than an actual problem with the game, but it might be worth mentioning.
- To get the B side for the 8th level, it's absolutely required that you have all the hearts before it, including the extremely well hidden secret ones. It is pretty fun to try to follow a guide and see what you missed, but it probably shouldn't be required.
- It certainly felt good to beat, but was the final screen of the 7th C side really necessary?
- For some reason the game crashes a lot on me.

So.

I don't write reviews normally unless its to make a joke in them. But Celeste. Celeste is wonderful. The music in the game is so dang good, and always fits the location you're in. The platforming is amazing, going from perfect sequence sections where one mistake means death and sections where you have a large margin of error. The game is just enjoyable. The story never really takes a backseat, but it's not forgettable. It's not a background thing you can forget and ignore throughout because it's done so well, and so integral to some sections. You want a happy ending, and damn if the game doesn't give you the ability to reach that. 

I'd highly recommend for anyone wanting a hard platformer with collectibles and a great soundtrack, or for those who can't platform for their lives and just want a touching tale theres Assist mode, which lets you change the rules of the game to help you, whether that means slowing down the gamespeed, giving yourself more jumps, or just making yourself invulnerable.

For those who want a real challenge, theres a side-B alternate world hidden within each, that offers increased challenge for those who want to really see what they can do with the different mechanics introduced in each section of the game. The alternate worlds offer new challenges, harder platforming, and a rocking remix of the normal course soundtrack, leading to a great experience, despite the fact you'll be listening to it for a while on account of the difficulty.

As I said, I'd highly recommend this game.

39664088.review:
First real review of a game decided to make this short and to the point so you get the basics on this masterpiece.

Art- I'm a sucker for pixel art but this is much more. The world map on the menu screen is huge and beautiful showing you all the places of your journey. The characters during dialog show their personalities perfectly. The levels are all stunning with anything from vibrant yellows and pinks to dark caves filled with little to no light. I could not ask for more in art assisting the overall game so 10/10 for this category.

Music- Basically it's amazing. Chiptune tracks follow you throughout each level only to abruptly stop at a story event leaving ominous atmospheres. The tracks individually are all amazing and do nothing but make the trek up the mountain feel breathtaking. The characters voices are the undertale style of sounds designated to each character over spoken words (yes I know these are in more games than undertale, I’m trying to be relatable) but this game adds a bit more to that aspect. Their sounds clearly show their personalities and it ends up as more meaningful than just scrolling text. 10/10

Story- Now here is where I was extremely surprised with the game. This is a platformer, a difficult platformer, that tells an actually meaningful story. Is tells a very relatable tale of depression and anxiety but mostly how we can get over these things using the mountain you are climbing as a metaphor. I have never seen a platforming game with anything like this making this game truly unique. Even so the story never intrudes with the gameplay and every cutscene is skippable. 10/10

Gameplay- Now here's the main course. If you’re looking into this game you're probably doing it for the challenging gameplay, right? Well all I can tell you is you are getting all that you could ever want from that department. The controls are super tight leading every death to be your fault. The levels are extremely varied as each introduces new obstacles and mechanics for you to play around with. Everything is so streamlined that you never once think about how you should have chosen such and such skill as there is nothing other than a dash and a wall climb. Excluding powerups you will be using these at all times. No pointless skills or items you have to buy. Just you and the mountain. If you end up beating the game then be ready for the huge amount of post game content. Each level has strawberries to collect and a cassette tape each. These cassette tapes open up much harder B-sides of each level. There are also much more special collectibles hidden deep within each level to find. If you happen to complete all B-sides be ready for the ultimate challenge that we must not even talk about here. So much content, amazIng mechanics, never boring. 10/10

Enjoyment- I hope it is obvious to you that I enjoy this game a lot. The bar is set extremely high for platformers in 2018, I just don’t know if it can be reached. I don’t remember a time I liked a platformer this much and don’t know if it will ever happen again. 10/10


Overall- Most complete games always coming from indies these days. No B.S. just an amazing game that is so worth your time
Final Score:10/10

100%*: 21 hours. Over 3900 deaths. It's stats like these that show how good a platformer is.

Celeste is a platforming game with a story that rings to the heart of a platformer. I want to climb the mountain. I don't have a reason, I don't know if I can, I am my own worst enemy, but by the end of the day I WILL climb that mountain.

Celeste features a multitude of mechanics you've seen elsewhere, mashed together in a perfect melody. It's not what they add but how well they add it and they did a perfect job. The regular story is acceptably difficult, tailored to teaching you mechanics and letting the average joe beat the game with a challenge. It also features berries to unlock that are reasonable hidden everywhere and provide an extra challenge through the regular mission. The remixes are brutal and amazing recreations of the levels for the platformer veterans. If you manage to break your way through all of that there is yet another final challenge waiting at the end.

But the best thing Celeste does is not belittle your time; after every level completed you get to see what berries you've missed, in what order they are in, and fast travel points through the level.

*: Not including gold berries

39659749.review:
If you love tight, tough platformers you owe it to yourself to play this.  If they think you might enjoy this style game, same deal.  While tough, it isn't impossible, and the assist mode lets you dial down the difficulty if you're having trouble.  Many of  the challenges of the game are entirely optional, with no real change to gameplay because of it.  There are some uses for a super rare pickup, and B side cassettes to find, which unlock even harder levels, but both are for post-story content.  The game takes a thoughtful approach to difficulty and accessibility that makes it the perfect introduction to tough platformers.

I've loved Matt's games for a long time and Celeste doesn't dissapoint.  The platforming's astoundingly good, walking a very delicate line between tough but fun and for masochists only.  Even though I died a heck of a lot of times (2864, I think) at no point did I look and think "you know what, no.  That's impossible.  I'll never do that."  It builds your skills slowly, always at the edge of what you think you can do until you're pulling off some incredible moves at the end.  It's an intense experience, and I have a blister on my thumb now, but it was well worth it.

Between the awesome level design, incredible controls and fantastic presentation this is easily my favorite platformer I've played in a long time.  Please play this game.  It is everything a tough, tight platformer should be.

39657892.review:
A really good but also really hard Platformer. The gameplay revolves around your two main abilities: Wall climbing and dashing. It doesn't seem like much but each new level introduce new object interacting differently with your abilities (platform moving only when you dash, cristal allowing you to dash several times if you touch them in mid-air, etc...), adding to that the exponentially increasing difficulty and even with only two abilities the game doesn't feel repetitive at all.

The story is nice and can be finished really quickly (5~6 hours) if you don't explore any of the levels. Most of the content of the game is actually on all the additional stuff. First, there is the numerous strawberries scattered in each levels that are either hidden or way more difficult to reach than just doing the normal path. Then, each level has a B-side which is like a hardcore version of the level. Finally, add to that a final chapter after you finish the main game that turn the difficulty up to 11 and you get a ton of additional content. After playing for 9 hours i'm about halfway through all of this.

Combine all this with a beautiful soundtrack, a beautiful pixel art and really nice level design and you get a game i have no hesitation recommanding if you don't mind playing a difficult platformer.

My only complaints:
- Sometimes screens are pretty long and you can't see what you're in store for until it's too late. This can be frustrating in a game where perfect execution and creative thinking is required, resulting in a lot of die and retry scenarios that are almost unavoidable.

- I found using an Xbox controller with the anolog stick the dashes didn't always go in the direction I wanted to. For example I wanted to go up right but it would go right instead. Might work better on other controllers, or a keyboard, though I'd recommend controller.

I died 1234 times and loved every second.

39650551.review:
Haven't put too much time into this game yet, but I just had to recommend it.

Everything about Celeste feels just right. The level design is impeccable, the controls are tight, but not unforgiving, the characters are lovely, the visuals are very pretty, the soundtrack is just beautiful and it all fits together really nicely.
Each chapter takes just a small handful of mechanics and gets the absolute most out of them. The main path has, so far, been challenging, but not too difficult. However, look out for cassette tapes because the B-sides of each chapter take the same mechanics and make much more difficult levels out of them.

And yet, throughout all that, it never becomes frustrating, at least not so far. Even if I die over and over again, I'm never more than maybe 10 to 20 seconds away from the last checkpoint. There are a few longer sections without a checkpoint to really test your mettle, but they are the exception and even then, there's maybe one or two per chapter and B-side. Regardless of that, the path is always perfectly clear.

It is a challenging game, but also has comprehensive accessibility options in form of the Assist Mode. Invulnerability, more dashes, infinite stamina or just slowing down the game. It's clear that the developers really want this game to be accessible to anyone without restricting you. I would personally recommend trying it without first, but the option is always there and the game locks absolutely nothing away from you for using it. Not collectables, not levels, not even achievements.
Be aware, though, that activating it puts a big "ASSIST MODE" stamp on your save file and there is no way to turn Assist Mode back off again.

If you, like me, already like precision platformers (games like Super Meat Boy, Dustforce, N++, They Bleed Pixels and their ilk), then this is a no-brainer. If you haven't tried precision platformers yet, then this is a great introduction. And who knows, maybe you'll learn to love the genre on your journey up the mountain to find out more about Madeline, Theo and just what on earth you're even doing up there. There's certainly a lot to love about this game.

39650393.review:
Celeste is one of my favourite games, even if I haven't completed it yet. I love the pixel graphics mixed in with the beautiful soundtrack, which is one of the best soundtracks I've ever heard. 

Celeste is game which takes part with a young girl by the name of Madeline, trying for some reason to climb Celeste mountain. During the intro Madeline discovers she has a unique ability which allows her to dash in any direction quickly. This dash ability creates for some challenging tasks which requires accurate button presses.

There are 8 chapters which have multiple levels in each, (with over 700 levels in the whole game!) and each chapter a new game mechanic is added. For example: In the first chapter there are platforms which move when you touch them, and then stop giving you momentum in order to cross a large gap in the level, the 5th chapter when you dash some platforms with move instantly and slowly return. Which can lead to some interesting level designs. 

Celeste rewards exploration. In each chapter there are multiple strawberries you can collect which don't really do anything and are usually far off the main story but it is nice collecting all the strawberries and feeling like you have beat that chapter 100%. In each chapter there is a cassette tape you can pick up called a B-Side which unlocks a far far significantly more difficult level, which can keep you trying, and trying again, and again until you give up and come back tomorrow and then smash that piece of impossibleness trash away with you're super amazing skillzzzzz you got.

Overall the game is worth the $19.99 USD.


You get:
-Amazing soundtrack
-Beautiful pixel graphics
-Unique chapter design keeping the game from going stale
-Far far far difficult B-Side levels
-And you get... STRAWBERRIES!

39648015.review:
Celeste really surprised me. I can't say I expected a challenging platformer to also have one of the simplest, yet greatest stories in a game. 

The controls of the game feel very tight. There's been very little times where when I mess up it isn't my fault completely. Controls are very responsive, and the levels are very well designed. There was never any point where I thought any one jump was completely impossible, and because the game respawns you at the start of a screen (a la super meat boy), it never ends up feeling frustrating as you can very quickly jump back in and try again. The game's difficulty stays challenging, but never reaches levels where you just get bored/frustrated like in common challenging platformers. Can't particularly speak for the post-game/B-side stages, but if the level design stays the same I have no doubt it will feel similar.

The game really respects the ability for the player to improve. No matter what screen, I never got stuck for more than a few minutes until I finally succesfully completed a screen. The game also rewards exploration, to an outstanding degree. I can't say I wasn't suprised when the first time I went through a level, I had only collected 13/20 collectibles even when I thought I searched everywhere. 

The atmosphere is brilliant, blending the artstyle and the soundtrack awesomely. The soundtrack, by itself, is excellent. It always fit the area's theme, and even works great as a stand-alone for when you want to listen for some nice instrumental chiptune music. The sprite work is very reminiscient of common metroidvania games, which is well done, but nothing special. However, there's small quirks in the character portriats when speaking, and pictures that really give it a unique style, being pretty cute. 

The story was what really caught me off guard, though. Maybe because it hits personally, but it was very heartwarming and had themes that everyone should at least try and practice. Don't really want to spoil anything, but I was really satisfied by it and enjoyed it. I completed the main story in ~8 hours, and still have loads of collectibles/alternate stages to go through. There's a nice amounr of content here.

Overall, this is one of the best indie platformers to come out in a long while, rivaling (and maybe even beating) games such as Super Meat Boy, The End is Nigh, Shovel Knight, etc. If you have a spare $20 left over, I'd definitely recommend it.
