39646504.review:
this game is a [b] 9.5/10 [/b] game in my opinion.

In Celeste, you play as Madeline, a girl who is determined to climb Mount Celeste (the game's namesake) as she walljumps, springs, and dashes across seven ~40 minute long levels filled with platformer fun.

The game features collectible strawberries, which although are a great stat to show off as a completionist, give you pretty much nothing but 1000 "points" (a callback to the Pico-8 Celeste, which can actually be found and played in one of the levels). Each level has fairly branching paths, with one main path which progresses the story. None of these optonal paths are important to the story, and are just a way of getting extra challenge and strawberries, as well as occassionally a casette tape.

The beauty of Celeste comes in it's fun, well-crafted difficulty. It's not a game which will beat you over the head for missing pixel-perfect jumps, but rather a game which gives you the tools necessary to clear an obstacle before letting you loose to explore how to get around and over it. The strawberries don't count for anything (especially the ones in the Pico-8 minigame) but you tend to feel inclines to get them because the sense of reward for completing these fairly difficult challenges is incredible.

The casette tapes unlock the "B-Side" of whatever level you got it on after completion. The B-Side will push you and the level's mechanics to the limit as you hurdle past the nuttiest of obstacles. Despite the rediculous difficulty of these levels, completion feels not too time consuming and you get an extra reward for doing so.



[b] SPOILERS [/b]

[spoiler] The story features a villain, "Part of You" which behaves similarly to Shadow Mario from the Super Mario Galaxy games. She sometimes will be chasing you in your path and will kill you if you fall behind into your old path and touch her. She can be a pain in the ass sometimes, but she isn't featured in that way for most of the game. She drives most of the plot, and you get to whoop her ass in a really cool sequence towards the end of the game which is followed by your epic ascent to the summit of Mount Celeste, accompanied by an incredible, intense soundtrack.

After completion, a bonus level opens up, but you can only enter if you collect four "hearts" which are aquired from beating each B-Side level. that bonus level also has it's own B-Side, so get ready for hell. [/spoiler]

My only gripe is the untapped potential of the strawberries, but that doesn't really matter very much.

Overall, Celeste is a really well-designed game which doesn't reven remotely leave the player starved for content. Along with a stellar soundtrack and popping visuals as well as fantastic gameplay for both veterans and novices, This game is an easy grab, and I absolutely recommend you buy it.

39644631.review:
A beautiful platformer with surface simple movement mechanics that explode in depth when you really investigate the possibilites.

The story is beautiful and I imagine relatable for many people, but even mentioning the theme is a bit of a spoiler so I apologize for not making a convincing argument for it.

I had a wonderful time, and if I had to make three complaints, they would be:

- That later game there are several puzzle elements that are too directly dependent on the player which has always been a dangerous design choice in 2D video games.  It's frustrating to pricely manipulate them so a lot of deaths feel unfair.

- Whenever you hit a certain puzzle element that refreshes your movement, it does not take input for a very breif amount of time.  There should be an input buffer there if the game is going to pause for 1/10th of a second every time you touch it.  I've fallen to my death more than once because I tried to time my movement too well.

- It seems diagonal inputs have an even piece of the thumbstick pie.  It's easier to aim a thumbstick top, down, left, right, than it is top-right, down-left, etc.  It would've polished the controls if diagonals had just a slightly higher threshold.

But these are all things that you have plenty of time to get used to, and since the deaths are much like super meat boy, it's rarely upsetting to fail.  The rooms are rarely so big that a death feels frustrating, so you just keep going and polishing your skillset.

39644629.review:
Tight Controls, Amazing Soundtrack and quite a relatable journey, Celeste is a difficult 2-D platformer that greatly impresses. 

Gameplay is really solid and combined with interesting level designs that take advantage of it. From jumping to Air-dashing, its all really tight and responsive. You will feel in control of all actions. Each chapter has their own unique mechanic that starts with its own introduction through small experimentation that get more demanding and require full understanding of the mechanic to get through a screen.

Celeste is not an easy game. Similar to Super Meat Boy, Death counts will easily hit the hundreds by the 1st playthrough. Most of the deaths will probably come from collecting optional strawberries which can be a pain to get. Their an optional side activity that is just there for collection. Hidden Cassetes tapes also  unlock B-side levels that are remixed and a hard version of the level (Like Super Meat boy's Dark world) that ramps up the difficulty and is for those that want an even greater challenge. I suggest leaving B-side until after the main game is finished as jumping from B-side to normal play feels jarring imo. Perseverance is key to finishing Celeste and success gives that satisfying feeling of passing a screen or getting a strawberry that gave you hell.

If the difficulty is too much for you, Assist mode is a feature that allows you to tweak settings such as Game speed, Invincibilty and having infinite stamina to make the journey more comfortable. I suggest having this on briefly if your not used to these type of tough platformers and taking it off when you feel your up to experience the full challenge.

The soundtrack is definetly a highlight as they were quite an enjoyable experience on their own from emotional piano scores to jazz and chiptune. Celeste has what i would call an "Adaptive Soundtrack"  ramps up or tones down depending on the sitation. Progressing through a level will add more layers onto the song and will tone down for story sequences. Overall, soundtrack absolutely nails the setting and vibes that are presented in Celeste and warrants a purchase as It is probably the best part of Celeste  imo.

The story wont be spoiled. Its nothing ground-breaking but it is a rollercoaster of different emotions that can invoke some thought and is definetly relatable to those that are going through a similar time in life of being unsure of what to do with it or how to move on from the past.

Celeste is an amazing game that i suggest anyone that enjoys platformers or is simply interested in the game to buy at full price. Let it be a sign for MMG to make more experiences like Celeste

I put an eye on this developer (Matt Makes Games) since his pretty awesome metroidvania An Untilted Story (check this out, its actually clever and fun game, not to mention it's free), so i had some great  expectations towards this one. 
And what could i say, hope is justified.  
Celeste - is smart kind of hardcore platformer, which is playing with his mechanics with real appretiation and  it's done perfect. All new features on levels and your standart abilities getting full synergy across the game, nothing is wasted. Great thing about this game is it's pacing, content just keep coming in the way that gets you more involved, i'm not really into long game sessions, but this got me playing it for almost 4 hours without any distractions. 
Controls is nicely put together and feels natural. Music is light and not brainsmashing, mostly piano based tunes, doing great with atmosphere. I guess controls and music (and ofcourse smart gamedesign decisions) is a key here to make you keep playing even when you can't beat some hard section of game. 
Visually it's clean   pixel art with simple but catchy graphics and design, rich backgrounds. However i had one issue with finding obstacle at the end of 3rd world, but it's completly not a big deal.
One more thing, i notice that for some reason characters, story, dialoges kinda reminds me of Nickelodeon era cartoons gets me some nostalgic vibes. 
In conclusion i would recommend this game if you want to play some solid hardcore platformer game. 
For me subjectively, as not much of a hardcore gamer Celeste gave not only challenge but managed to entertain me aswell.

39641561.review:
Красивый (насколько может быть красивой пиксельная игра) платформер с потрясщающей музыкой. Увлекательный геймплей, в основе которого лежат механики, уникальные для каждого уровня и меняющие подход к прохождению уровней. Комнаты с ягодами не похожи одна на другую и к каждой нужен свой подход (и очень часто, не один десяток попыток), а некоторые из них спрятаны очень хорошо и придётся не один раз пробежаться чтобы собрать все ягоды! Периодически вам будут встречаться различные персонажи, разговор с которыми даст небольшую передышку между, иногда кажется, бесконечным уровнем. В общем отличный платформер за небольшие деньги, который подарит массу положительных эмоций… до того момента пока вы не найдёте свою первую аудиокассету, которая открывает бонусный уровень и показывает игру совсем с другой стороны.

  Бонусные уровни — это греховный плод союза обычных уровней Celeste и I Wanna Be The Boshy благословлённый самим Сатаной. Они не до абсурда сложны как в Боши, но неподготовленных заставят понервничать и бросать играть, чтобы потом опять вернуться и наконец пройти ту самую часть уровня на которой вы уже сидите минут 20 чтобы подсунуть вам ещё более сложное испытание в следующей комнате! Вы будете молить чтобы этот уровень скорее закончился, чтобы перейти к следующей главе (я не переходил к следующей части игры пока не завершал бонусный уровень) и посмотреть наконец сколько раз ты умудрился умереть, ведь разработчки любезно в конце каждого прохождения показывают сколько ты раз умудрился сдохнуть пока всё не прошёл (на одном из бонусных уровней я умудрился умереть 1400 раз). Однако то сильное чувство удовлетворения которое ты получаешь от прохождения этих бонусных уровней как назло заставят и дальше их проходить.

10 "Я всё равно достану эту ягоду"\10

39636510.review:
Let me just start by saying I'm not very good at platformers, I usually try to rush through them, dying again and again until I finally get frustrated enough to give up. thankfully the developers of Celeste have made their game for casuals and hardcore fans of the genre alike.

The platforming in Celeste is top notch (as it should be in a platformer), Madeline feels smooth and satisfying to control, jumping, dashing, ledge grabbing, and climbing all feel natural and fun to execute. it's probably best played with a D-pad as using the analog stick is kind of flimsy at times and causes you to jump or dash in the wrong direction, which usually ends in death and multiple retries of the same section.

Celeste's level design never gets slow or stale, it feels original and fresh from start to finish, never was there a dull moment. New concepts and mechanics are thrown at the player with each new level, keeping a steady increase in difficulty and creativity. every bit of platforming revolves around Madeline's dashing ability, from special green crystals that recharge your dash when broken, to platforms that move when a dash is performed, every puzzle in Celeste is based on the dash. 

If the game is too difficult for you, there is an assist mode with options like extra dashes or invincibility, You can still get all the collectibles with assist mode turned on which is nice, but it does feel a bit like cheating and therefore makes getting the collectibles far less rewarding. For the more hardcore fans of the genre, every level has a B-side tape you can find and collect to unlock a much MUCH! harder version of that level, after completing the B-sides you are given access to the C-side levels, which as you might have guessed ramp up the difficulty to the extreme.

Not only is Celeste beaming with delightfully colorful pixel art and one of the most amazing soundtracks you may ever hear in a video game, but it also has a much more down to earth and relatable story than you would expect from a game of its genre, tackling such subjects as depression and anxiety.

The characters you run into during your quest to best the mountain are quite charming and full of personality, each with their own distinct synthesized voices making it quite easy to get attached to them. The dialogue is smartly written and genuine as well as funny at times, which adds to the overall charm of the encounters with these characters.

With more than seven-hundred screens, there are plenty of seriously challenging yet rewarding platforming puzzles to be solved, secrets to find, and a beautifully told story full of charm and personality to be experienced. There are plenty of good times to be had with Celeste, even though it can get frustratingly hard every now and then, it's still always worth coming back to.

39626183.review:
[b] Celeste: A Climb You Won't Soon Forget [/b]

Simply put, Celeste is a fantastic 2D platformer that any fan of the genre will love and appreciate. If you enjoyed games such as Super Meat Boy, The End is Nigh, N++, Hollow Knight, Super Mario Bros, and Shovel Knight, this game is right up your alley. It's fun, it's challening, and it's worth your money, so read no further and buy this game. 

Celeste is comprised of 8 chapters, each filled with unique mechanics and near perfect level design. The start of each chapter slowly introduces a mechanic, sometimes more than one mechanic, and slowly builds on it until the peak of the chapter where it truly challenges you, knowing you're fully equipped with the knowledge and understanding to beat it. This formula is persistent throughout the entire game, but it works very well and makes for a consistent difficulty curve that never feels too unfair or frustrating. If it does become too difficult for you, there's an option called "Assist Mode" that can make the game easier in many ways. Similar to the Simple mode in Cuphead. Levels are also filled with strawberries to collect, completely optional, however, they serve as some of the games greatest challenges and getting them all really fills you with pride and satisfaction. There are other collectibles to find, but I'll keep them a secret save for one: The B side. In each chapter you can find a secret tape. After completion of the chapter, you can select the B side which is basically a remixed, hard version of that chapter. These remixed chapters are tough as balls and if your platforming skills aren't adept enough you can easily spend hours trying to get through them. Again, optional, but beating them feels very rewarding.

The most important part of a platformer is arguably the controls. If the controls suck, the entire game falls apart on itself and simple jumps become daunting tasks. Celeste does not suffer from this problem in the slighest bit. Your movest is comprised of jumping, grabbing on to walls, and a one use dash that refreshes on contact with solid ground. Never does the control scheme feel slow or weak. It flows so well and feels so smooth. None of the mechanics (except the wind) feel clunky or hard to execute either, and are incorporated into the gameplay seamlessly. 

While many people lately seem to feel pixel art in indie games is cheap and just tries to be pixelated because that's so indie, I couldn't disagree more when it comes to celeste. The game looks great. The snow blowing through the air, the gorgeous sunrise, the abandoned hotel with remnants of the past, all of the environments just look fantastic. Each chapter is also accompanied by an outstanding soundtrack that never gets repetitous to listen to.The music in this game also helps set the tone the specific chapter is tring to evoke to a near perfect degree. If there were any complaints I had with the art it would be the text boxes and the map select. These are not pixelated and as a result look very jarring, and don't mesh very well in my opinion. There are moments where it allows for the characters to feel more animated and detailed facial expressions, but I think the differing art styles is one of the weaker elements of celeste.

On top of all these amazing qualities, Celeste has a pretty good story. Nothing revolutionary or mindblowing, but engaging and interesting nonetheless, and makes the player feel more connected to our protagonist, making you more invested in getting to the top of the mountain. Even if the themes and message of the story isn't very original, it's told well and does keep you interested. And hey, what was the last time a 2D platformer actually had a story beyond get this thing or person because you have to. 

Celeste is a platformer enthusiast's ideal game, and for many will even exceed expectations. Seriously, I can't recommend this game enougn, go do yourself a favor and play it.

39623122.review:
Celeste is a precise platformer with charming characters and atmosphere, and a simple yet surprisingly relatable story. The gameplay is structured into small rooms each different from the last, Similar in style to The End is Nigh. I love games with dash mechanics and this pulls it off in a very natural way, It doesn't feel like some "special move" or anything like that it feels smooth combing jumping, dashing, and climbing walls. The game wastes no time with tutorials simply telling you a button input and... well that's it, The game's level design is structured in a way that allows the player to figure things out on their own, discovering the subtleties of movement, thus respecting their inteligence. This is a constant throughout the game as each Chapter of the game introduces a new mechanic for that specific chapter, The game however never gives any explicit tutorials on these new mechanics, and let's the player, once again to, quickly learn and understand what this new mechanic does.

The presentation is simply phenominal, The music is an ambient chiptune, complimenting the game's atmosphere wonderfully.  And the pixel art is quite charming, having a nostalgic feel to it. I quite like the game's use Of text boxes as the background for each one is different depending on the character. I really like the game's use of character portraits, you can see them blink and move, it's a nice small detail. The art at the end of each chapter made me feel cozy and accomplished for my efforts. a cherry on top (of a mountain) in a way.

This game's plot is simple yet surprisingly enjoyable, The two main characters, Madeline and Theo are very likeable.
Madeline swaps between being caring and being passive agressive and snarky. You progresively learn more about her as the game progresses which I won't spoil. Theo I have mixed feelings about, he's the stereotyplical cool nerd, using apps, taking selfies, saying things like "Yolo" that person who can easily be found on any college campus. His carefree attitude functions as a sort of foil for Madeline, making her flaws all the more noticeable. The dialouge for every character in this game is quite enjoyable from my perspective.

Overall, Celeste is a charming adventure of self discovery, challenging you with difficult yet fair levels. If you enjoy simple and fun platformser that don't to anything too fancy, you will More than likely enjoy Celeste. I sincerely loved celeste, I will likely play through multiple times past writing this review, and I look forward to it.

39617847.review:
Celeste is a 2D action platforming game with tight controls, ingenius puzzles, and adorable art. You play as a girl climbing Celeste Mountain, a treacherous abandoned ruin filled with deadly traps. Along the way you face your fears and discover some unsettling people and places.

Celeste is made by Matt Thorson, known mostly for TowerFall but also the creator of other old-school platformers like An Untitled Story and the Jumper series. Celeste definitely has thatsignature Thorson action - tight control inputs, precise timing, and quick reflexes are a MUST if you want to master this game. The game doesn't punish failure, however - failing simply puts you back at the start of your current screen, meaning you can immediately leap back into action.

If you're looking for a challenge, there are optional collectibles scattered throughout each level, and some of them require true precision and timing to collect. There is also an unlockable B Side for each level, and the B Side variant of each level doubles down on the challenge.

Don't let the pixel art fool you - there is some incredible character art in this game. Each time you complete a chapter, you're rewarded with a piece of incredible artwork. The characters you meet along the way are funny and interesting, but you aren't forced to listen to the whole story if you want to just get back to the action.

I would definitely recommend Celeste to anyone who enjoyed any of Matt Thorson's previous games, or to anyone who just loves fast-paced platforming with clever puzzles and satisfying challenges like in Super Meat Boy or VVVVVV.

39615693.review: This game is outstanding. One of the best games I've played to date. First off, the visuals and music are so polished and beautiful. I just want every screen of this game as my background (the backgrounds are incredibly detailed and help make the game feel very polished) and I could listen to this music for hours. I mean, each level has it's own death transition! That should give you a taste of how much love the developers put into this game. The dialogue is incredibly charming and tells a story about complicated feelings so elegantly and with so much honesty (I mean, you can feel it through the dialogue). The gameplay is incredibly fluid and its difficulty curve is perfect (However, I am a platformer afficiando, so take that with a grain of salt). I mean, seriously. Just jumping around and dashing in an empty space feels amazing, and there are so many collectibles to find using these amazing controls! You can choose to play on assist mode, or complete the game 100% and have an outstanding time no matter what. This game simply gets everything right: from skippable cutscenes to counters that help see what you missed in a level. The B-sides are just as fun as the main story and there's secrets hiding in every corner. No secret makes you want to use a walkthrough; they are well-hidden, but also well telegraphed. There are so many cool, inventive mechanics to come across while traversing through in this game... and the level design... Oh, the level design! It's absolutely perfect. This game is incredible and a great start if you want to start playing hardcore platformers. 10/10

39614648.review:
Celeste is one of the best challenging platformers I have ever played. 

Check out my video review - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0c42lMl6y1g

For the longest time Super Meat Boy held this position for me, but with Celeste's story it takes the top spot. 

Tackling issues with anxiety and self-acceptance made the journey far more personal than I would have expected. The game is also only as hard as you want it to be. You can approach it from different perspectives. Speedrunning, exploration, story, or through an assist mode for players who may struggle with the difficulty. 

The main set of levels may be seen as very easy for players, but if you manage to find the B-side tapes hidden in different chapters you unlock a very difficult set of the same levels. 

While much more challenging, the design of these levels come very considered. I never felt like I didn't know how to move forward, it was just a matter of good execution. 

The visuals and music are incredible too, honestly this game is the whole package, and you'd be crazy to pass it up.

My only real complaint was that the game didn't have much online functionality. There are some big global numbers where you can see how many deaths there are amongst all players. I would have really liked to have seen other players' speedrun numbers, otherwise you have nothing to compare to.

39612991.review:
This game feels like what happens when you take all those super hard balls to the wall platformers and actually put some effort into them beyond testing the players patience or desire to be a masochist. I would call this the Dark Souls of platformers, but that would be an insult to the game.

Right off the back the game doesn't waste time with over drawn tutorials, immedietely telling you everything that you need to know, jump, dash, die, repeat. Sure on paper it seems frustrating but the absolutely non existant wait time between dying and respawning minimizes any frustration you may feel, turning each death into a learning experience as you slowly feel yourself going from completely overhwlemed at the challegned lying before you to mountain climbing acrobat fueled by the curiousity, hope, and luck.

Based on my limited time with the game so far i can tell you the music and the writing are pretty well done, I love the piano instrumental that plays in the background as you scale the tower.

I reccomend this game completely.

39611908.review:
ign10分大作？像素跑酷？不就是super meat boy嘛，能好玩到哪去？




emmmmm

现在几点了？

===================================
2D跑酷其实已经非常多了，比较著名的，《i wanna》系，《Super Meat Boy》，《Ori》等，都以硬核为卖点，本作其实也不例外。《celeste》更像是《The End Is Nigh》，很多相似点但是其实完全不同。

100分钟初体验评测：
玩法上，
玩家控制的主角可以二段跳（实际上是跳+冲刺）+扒墙，用这些能力进行一些复杂的跑酷登山就是主要玩法了。[spoiler]手柄上三四个键加摇杆，初接触有点手忙脚乱。光熟悉操作就要死十几次[/spoiler]但是比较有意思的是他的跑酷支线非常多，我自认为比较仔细的收集了第一章的收集品，结算界面显示11/20，表明我只找到了一半左右！可见其内容量之大，ign介绍说有700多张图..

剧情只看了个开头不好评价，但是叙事风格很棒。

音乐极佳。和游戏节奏很扣，甚至有节拍的地图会专门有个节拍bgm，感官享受！

但是话说回来，游戏还是得看游戏性，部分关卡设计创意十足，有些就是老套的东西了，但是并不影响总体体验非常好这一情况。操作上我觉得手感没有《The End Is Nigh》好，有点滑溜不好控制，让游戏难度提升了非常多，个人感觉。[spoiler] 我感觉是手柄键位的问题，键盘党也许会好一些。[/spoiler]

9.5/10
+玩法优秀，关卡设计复杂且丰富
+音乐极佳

-操作不顺畅带来的难度提升

对于硬核跑酷玩家一定不能错过
休闲玩家可以等各大视频了，难度确实有点高。

39611431.review:
DON'T MISS CELESTE, JUST GET IT.

This game is simply beautiful. 
If you played Towerfall, you'll feel right home. The controls feel great and the dash ability is really, really fun.
But the thing that I'm loving the most so far is the atmosphere. It feels like a childhood memory. 
Celeste REWARDS EXPLORATION. This is the main selling point for me. I just spent a lot of time in a level just to see at the end that I only got 11/20 collectibles. It's filled with surprises and pretty little scenarios and vistas.

The people that made this game are great and love videogames. You'll see that love poured in every sound, artwork and animation. 

So, what are you waiting for? Go climb the Celeste mountain.
